built with pdoc

ediff.center

Module: ediff.center

Find the center of a 2D diffraction pattern.

  • The center determination may be surprisingly tricky in certain cases.
  • Nevertheless, usually it is enough to call CenterLocator as shown below.
  • More details and examples at GitHub: https://mirekslouf.github.io/ediff/docs
>>> # Example: How to use CenterLocator and get results?
>>> import ediff as ed
>>>
>>> center = ed.center.CenterLocator(
>>>    input_image='some_diffractogram.png',
>>>    determination='intensity',
>>>    refinement='sum',
>>>    verbose=False, final_replot=True)
>>>
>>> print('Determined center coordinates:', center.x1, center.y1)
>>> print('Refined center coordinates   :', center.x2, center.y2)

   1'''
   2Module: ediff.center
   3--------------------
   4Find the center of a 2D diffraction pattern.
   5
   6* The center determination may be surprisingly tricky in certain cases.
   7* Nevertheless, usually it is enough to call `CenterLocator` as shown below.
   8* More details and examples at GitHub: https://mirekslouf.github.io/ediff/docs
   9
  10>>> # Example: How to use CenterLocator and get results?
  11>>> import ediff as ed
  12>>>
  13>>> center = ed.center.CenterLocator(
  14>>>    input_image='some_diffractogram.png',
  15>>>    determination='intensity',
  16>>>    refinement='sum',
  17>>>    verbose=False, final_replot=True)
  18>>>
  19>>> print('Determined center coordinates:', center.x1, center.y1)
  20>>> print('Refined center coordinates   :', center.x2, center.y2)
  21'''
  22
  23# CenterDet, major update and improvements by MS->PS
  24# PS 2023-10-06: CentDet update, methods compatibility
  25# MS 2023-11-26: Improved code formatting and docs + TODO notes for PS
  26# MS 2024-23-09: Re-desing/draft of CenterLocator => CenterLocator_new
  27# PS 2025-XX-XX: Updates + imporovements in branch {center_determination}
  28# MS 2025-08-01: Import of {center_determination} branch to {main) 
  29    
  30
  31import numpy as np
  32import skimage as sk
  33import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
  34from matplotlib.patches import Circle
  35from matplotlib.legend_handler import HandlerBase
  36from math import floor
  37from scipy.optimize import curve_fit
  38from scipy.ndimage import map_coordinates
  39
  40import ediff.io 
  41import ediff.radial 
  42import os
  43import cv2
  44
  45from skimage.measure import moments
  46from skimage.transform import hough_circle, hough_circle_peaks
  47from skimage.registration import phase_cross_correlation
  48import skimage.feature as skf
  49from scipy.ndimage import gaussian_filter
  50
  51from scipy.signal import find_peaks
  52from scipy.fft import _pocketfft, set_backend
  53from textwrap import dedent
  54
  55import sys
  56import warnings
  57warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")
  58
  59from functools import wraps
  60CPU_COUNT = os.cpu_count()
  61
  62
  63class CenterLocator:
  64    '''
  65    CenterLocator object : determine and refine the center of a 2D electron 
  66    diffraction pattern (diffractogram)
  67    
  68    This class detects the center of diffraction patterns. It offers several 
  69    automatic or manual methods and optionally refines the center position.
  70
  71
  72    Parameters
  73    ----------
  74    input_image : str, path, or numpy.ndarray
  75        The input 2D diffraction image, either a file path or a NumPy array.
  76
  77    determination : str or None, optional, default=None
  78        Method used for the initial center determination.
  79        Options include:
  80        - 'manual': Manual detection = interactive plot where the user
  81          selects 3 points defining a diffraction ring with a mouse.
  82        - 'intensity' : Auto-detection = the intensity center
  83          from the central region.
  84        - 'curvefit': Automatic detection = fit the intensity center
  85          from the central region using pseudo-Voigt profile.                      
  86        - 'hough' : Automatic detection using Hough transform
  87          to find center of ring-like structures.
  88        - 'phase' : Automatic detection using phase correlation
  89          to find the symmetry center.
  90        - 'ccorr' : Automatic detection using cross-correlation
  91          to find the symmetry center.
  92        - None : Skip the center determination;
  93          it is supposed that the center coordinates
  94          will be read from *in_file* argument - see below.
  95          
  96    refinement : str or None, optional, default=None
  97        Method used for refining the initially detected center.
  98        Options include:
  99        - 'manual': Manual fine-tuning of the center along
 100          the selected diffraction ring.
 101        - 'sum' : Automatic refinement by maximizing the intensity sum
 102          the selected diffraction ring.
 103        - 'var': Automatic refinement by minimizing intensity variance
 104          the selected diffraction ring.
 105
 106    rtype : int, default=1
 107        How to determine a radius of a difraction ring for center refinement.
 108        In powder diffractograms, the diffraction rings are clearly defined.
 109        In spotty diffractograms, the diffraction ring is an fictive ring
 110        connecting at least three diffraction spots.
 111        Options include:
 112        - 0 : Peak matching method
 113          (fast and simple, but failing for non-powders, historical).
 114        - 1 : Radial distribution method
 115          (slower but more universal, new default).
 116        
 117    in_file : str or None, optional, default=None
 118        Path to a file from which the (previously saved)
 119        center coordinates will be loaded.
 120
 121    out_file : str or None, optional, default=None
 122        Path to a file where the determined
 123        center coordinates will be saved.
 124        
 125    sobel : bool, optional, default=False
 126        If True, apply Sobel filter to the image before processing.
 127        
 128    heq : bool or None, optional, default=False
 129        If True, apply histogram equalization internally (display unchanged).
 130
 131    icut : float or None, optional, default=None
 132        Cut-off intensity level for processing the image.
 133        
 134    cmap : str, optional, default='gray'
 135        Matplotlib colormap name used for displaying the image.
 136        
 137    csquare : int, optional, default=50
 138        Size (in pixels) of the central square used for initial center search.
 139        
 140    cintensity : float, optional, default=0.8
 141        Threshold intensity for finding the intensity center. Pixels with a 
 142        (relative) intensity lower than cintensity are ignored.
 143        
 144    verbose : int, optional, default=0
 145        Verbosity level for printing messages during processing:
 146        - 0 : Silent mode  no messages are printed.
 147        - 1 : Show help messages during manual refinement only.
 148        - 2 : Full verbose mode  print all messages and debug information.
 149        - 3 : Progress mode  print brief status updates during time-consuming 
 150              processing.
 151        
 152    print_sums : bool, optional, default=False
 153        If True, print intensity sums after each adjustment (in manual modes).
 154        
 155    final_print : bool, optional, default=True
 156        If True, print final coordinates to stdout.
 157    
 158    live_plot : bool, optional, default=True
 159        If True, show live visualization of some processes if available.
 160 
 161    Returns
 162    -------
 163    None
 164        The result is stored in the instance variables:
 165        - `(x1, y1)` for the initially determined center
 166        - `(x2, y2)` for the refined center (if refinement is applied)
 167            
 168    Technical notes
 169    ---------------
 170    * The class automatically initializes and uses two internal components:
 171      `CenterDetermination` and `CenterRefinement`.
 172    * These internal processes are hidden from the user but can be accessed 
 173      directly if needed.
 174
 175    Examples
 176    --------
 177    >>> import ediff as ed
 178    >>>
 179    >>> locator = ed.center.CenterLocator(
 180    >>>    input_image   = '.r/path/to/your/data.png',   
 181    >>>    determination = 'manual',           
 182    >>>    refinement    = 'sum',
 183    >>>    final_print   = True)   
 184                              
 185    '''
 186    
 187    
 188    def __init__(self,
 189                 input_image, 
 190                 determination = None, 
 191                 refinement = None,
 192                 rtype = 1,
 193                 in_file = None,
 194                 out_file = None,
 195                 sobel = False,
 196                 masking = True,
 197                 ellipse = False,
 198                 mcorrect = None,
 199                 heq = False, 
 200                 icut = None,
 201                 cmap = 'gray',
 202                 csquare=50,
 203                 cintensity=0.8,
 204                 verbose = 0,
 205                 print_sums = False,
 206                 final_print = True,
 207                 live_plot = False):
 208        
 209        ######################################################################
 210        # PRIVATE FUNCTION: Initialize CenterLocator object.
 211        # The parameters are described above in class definition.
 212        ######################################################################
 213
 214        ## Initialize input attributes ---------------------------------------
 215        
 216        # Input image = diffraction pattern
 217        # (it can be either image file or numpy array)
 218        self.input_image = input_image
 219        
 220        # Methods of center determination, refinement, and radius estimation
 221        self.determination = determination
 222        self.refinement = refinement
 223        self.rtype = rtype
 224        
 225        # For reproducibility, convert the method names to lowercase
 226        if determination is not None:
 227            self.determination = determination.lower()
 228        if refinement is not None:
 229            self.refinement = refinement.lower()
 230        
 231        # Text files for reading/saving center coordinates
 232        self.in_file = in_file
 233        self.out_file = out_file
 234        
 235        # Image processing parameters
 236        self.ellipse = ellipse
 237        self.mcorrect = mcorrect
 238        self.sobel = sobel
 239        self.masking = masking
 240        self.heq = heq
 241        self.icut = icut
 242        self.cmap = cmap
 243        self.csquare = csquare
 244        self.cintensity = cintensity
 245        
 246        # Process-Information parameters
 247        self.verbose = verbose
 248        self.print_sums = print_sums
 249        self.final_print = final_print
 250        self.live_plot = live_plot
 251        
 252        ## Initialize new attributes ------------------------------------------
 253        self.to_refine = []
 254        self.dText = []
 255        self.rText = []
 256        
 257        # The value of the following attribute can be adjusted
 258        self.marker_size = 100          
 259
 260        ## (1) Read input image -----------------------------------------------
 261        if self.verbose==3:
 262            print("[INFO] Loading image.")
 263        # The input image can be numpy.array (ndarray) or image file (path/str)
 264        if isinstance(input_image, np.ndarray):
 265            self.image = input_image
 266        else:
 267            self.image = ediff.io.read_image(self.input_image)
 268        
 269        ## (2) Correct ellipse ------------------------------------------------
 270        if self.ellipse:
 271            if self.verbose==3:
 272                print("[INFO] Correcting ellipse distortion... ", 
 273                      end="", flush=True)
 274            self.image = self.ellipse_distortion(self.image, show=True,
 275                                                 method=self.mcorrect)
 276            if self.verbose == 3:
 277                print(" [DONE]")
 278                
 279        ## (3) Read center coordinates ----------------------------------------
 280        # The center coordinates may have been determined in a previous run 
 281        # of the program and saved to a text file.
 282        # We can Load coordinates from an input file if specified, this is done 
 283        # by the following command. As the saved coordinates can be used INSTEAD 
 284        # of CenterDetermination we will read them here.
 285        if self.in_file is not None: 
 286            self.load_results()  
 287            if self.verbose==3:
 288                print("[INFO] Loading saved center coordinates.")
 289        
 290        ## (4) Run CenterDetermination ----------------------------------------
 291        if self.verbose == 3:
 292            print("[INFO] Detecting center...", end="", flush=True)
 293            
 294        #  (4a) Initialize/run CenterDetermination
 295        self.center1 = CenterDetermination(self,
 296                self.input_image,
 297                self.determination,
 298                self.heq,
 299                self.icut,
 300                self.cmap,
 301                self.csquare,
 302                self.cintensity,
 303                self.verbose,
 304                self.print_sums)
 305        
 306        if self.verbose == 3:
 307            print(" [DONE]")
 308    
 309        #  (4b) Find radius of a circle/diffraction ring, which is needed 
 310        #       for the next step = CenterRefimenement.
 311        if self.verbose==3:
 312            print("[INFO] Estimating radius of the diffraction pattern...",
 313                  end="", flush=True)
 314    
 315        if self.determination != "manual":
 316            self.center1.r = self.center1.get_radius(
 317                self.rtype,
 318                self.image, 
 319                self.center1.x, 
 320                self.center1.y, 
 321                disp=False)
 322        
 323        if self.verbose == 3:
 324            print(" [DONE]")
 325            
 326        ## (5) Initialize/run CenterRefinement --------------------------------
 327        if self.verbose==3:
 328            print("[INFO] Refining center coordinates...",
 329                  end="", flush=True)
 330                
 331        self.center2 = CenterRefinement(self,
 332            self.input_image, 
 333            self.refinement,
 334            self.in_file,
 335            self.out_file,
 336            self.heq, 
 337            self.icut,
 338            self.cmap,
 339            self.verbose,
 340            self.print_sums)
 341        
 342        if self.verbose == 3:
 343            print(" [DONE]")
 344            
 345            
 346        ## (6) Collect results ------------------------------------------------
 347        if self.verbose==3:
 348            print("[INFO] Collecting results.")
 349        self.x1 = self.center1.x
 350        self.y1 = self.center1.y
 351        
 352        # Center only detected and not refined
 353        if self.refinement is not None:
 354            self.x2 = self.center2.xx
 355            self.y2 = self.center2.yy
 356        else: 
 357            # Center detected and refined
 358            self.x2 = self.center1.x
 359            self.y2 = self.center1.y
 360            self.center2.xx = self.center1.x
 361            self.center2.yy = self.center1.y
 362            self.center2.rr = self.center1.r
 363        
 364        ## (7) Switch coordinates if necessary --------------------------------
 365        #      This step is important, as center detection/refinement methods
 366        #      have various coordinate system origins. The conversion is 
 367        #      necessary for some combinations of methods
 368        
 369        if (self.determination == "intensity"):
 370            self.x1, self.y1 = self.convert_coords(self.x1, self.y1)
 371            self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2)  
 372        
 373        if (self.determination =="hough" and self.refinement == "manual"):
 374            self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2)  
 375
 376        if (self.determination =="phase" and self.refinement == "manual"):
 377            self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2)  
 378            
 379        if (self.determination =="ccorr" and self.refinement == "manual"):
 380            self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2) 
 381                        
 382        if (self.determination == "curvefit" and self.refinement == "manual"):
 383            self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2) 
 384                            
 385        ## (8) Print the coordinates if required ------------------------------
 386        if self.final_print:
 387            self.dText=str(self.dText)
 388            self.rText=str(self.rText)
 389            
 390            print("----------------------------------------------------------")
 391            print(self.dText.format(float(self.x1),float(self.y1)))
 392            
 393            if self.refinement is not None:
 394                print(self.rText.format(float(self.x2),float(self.y2)))
 395                        
 396        ## (9) Save results to a .txt file if specified -----------------------
 397        
 398        if out_file is not None:
 399            self.save_results()
 400            if self.verbose==3:
 401                print("[INFO] Saving results.")
 402
 403    
 404    def output(self):
 405        """
 406        Return the final results of center determination and refinement. 
 407        
 408        Returns
 409        -------
 410        x1 : float
 411            x-coordinate of the center determined by the *determination* method.
 412            
 413        y1 : float
 414            y-coordinate of the center determined by the *determination* method.
 415        
 416        x2 : float
 417            x-coordinate of the center after *refinement*, or same as x1 if no 
 418            refinement was used.
 419        
 420        y2 : float
 421            y-coordinate of the center after *refinement*, or same as y1 if no 
 422            refinement was used.
 423
 424            
 425        Notes
 426        -----
 427        - The function always returns four values: (x1, y1, x2, y2).
 428        - If no refinement method was used (`refinement=None`), then (x2, y2) 
 429          will be equal to (x1, y1).
 430        - All values are rounded to one decimal place before returning.
 431        - Coordinates are internally converted to float to ensure consistency 
 432          in output.
 433        """
 434        
 435        # (1) refinement=None -------------------------------------------------
 436        if self.center2.ret == 1:
 437            # Convert to float
 438            if type(self.x1) != float:
 439                self.x1, self.y1, self.x2, self.y2 = \
 440                    [float(value) for value in (self.x1, self.y1, 
 441                                                self.x2, self.y2)]
 442                    
 443        # (2) refinement!=None ------------------------------------------------
 444        else:
 445            # Convert to float
 446            if type(self.x1) != float:
 447                self.x1, self.y1 = \
 448                    [float(value) for value in (self.x1,self.y1)]
 449            # Define x2,y2 = x1,y1
 450            self.x2 = self.x1
 451            self.y2 = self.y1
 452            
 453        # (3) Return (rounded) values of center coordinates -------------------
 454        return (np.round(self.x1,1), np.round(self.y1,1), 
 455                np.round(self.x2,1), np.round(self.y2,1))  
 456
 457    
 458    def save_results(self):
 459        '''
 460        Save the determined and refined center coordinates to a file.
 461    
 462        This method writes the coordinates (x1, y1) from the *determination*
 463        step and (x2, y2) from the *refinement* step to a file specified by the 
 464        `out_file` attribute.
 465    
 466        - If the file already exists, the results are appended to the end.
 467        - If the file does not exist, it is created and the results are written.
 468        - Coordinates are formatted to four decimal places for clarity.
 469        
 470        
 471        Parameters
 472        ----------
 473        None
 474        
 475        Returns
 476        -------
 477        None
 478        
 479        Notes
 480        -----
 481        - If `self.out_file` is None, the method does nothing.
 482        - The results are written in the format:
 483            x1: <value>, y1: <value>
 484            x2: <value>, y2: <value>
 485        - This method does not raise an error if the path is invalid;
 486          ensure `out_file` is a valid writable path.
 487        '''
 488        
 489        if self.out_file is not None:
 490            # Check if the specified file exists
 491            if os.path.isfile(self.out_file):
 492                # Append results to in_file
 493                with open(self.out_file, 'a') as f:  # Open in append mode
 494                    f.write(f"x1: {self.x1:.4f}, y1: {self.y1:.4f}\n")
 495                    f.write(f"x2: {self.x2:.4f}, y2: {self.y2:.4f}\n")
 496            else:
 497                # If the file does not exist, create it and write results
 498                with open(self.out_file, 'w') as f:  # Open in write mode
 499                    f.write(f"x1: {self.x1:.4f}, y1: {self.y1:.4f}\n")
 500                    f.write(f"x2: {self.x2:.4f}, y2: {self.y2:.4f}\n")
 501
 502
 503    def load_results(self, path=None):
 504        """
 505        Load center coordinates from a results file.
 506    
 507        This method reads a text file (defaulting to `self.in_file` or
 508        a provided `path`) containing previously saved center coordinates.
 509        It extracts coordinate pairs (x1, y1) from the determination step and
 510        (x2, y2) from the refinement step. All sets of values are stored
 511        internally, with the most recent values assigned to instance variables 
 512        `self.x1`, `self.y1`, `self.x2`, and `self.y2`.
 513    
 514        Parameters
 515        ----------
 516        path : str, optional
 517            Path to the results file. 
 518            If not provided, the method uses `self.in_file`.
 519    
 520        Returns
 521        -------
 522        tuple or None
 523            If `path` is provided and successfully loaded:
 524                (x1_values, y1_values) : Lists of all loaded x1 and y1 values.
 525            If loading fails:
 526                None
 527    
 528        Notes
 529        -----
 530        - The file is expected to contain lines in the following format:
 531            x1: <value>, y1: <value>
 532            x2: <value>, y2: <value>
 533        - Multiple coordinate entries can be loaded; the last set is stored in
 534          the instance variables for easy access.
 535        - If the file doesn't exist or is unreadable, a warning is printed and
 536          the function returns None.
 537        """      
 538        
 539        if path is not None:
 540            self.in_file = path
 541            
 542        if self.in_file is not None and os.path.isfile(self.in_file):
 543            with open(self.in_file, 'r') as f:
 544                lines = f.readlines()
 545                
 546                # Initialize lists to hold multiple values
 547                x1_values = []
 548                y1_values = []
 549                x2_values = []
 550                y2_values = []
 551    
 552                for line in lines:
 553                    # Strip and split each line to get the coordinates
 554                    parts = line.strip().split(',')
 555                    if len(parts) == 2:
 556                        # Extract x1 and y1 or x2 and y2 based on line content
 557                        if 'x1' in parts[0]:
 558                            x1 = float(parts[0].split(':')[1].strip())
 559                            y1 = float(parts[1].split(':')[1].strip())
 560                            x1_values.append(x1)
 561                            y1_values.append(y1)
 562                        elif 'x2' in parts[0]:
 563                            x2 = float(parts[0].split(':')[1].strip())
 564                            y2 = float(parts[1].split(':')[1].strip())
 565                            x2_values.append(x2)
 566                            y2_values.append(y2)
 567    
 568                # Store the last set of values as instance variables 
 569                self.x1 = x1_values
 570                self.y1 = y1_values
 571                self.x2 = x2_values
 572                self.y2 = y2_values
 573    
 574                # Store the last loaded values:
 575                if x1_values and y1_values and x2_values and y2_values:
 576                    self.x1 = x1_values[-1]
 577                    self.y1 = y1_values[-1]
 578                    self.x2 = x2_values[-1]
 579                    self.y2 = y2_values[-1]
 580                    
 581                if path is not None:
 582                    return x1_values, y1_values
 583        else:
 584            print("Error reading text file with center coordinates!")
 585            return
 586
 587
 588    def get_circle_pixels(self, image, cx, cy, r, num_points=360):
 589        """
 590        Extract pixel values along a circular path in the image.
 591    
 592        Parameters
 593        ----------
 594        image : np.ndarray
 595            2D grayscale image from which pixel values are extracted.
 596            
 597        cx : float
 598            X-coordinate (row) of the circle center.
 599        
 600        cy : float
 601            Y-coordinate (column) of the circle center.
 602        
 603        r : float
 604            Radius of the circle.
 605        
 606        num_points : int, optional
 607            Number of points to sample along the circular path. Default is 360.
 608    
 609        Returns
 610        -------
 611        pixels : np.ndarray
 612            1D array of pixel intensity values sampled along the circular path.
 613        """
 614        points = np.linspace(0, 2 * np.pi, num_points)
 615        
 616        # Generate coordinates for the circle
 617        x = cx + r * np.cos(points)
 618        y = cy + r * np.sin(points)
 619        
 620        # Use map_coordinates for accurate sub-pixel interpolation
 621        coords = np.vstack((y, x))
 622        
 623        # 'order=1' is linear interpolation
 624        pixels = map_coordinates(image, 
 625                                 coords, 
 626                                 order=1, 
 627                                 mode='constant', 
 628                                 cval=0.0)
 629        
 630        # Return pixels
 631        return pixels
 632     
 633     
 634    def intensity_sum(self, im, cx, cy, r):
 635        """
 636        Compute the sum of pixel intensities along a circular path.
 637    
 638        This function extracts pixel values along a circle defined by the 
 639        given center coordinates (cx, cy) and radius r, then returns 
 640        the sum of these intensities.
 641    
 642        Parameters
 643        ----------
 644        im : np.ndarray
 645            2D grayscale image from which the intensities are extracted.
 646        
 647        cx : float
 648            X-coordinate (row) of the circle center.
 649        
 650        cy : float
 651            Y-coordinate (column) of the circle center.
 652        
 653        r : float
 654            Radius of the circle.
 655    
 656        Returns
 657        -------
 658        float
 659            Sum of pixel intensities along the circular path.
 660        """
 661        # Get pixel intensities
 662        pixels = self.get_circle_pixels(im, cx, cy, r)
 663        
 664        # Sum pixel intensities
 665        return np.sum(pixels)
 666    
 667    
 668    def intensity_variance(self, image, px, py, pr):
 669        ''' 
 670        Variance of intensity values of pixels of a diffraction pattern.
 671
 672        Parameters
 673        ----------
 674        image : array of uint8
 675            image from which the diffraction pattern has been detected.
 676        
 677        px : float64
 678            x-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
 679        
 680        py : float64
 681            y-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
 682        
 683        pr : float64
 684            radius of the diffraction pattern.
 685
 686        Returns
 687        -------
 688        s : float64
 689            intensity variance
 690
 691        '''
 692        # Extract pixels on the circle border
 693        pxc, pyc = self.get_circle_pixels(px, py, pr)
 694        pxc = np.array(pxc, dtype=int)
 695        pyc = np.array(pyc, dtype=int)
 696        
 697        # Calculate sum using the filtered values
 698        s = np.var(image[pxc, pyc])
 699        return s
 700    
 701    
 702    def convert_coords(self, x, y):
 703        """
 704        Convert coordinates between numpy and matplotlib systems.
 705
 706        Parameters
 707        ----------
 708        x : int or float
 709            The x-coordinate in the numpy (column index) format.
 710        
 711        y : int or float
 712            The y-coordinate in the numpy (row index) format.
 713
 714        Returns
 715        -------
 716        tuple of (int or float, int or float)
 717            The converted coordinates in matplotlib format, where:
 718            - First element corresponds to y (new x in matplotlib).
 719            - Second element corresponds to x (new y in matplotlib).
 720        """
 721        return y, x
 722
 723
 724    def visualize_results(self, csquare=None, out_file=None, out_dpi=200):
 725        '''
 726        Visualize diffractogram and its center after
 727        center determination + refinement.
 728    
 729        Parameters
 730        ----------
 731        csquare : int, optional, default is None
 732            If csquare argument is given,
 733            only the central square of the diffractogram will be plotted;
 734            the size of the central square will be equal to csquare argument.
 735        
 736        out_file : str, optional, default is None
 737            If out_file is given,
 738            save the final plot to image named *out_file*.
 739        
 740        out_dpi : int, optional, default is 200
 741            DPI of the output image file;
 742            this parameter is relevant only if out_file is given.
 743    
 744        Returns
 745        -------
 746        None
 747            The output is the image of the diffractogram
 748            showing also the central coordinates and refinement ring.
 749        '''
 750        
 751        # (0) Collect center coordinates and radii ----------------------------
 752        x1, y1 = (self.x1, self.y1)
 753        r1 = self.center1.r
 754
 755        x2, y2 = (self.x2, self.y2)
 756        r2 = self.center2.rr
 757
 758        # (1) Prepare the image of the diffractogram --------------------------
 759        image = np.copy(self.to_refine)
 760        if self.icut is not None:
 761            im = np.where(image > self.icut, self.icut, image)
 762        else:
 763            im = np.copy(image)
 764            
 765        # (2) Calculate intensity sum or intensity variance -------------------
 766        if self.refinement == "var":
 767            dvar = self.intensity_variance(image, x1, y1, r1)
 768            rvar = self.intensity_variance(image, x2, y2, r2)
 769            labeld = f'd-center: [{x1:.1f}, {y1:.1f}]\nint-var: {dvar:.1f}'
 770            labelr = f'r-center: [{x2:.1f}, {y2:.1f}]\nint-var: {rvar:.1f}'
 771        else:
 772            dsum = self.intensity_sum(image, x1, y1, r1)
 773            rsum = self.intensity_sum(image, x2, y2, r2)
 774            labeld = f'd-center: [{x1:.1f}, {y1:.1f}]\nint-sum: {dsum:.1f}'
 775            labelr = f'r-center: [{x2:.1f}, {y2:.1f}]\nint-sum: {rsum:.1f}'
 776            
 777        # (3) Calculate xy-limits if we want to see only the central square ---
 778        if csquare is not None:
 779            xmin, xmax = (0, image.shape[0])
 780            ymin, ymax = (0, image.shape[1])
 781            edge = (xmax - csquare) // 2
 782            xmin += edge
 783            xmax -= edge
 784            ymin += edge
 785            ymax -= edge
 786    
 787        # (4) Final plot: show the diffractogram + refinement results ---------
 788        fig, ax = plt.subplots(layout='constrained')
 789        ax.imshow(im, cmap=self.cmap)
 790    
 791        ax.set_title(f'Center :: {self.determination}/{self.refinement}')
 792    
 793        ax.scatter(x1, y1, 
 794                   label=labeld, 
 795                   color='gold', 
 796                   marker='x', 
 797                   s=60, lw=1)
 798        c0 = plt.Circle((x1, y1), r1, 
 799                        color='gold', 
 800                        fill=False, 
 801                        label='detected center', 
 802                        lw=1)
 803        ax.add_patch(c0)
 804    
 805        ax.scatter(x2, y2,
 806                   label=labelr, 
 807                   color='red', 
 808                   marker='x', lw=1, s=60)
 809        c1 = plt.Circle((x2, y2), r2, 
 810                        color='red', 
 811                        fill=False, 
 812                        label='refined center', 
 813                        lw=1)
 814        ax.add_patch(c1)
 815    
 816        ax.legend(loc='upper left', frameon=False, 
 817                  handler_map={Circle: HandlerCircle()}, 
 818                  bbox_to_anchor=(.98, 1.01), 
 819                  bbox_transform=ax.transAxes)
 820    
 821        # Remove axes (= tick and ticklabels) around the diffractogram
 822        ax.axis('off')
 823        
 824        # Plot only the central square region if requested
 825        if csquare is not None:
 826            ax.set_xlim(xmin, xmax)
 827            ax.set_ylim(ymin, ymax)
 828        
 829        # Save the result to output file if requested
 830        if out_file is not None:
 831            fig.savefig(out_file, dpi=out_dpi)
 832        
 833        # Show the plot on screen
 834        plt.show(block=False)
 835
 836
 837    def ellipse_distortion(self, img, show=True, method=None):
 838        """
 839        Corrects elliptical distortion in an image by transforming 4 distorted 
 840        points (which should ideally lie on a circle) to lie on a true circle.
 841    
 842        Parameters
 843        ----------
 844        img : np.ndarray
 845            Input image (2D numpy array) containing an elliptical diffraction 
 846            pattern.
 847        
 848        show : bool, optional
 849            If True, displays the original and corrected images. 
 850            Default is True.
 851        
 852        method : str, optional
 853            Point selection method: 'manual' or 'auto'.
 854            - 'manual': User clicks four points on the image.
 855            - 'auto': Automatically detects the four brightest Bragg spots 
 856              (not yet implemented).
 857    
 858        Returns
 859        -------
 860        corrected : np.ndarray
 861            The distortion-corrected image.
 862        """
 863            
 864        # Helper function
 865        def refine_to_local_max(img, pt, window=9):
 866            """
 867            Refine a point to the local maximum intensity within a neighborhood.
 868        
 869            This function searches for the brightest (maximum intensity) pixel
 870            within a square window centered around a given point. It is typi-
 871            cally used to improve the accuracy of an estimated center by snap-
 872            ping it to the nearest local maximum.
 873        
 874            Parameters
 875            ----------
 876            img : ndarray
 877                2D array (grayscale) in which the local maximum is to be found.
 878                
 879            pt : array-like of float
 880                Initial (x, y) point coordinates around which the local maximum 
 881                is searched.
 882                
 883            window : int, optional
 884                Size of the square window for the local search (default is 9).
 885                The actual window will be `window x window` pixels, 
 886                centered at `pt`.
 887        
 888            Returns
 889            -------
 890            refined_pt : ndarray of float
 891                Refined point coordinates [x, y] corresponding to the brightest 
 892                pixel in the local window.
 893        
 894            Notes
 895            -----
 896            - If the window overlaps the image boundaries, it is clipped 
 897              appropriately.
 898            - If the window is completely outside the image, the original point 
 899              is returned.
 900            - Assumption : `img` uses (row, column) = (y, x) indexing.
 901            """
 902            x, y = int(round(pt[0])), int(round(pt[1]))
 903            r = window // 2
 904            x_min, x_max = max(0, x - r), min(img.shape[1], x + r + 1)
 905            y_min, y_max = max(0, y - r), min(img.shape[0], y + r + 1)
 906    
 907            local = img[y_min:y_max, x_min:x_max]
 908            if local.size == 0:
 909                return np.array([x, y], dtype=np.float32)
 910    
 911            dy, dx = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(local), local.shape)
 912            refined_x = x_min + dx
 913            refined_y = y_min + dy
 914            return np.array([refined_x, refined_y], dtype=np.float32)
 915        
 916        # Elliptical correction workflow --------------------------------------
 917        h, w = img.shape
 918    
 919        if method != "manual":
 920            print("Only user-assisted ('manual') correction available.")
 921            method = "manual"
 922    
 923        if method == 'manual':
 924            # Manual point selection
 925            plt.imshow(img, cmap=self.cmap)
 926            plt.title("Click 4 distorted points (in circular order)")
 927            raw_pts = np.array(plt.ginput(4, timeout=-1), dtype=np.float32)
 928            plt.close()
 929    
 930            # Refine each point to local max
 931            distorted_pts = np.array([
 932                refine_to_local_max(img, pt, window=9) for pt in raw_pts
 933            ], dtype=np.float32)
 934    
 935        # Compute center and average radius
 936        center = np.mean(distorted_pts, axis=0)
 937        radii = np.linalg.norm(distorted_pts - center, axis=1)
 938        avg_radius = np.mean(radii)
 939    
 940        # Target points evenly on circle
 941        angles = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, 5)[:-1]
 942        circle_pts = np.stack([
 943            center[0] + avg_radius * np.cos(angles),
 944            center[1] + avg_radius * np.sin(angles)
 945        ], axis=1).astype(np.float32)
 946    
 947        # Perspective transform
 948        H = cv2.getPerspectiveTransform(distorted_pts, circle_pts)
 949        
 950        # Make output square by padding the image to max_dim x max_dim
 951        max_dim = max(h, w)
 952        
 953        # Compute offset to center the original image content in the square 
 954        x_offset = (max_dim - w) // 2
 955        y_offset = (max_dim - h) // 2
 956        
 957        # Create a translation matrix to shift image content to center
 958        T = np.array([
 959            [1, 0, x_offset],
 960            [0, 1, y_offset],
 961            [0, 0, 1]
 962        ], dtype=np.float32)
 963        
 964        # Combine the original homography with the translation
 965        H_total = T @ H  # Matrix multiplication
 966        
 967        # Apply the combined transformation
 968        corrected = cv2.warpPerspective(
 969            img, H_total, (max_dim, max_dim),
 970            borderMode=cv2.BORDER_CONSTANT,
 971            borderValue=0
 972        )
 973
 974        # Show results
 975        if show:
 976            plt.figure(figsize=(12, 5))
 977            plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
 978            plt.title("Original with refined points")
 979            plt.imshow(img, cmap=self.cmap)
 980            plt.scatter(*distorted_pts.T, color='cyan', s=40)
 981    
 982            plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)
 983            plt.title("Corrected image")
 984            plt.imshow(corrected, cmap=self.cmap)
 985            plt.show()
 986    
 987        return corrected
 988
 989
 990class CenterDetermination:
 991    '''
 992    CenterDetermination object - initial detection of a diffractogram center.
 993
 994    This class is responsible for identifying the center coordinates of 
 995    a 2D diffraction pattern image using various detection methods specified 
 996    by the user. It initializes with the input image and other parameters
 997    that influence the center detection process.
 998
 999    Parameters
1000    ----------
1001    parent : CenterLocator
1002        Reference to the parent CenterLocator object, allowing access 
1003        to shared attributes and methods.
1004        
1005    input_image : str, path, or numpy.array
1006        The input image representing a 2D diffraction pattern, provided as 
1007        a file path or a NumPy array.
1008        
1009    determination : str or None, optional, default=None
1010        Method used for the initial center determination.
1011        Options include:
1012        - 'manual'   : Manual selection of 3 points on a diffraction ring.
1013        - 'hough'    : Automatic detection using Hough transform.
1014        - 'intensity': Automatic detection based on the intensity center 
1015                       of the central region.
1016        - 'phase'    : Automatic detection using phase correlation to find 
1017                       the symmetry center.
1018        - 'ccorr'    : Automatic detection using cross-correlation to find 
1019                       the symmetry center.
1020        - 'curvefit' : Automatic detecting using pseudo-Voigt profile fitting 
1021        
1022    in_file : str or None, optional, default=None
1023        Path to the file from which previously saved coordinates will be loaded.
1024    
1025    out_file : str or None, optional, default=None
1026        Path to the file where the determined coordinates will be saved.
1027        
1028    sobel : bool, optional, default=False
1029        If True, apply Sobel filter to the image before processing.
1030        
1031    heq : bool or None, optional, default=False
1032        If True, apply histogram equalization internally (display unchanged).
1033    
1034    icut : float or None, optional, default=None
1035        Cut-off intensity level for processing the image.
1036        
1037    cmap : str, optional, default='gray'
1038        Matplotlib colormap name used for displaying the image.
1039        
1040    csquare : int, optional, defaul=50
1041        Size (in pixels) of the central square used for initial center search.
1042        
1043    cintensity : float, optional, default=0.8
1044        Threshold intensity for finding the intensity center. Pixels with a 
1045        (relative) intensity lower than cintensity are ignored.
1046        
1047    verbose : bool, optional, default=False
1048        If True, print informational verbose during the detection process.
1049        
1050    print_sums : bool, optional, default=False
1051        If True, print intensity sums after each adjustment (in manual modes).
1052        
1053    
1054
1055    Returns
1056    -------
1057    None
1058
1059    Notes
1060    -----
1061    - The class preprocesses the input image and then applies the specified 
1062      center detection method.
1063    - The detected center coordinates are stored in instance variables
1064      `x`, `y`, and `r`, representing the center's x-coordinate, 
1065      y-coordinate, and radius, respectively.
1066      
1067    '''
1068    
1069    def __init__(self, parent,
1070                 input_image,
1071                 determination = None, 
1072                 in_file = None,
1073                 out_file = None,
1074                 heq = False, 
1075                 icut = None,
1076                 cmap = 'gray',
1077                 csquare=50,
1078                 cintensity=0.8,
1079                 verbose = 0,
1080                 print_sums = False):
1081
1082        
1083        ######################################################################
1084        # PRIVATE FUNCTION: Initialize CenterLocator object.
1085        # The parameters are described above in class definition.
1086        ######################################################################
1087        
1088        ## (0) Initialize input attributes -----------------------------------
1089        self.parent = parent
1090        
1091        ## (1) Initialize new attributes -------------------------------------
1092        self.step=0.5 
1093        
1094        ## (2) Run functions -------------------------------------------------
1095        #  (2a) Preprocess data
1096        self.preprocess(preInit=1)
1097        
1098        #  (2b) Center detection methods
1099        if determination.lower() == "manual":
1100            self.x, self.y, self.r = self.detection_3points()
1101            
1102        elif determination.lower() == "hough":
1103            self.x, self.y, self.r = self.detection_Hough(
1104                sobel=self.parent.sobel,
1105                live_plot=self.parent.live_plot)
1106            
1107        elif determination.lower() == "intensity":
1108            self.x, self.y, self.r = self.detection_intensity(
1109                self.parent.csquare, 
1110                self.parent.cintensity,
1111                sobel=self.parent.sobel)
1112            
1113        elif determination.lower() == "phase":
1114            self.y, self.x, self.r = self.detection_phase(
1115                sobel=self.parent.sobel,
1116                masking=self.parent.masking)
1117         
1118        elif determination.lower() == "ccorr":
1119            self.y, self.x, self.r = self.detection_crosscorr(
1120                sobel=self.parent.sobel,
1121                disp=False)
1122        
1123        elif determination.lower() == "curvefit":
1124            self.x, self.y, self.r = self.detection_curvefit()
1125                
1126        else: 
1127            print("Selected determination method does not exist.")
1128            sys.exit()
1129
1130
1131    def preprocess(self, preInit=0, preHough=0, preManual=0,
1132                   preVar=0, preSum=0, preInt=0):  
1133        """
1134        Preprocess the input image based on the selected automatic detection 
1135        and refinement methods.
1136    
1137        Parameters
1138        ----------
1139        preInit : bool, optional, default=0
1140            Preprocess the original image using initialization methods such as
1141            histogram equalization (heq) or contrast clipping (icut). This
1142            is used to enhance the input image prior to any detection or
1143            correction.
1144        
1145        preHough : bool, optional, default=0
1146            Perform preprocessing required for Hough transform-based automatic 
1147            detection. This includes edge detection and handling beamstoppers. 
1148    
1149        preManual, preVar, preSum, preInt : bool, optional, default=0
1150            Placeholder flags for future preprocessing needs for manual 
1151            detection and different refinement methods (variance, sum, 
1152            intensity-based). Currently unused.
1153    
1154        Returns
1155        -------
1156        edges : np.ndarray of bool, optional
1157            Edge map obtained using the Canny edge detector, required for Hough
1158            transform. Only returned if `preHough` is True.
1159    
1160        Notes
1161        -----
1162        This function performs different preprocessing steps depending on the
1163        detection/refinement strategy selected. It is modular and supports
1164        optional display of intermediate results if `self.parent.verbose` is True.
1165        """
1166    
1167        # Flags
1168        control_print = 1
1169        
1170        # Load original image
1171        if len(self.parent.image.shape)!=2:
1172            self.parent.image = np.mean(self.parent.image,axis=2)
1173            
1174        image = np.copy(self.parent.image)
1175        
1176        ### After initialization: perform an image enhancement if specified
1177        if preInit == 1:
1178            # Enhance diffraction pattern to make it more visible
1179            if self.parent.heq == 1:
1180                if self.parent.verbose==2:
1181                    print("Histogram equalized.")
1182                image = sk.exposure.equalize_adapthist(image)
1183
1184            self.parent.to_refine = image
1185            return
1186        
1187        ### Hough transform: perform pre-processing necessary for the detection
1188        if preHough == 1:           
1189            if self.parent.heq == 0:
1190                csq = self.central_square(self.parent.to_refine, csquare=80)   
1191                
1192                # Beam stopper present in image
1193                if np.median(csq)<100 and np.median(csq) > 0:
1194                    if self.parent.verbose==2:
1195                        print('Beamstopper removed.')
1196                    max_indices=np.where(self.parent.to_refine>np.median(csq))
1197        
1198                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
1199                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
1200        
1201                    self.parent.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0    
1202                    
1203                    max_indices = \
1204                        np.where(self.parent.to_refine < 0.8*np.median(csq))
1205                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
1206                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
1207        
1208                    self.parent.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0   
1209                    
1210                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1211                    edges = sk.feature.canny(self.parent.to_refine, 
1212                            sigma=0.2, 
1213                            low_threshold=2.5*np.median(self.parent.to_refine), 
1214                            high_threshold=3*np.median(self.parent.to_refine))
1215                    
1216                    # Dilate the edges to connect them
1217                    selem = sk.morphology.disk(5)
1218                    dilated_edges = sk.morphology.dilation(edges, selem)
1219                    
1220                    # Erode the dilated edges
1221                    # to reduce thickness and smooth the contour
1222                    connected_edges=sk.morphology.erosion(dilated_edges,selem)
1223
1224                    if control_print == 1:
1225                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
1226                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.parent.image, origin="upper")
1227                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
1228                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.parent.to_refine, origin="upper")
1229                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
1230                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
1231                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
1232                        ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges, origin="upper")
1233                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
1234                        plt.tight_layout()
1235                        plt.show(block=False)
1236                        
1237                # No beam stopper in image
1238                else:
1239                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1240                    print('No beamstopper.')
1241                    edges = sk.feature.canny(self.to_refine, 
1242                                             sigma=0.2, 
1243                                             low_threshold=80, 
1244                                             high_threshold=100)
1245                    
1246                    # Dilate the edges to connect them
1247                    selem = sk.morphology.disk(10)
1248                    dilated_edges = sk.morphology.dilation(edges, selem)
1249                    
1250                    # Erode the dilated edges
1251                    # to reduce thickness and smooth the contour
1252                    connected_edges=sk.morphology.erosion(dilated_edges,selem)
1253                    connected_edges = sk.morphology.remove_small_objects(
1254                        connected_edges, 
1255                        min_size=100)
1256                    
1257                    if control_print == 1:
1258                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
1259                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
1260                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
1261                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
1262                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
1263                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper",)
1264                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
1265                        ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges,origin="upper")
1266                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
1267                        plt.tight_layout()
1268                        plt.show(block=False)
1269                
1270            elif self.heq == 1: 
1271                # Central square extraction
1272                csq = self.central_square(self.to_refine, csquare=80)   
1273
1274                # Beam stopper present in image
1275                if 0.4 <= np.median(csq) <= 0.6:
1276                    
1277                    max_indices = \
1278                        np.where(self.to_refine > 2*np.median(self.to_refine))
1279    
1280                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
1281                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
1282    
1283                    self.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0 
1284                                                     
1285                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1286                    edges = sk.feature.canny(
1287                        self.to_refine, 
1288                        sigma=0.2, 
1289                        low_threshold=1.5*np.median(self.to_refine), 
1290                        high_threshold=3*np.median(self.to_refine))
1291
1292                    
1293                    if control_print == 1:
1294                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
1295                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
1296                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
1297                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
1298                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
1299                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
1300                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
1301                      #  ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges)
1302                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
1303                        plt.tight_layout()
1304                        plt.show(block=False)
1305                    
1306                # No beam stopper in image
1307                else:
1308                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1309                    edges = sk.feature.canny(
1310                        self.to_refine, 
1311                        sigma=0.2, 
1312                        low_threshold=2.5*np.median(self.to_refine), 
1313                        high_threshold=3*np.median(self.to_refine))
1314
1315                    
1316                    if control_print == 1:
1317                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
1318                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
1319                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
1320                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
1321                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
1322                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
1323                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
1324                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
1325                        plt.tight_layout()
1326                        plt.show(block=False)
1327            
1328            return edges
1329        
1330
1331    def sobel_filt(self, image, disp=True):   
1332        """
1333        The Sobel filter, which is a simple 33 kernel convolved with the image 
1334        which approximates the gradient of intensity in a certain direction. 
1335        Since the Sobel filter is a simple matrix, it can be applied across 
1336        datasets without concern for effects caused by changing user defined 
1337        thresholds, and is much faster and impartial than an iterative method
1338
1339        Parameters
1340        ----------
1341        image : TYPE
1342            DESCRIPTION.
1343        disp : TYPE, optional
1344            DESCRIPTION. The default is False.
1345
1346        Returns
1347        -------
1348        sobel_magnitude : TYPE
1349            DESCRIPTION.
1350
1351        """
1352        # Apply Sobel filter
1353        sobel_x = cv2.Sobel(image, 
1354                            cv2.CV_64F, 
1355                            1, 0, 
1356                            ksize=3)  # Horizontal edges
1357        sobel_y = cv2.Sobel(image, 
1358                            cv2.CV_64F, 
1359                            0, 1,
1360                            ksize=3)  # Vertical edges
1361        
1362        # # Take absolute values to remove negatives
1363        # sobel_x = np.abs(sobel_x)
1364        # sobel_y = np.abs(sobel_y)
1365
1366        
1367        # Compute gradient magnitude
1368        sobel_magnitude = np.sqrt(sobel_x**2 + sobel_y**2)
1369        
1370        # Normalize
1371        sobel_magnitude = \
1372            np.uint8(255 * sobel_magnitude / np.max(sobel_magnitude))  
1373        
1374        if disp:
1375            # Display results
1376            plt.figure(figsize=(12, 4))
1377            plt.subplot(1, 3, 1), 
1378            plt.imshow(sobel_x, cmap='gray'), 
1379            plt.title('Sobel X')
1380            plt.subplot(1, 3, 2),
1381            plt.imshow(sobel_y, cmap='gray'),
1382            plt.title('Sobel Y')
1383            plt.subplot(1, 3, 3), 
1384            plt.imshow(sobel_magnitude, cmap='gray'), 
1385            plt.title('Gradient Magnitude')
1386            plt.show()
1387        
1388        return sobel_magnitude
1389    
1390    
1391    def detection_phase(self, normalize_bg=True, sobel=False, 
1392                        disp=False, masking=True):
1393        """
1394        Detects the center of symmetry in a diffraction image using a 
1395        combination of weighted intensity averaging and phase cross-correlation.
1396    
1397        This method performs the following steps:
1398            1. Estimates an initial center using a weighted average of pixel 
1399               intensities.
1400            2. Crops the image to focus on its central region.
1401            3. Optionally normalizes the background to mitigate experimental 
1402               artifacts.
1403            4. Computes a refined center via inversion symmetry and phase 
1404               cross-correlation.
1405            5. Returns the final refined center coordinates.
1406    
1407        Parameters
1408        ----------
1409        normalize_bg : bool, optional, default=True
1410            If True, normalize background intensity to reduce artifacts.
1411            
1412        sobel : bool, optional, default=False
1413            If True, applies Sobel filtering (currently unused if not implemented)
1414            
1415        disp : bool, optional, default=False
1416            If True, displays intermediate processing results. 
1417            
1418        masking : bool, optional, default=True
1419            If True, applies masking to exclude unwanted regions from analysis
1420    
1421        Returns
1422        -------
1423        r_final : float
1424            Estimated row-coordinate of the image center after refinement.
1425            
1426        c_final : float
1427            Estimated column-coordinate of the image center after refinement.
1428            
1429        None : NoneType
1430            Placeholder for future functionality (e.g., radius estimation).
1431        """
1432        # (1) Get image  ------------------------------------------------------
1433        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1434        
1435        # if Sobel==True, perform Sobel filtration
1436        # https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ultramic.2016.12.021
1437        if sobel:
1438            image = self.sobel_filt(image,disp)
1439        
1440        
1441        # shift the pixel values (smallest value is zero -> non-negative image)
1442        image -= image.min()
1443
1444        # (2) Prepare mask and compute weighted center ------------------------
1445        if masking:
1446            mask = self.auto_masking(image) 
1447            # print("masked")
1448        else: mask = np.ones_like(image, dtype=bool) # binary mask
1449        
1450        weights = image                        # 
1451        
1452        rr, cc = np.indices(image.shape)       # matrices of row/col indices
1453
1454        # Weighted center of mass (brighter pixels contribute more)
1455        # This gives an initial estimate of the center (r_, c_).
1456        r_ = int(np.average(rr.flatten(), weights=weights.flatten()))
1457        c_ = int(np.average(cc.flatten(), weights=weights.flatten()))
1458
1459        # (3) Crop the image around the estimated center ----------------------
1460        # Some diffraction patterns are not centered, and so there's a lot of 
1461        # image area that cannot be used for registration.
1462        # Radial inversion becomes simple inversion of dimensions
1463        side_length = \
1464            floor(min([r_,abs(r_-image.shape[0]),c_,abs(c_-image.shape[1])]))
1465        rs = slice(r_ - side_length, r_ + side_length)
1466        cs = slice(c_ - side_length, c_ + side_length)
1467        image = image[rs, cs]
1468        mask = mask[rs, cs]
1469    
1470        # (4) Normalize background intensity (optional) -----------------------
1471        # This step removes intensity variations due to experimental artifacts, 
1472        # such as uneven illumination.
1473        if normalize_bg:
1474            with warnings.catch_warnings():
1475                warnings.simplefilter("ignore", category=RuntimeWarning)
1476                image = image.astype(np.float64)  # float64 before division
1477                image /= gaussian_filter(
1478                    input=image, sigma=min(image.shape) / 25, truncate=2)
1479        
1480        # Replace NaN values with 0s
1481        image = np.nan_to_num(image, copy=False)
1482
1483
1484        # (5) Compute inversion symmetry using Fourier methods ----------------
1485        # an inverted copy of the image (im_i) and mask (mask_i), 
1486        # flipping both horizontally and vertically ::-1
1487        im_i = image[::-1, ::-1]
1488        mask_i = mask[::-1, ::-1]
1489
1490        # downsampling to speed up processing (for too large images)
1491        downsampling = 1
1492        if min(image.shape) > 1024:
1493            downsampling = 2
1494    
1495        # phase cross-correlation finds the best alignment between the image
1496        # and its inverted copy
1497        # the shift tells us how much the center is offset from perfect 
1498        # inversion symmetry.
1499        shift, *_ = self.calc_fft(phase_cross_correlation)(
1500            reference_image=image[::downsampling, ::downsampling],
1501            moving_image=im_i[::downsampling, ::downsampling],
1502            reference_mask=mask[::downsampling, ::downsampling],
1503            moving_mask=mask_i[::downsampling, ::downsampling],
1504        )
1505        
1506        # The computed shift is rescaled to match the original image resolution.
1507        correction = shift * downsampling
1508
1509
1510        # (6) User information (if required) ----------------------------------
1511        if (self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print):
1512            self.parent.dText = \
1513                "Center Determination (PhaseCorrCenter): ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1514        
1515        # Ensure correction is a tuple or list before extracting elements
1516        correction_r, correction_c = correction \
1517            if isinstance(correction, (list, tuple, np.ndarray)) \
1518                else (correction, correction)
1519        
1520        r_final = r_ + correction_r / 2
1521        c_final = c_ + correction_c / 2
1522                
1523        return float(r_final), float(c_final), None
1524    
1525
1526    def detection_crosscorr(self, normalize_bg=True, sobel=False, disp=False):
1527        """
1528        Detects the center of symmetry in a diffraction image using a 
1529        combination of weighted intensity averaging and cross-correlation.
1530    
1531        This method performs the following steps:
1532            1. Estimates an initial center using the weighted average of pixel
1533               intensities.
1534            2. Crops the image to focus on its central region.
1535            3. Optionally normalizes the background to reduce experimental
1536               artifacts.
1537            4. Computes a refined center by analyzing inversion symmetry 
1538               using cross-correlation.
1539            5. Returns the final corrected center coordinates.
1540    
1541        Parameters
1542        ----------
1543        normalize_bg : bool, optional, default=True
1544            If True, normalizes the background intensity to reduce illumination 
1545            artifacts. 
1546            
1547        sobel : bool, optional, default=False
1548            If True, applies Sobel filtering to enhance edges prior to processing. 
1549            
1550        disp : bool, optional, default=False
1551            If True, displays intermediate processing results.
1552    
1553        Returns
1554        -------
1555        r_final : float
1556            Estimated row-coordinate of the image center after refinement.
1557            
1558        c_final : float
1559            Estimated column-coordinate of the image center after refinement.
1560        """
1561       
1562        # (1) Get image -------------------------------------------------------
1563        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1564        
1565        # Apply Sobel filter if requested
1566        if sobel:
1567            image = self.sobel_filt(image, disp=False)
1568        
1569        # Shift pixel values to ensure non-negative image
1570        image -= image.min()
1571     
1572    
1573        # (2) Normalize background intensity (optional) -----------------------
1574        if normalize_bg:
1575            with warnings.catch_warnings():
1576                warnings.simplefilter("ignore", category=RuntimeWarning)
1577                image = image.astype(np.float64) 
1578                image /= gaussian_filter(image, 
1579                                         sigma=min(image.shape) / 25, 
1580                                         truncate=2)
1581        
1582        # Replace NaN values with 0s
1583        image = np.nan_to_num(image, copy=False)
1584    
1585        # (3) Compute inversion symmetry using cross-correlation --------------
1586        # Dynamically set the margin to a reasonable fraction of the image size
1587        margin = int(np.floor(image.shape[0] // 4))
1588        im_i = image[margin:-margin, margin:-margin]  # Crop slightly
1589        
1590        template = im_i[::-1, ::-1]  # Inverted image for symmetry comparison
1591    
1592        # Compute cross-correlation using OpenCV template matching
1593        # it finds areas in an image that best match a given template. 
1594        # it compares the original image with its inverted version to measure 
1595        # inversion symmetry
1596        # im_i (template) slides over image in a pixel-by-pixel manner.
1597        # at each position, it computes the cross-correlation between 
1598        # overlapping pixels.
1599        # result is a 2D matrix, where each value represents the correlation 
1600        # score at a particular location. Higher values indicate
1601        # better symmetry at that position.
1602        
1603        # Ensure template is smaller than image
1604        assert template.shape[0] <= image.shape[0] \
1605            and template.shape[1] <= image.shape[1], \
1606            "Template is larger than the image"
1607        
1608        result = cv2.matchTemplate(image.astype(np.float32), 
1609                                   template.astype(np.float32), 
1610                                   method=cv2.TM_CCORR_NORMED)
1611        
1612        # Get the location of the best match in `result`
1613        max_location = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(result), result.shape) 
1614        correction_r, correction_c = max_location  
1615        
1616        if disp: 
1617            plt.figure()
1618            plt.imshow(result, cmap="inferno")
1619            plt.title("Correlation matrix")
1620            plt.show()
1621            plt.axis("off")
1622            plt.tight_layout()
1623            plt.show()
1624        
1625        # Adjust to original image coordinates (account for template cropping)
1626        corrected_r = correction_r + template.shape[0] // 2
1627        corrected_c = correction_c + template.shape[1] // 2
1628        
1629        # (4) Visualization ---------------------------------------------------
1630        # Plot with correct alignment
1631        if disp:
1632            
1633            plt.figure()
1634            if self.parent.icut:
1635                orig=np.where(self.parent.to_refine>self.parent.icut,
1636                              self.parent.icut, self.parent.to_refine)
1637            else: orig = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1638            
1639            # Assuming fft_im_i is your Fourier transform image
1640            center_size = 513
1641            center_x = orig.shape[1] // 2
1642            center_y = orig.shape[0] // 2
1643
1644            # Crop the central part of the spectrum
1645            orig = orig[
1646                center_y - center_size // 2:center_y + center_size // 2,
1647                center_x - center_size // 2:center_x + center_size // 2]
1648            
1649            plt.imshow(orig, cmap="gray", origin="lower")
1650            plt.scatter(corrected_c-center_x//2, corrected_r-center_y//2, 
1651                        color="white", marker="x", s=100,
1652                        label = "center")
1653            my_title =  "Location of the highest correlation coefficient"
1654            my_title += "in the original image."
1655            plt.title(my_title)
1656            plt.axis("off")
1657            plt.tight_layout()
1658            
1659            plt.show()
1660        
1661        # (5) User information (if required) ----------------------------------
1662        if self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print:
1663            self.parent.dText = \
1664                "Center Determination (CrossCorrCenter): ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1665
1666        return float(corrected_r), float(corrected_c), None
1667
1668    
1669    def detection_intensity(self, 
1670                            csquare, cintensity, plot_results=0, sobel=0):
1671        '''
1672        Find center of intensity/mass of an array.
1673        
1674        Parameters
1675        ----------
1676        arr : 2D-numpy array
1677            The array, whose intensity center will be determined.
1678            
1679        csquare : int, optional, default is 20
1680            The size/edge of the square in the (geometrical) center.
1681            The intensity center will be searched only within the central
1682            square.
1683            Reasons: To avoid other spots/diffractions and
1684            to minimize the effect of possible intensity assymetry
1685            around the center. 
1686            
1687        cintensity : float, optional, default is 0.8
1688            The intensity fraction.
1689            When searching the intensity center, we will consider only
1690            pixels with intensity > max.intensity.
1691            
1692        Returns
1693        -------
1694        xc, yc : float,float
1695            XY-coordinates of the intensity/mass center of the array.
1696            Round XY-coordinates if you use them for image/array calculations.
1697        '''  
1698        
1699        # (1) Get image/array size --------------------------------------------
1700        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1701        
1702        if sobel:
1703            image = self.sobel_filt(image, disp=False)
1704             
1705        arr = np.copy(image)
1706        xsize,ysize = arr.shape
1707        
1708        # (2) Calculate borders around the central square ---------------------
1709        xborder = (xsize - csquare) // 2
1710        yborder = (ysize - csquare) // 2
1711        
1712        # (3) Create the central square, --------------------------------------
1713        # from which the intensity center will be detected
1714        arr2 = arr[xborder:-xborder,yborder:-yborder].copy()
1715        
1716        # (4) In the central square, ------------------------------------------
1717        # set all values below cintenstity to zero
1718        arr2 = np.where(arr2>np.max(arr2)*cintensity, arr2, 0)
1719        
1720        # (5) Determine the intensity center from image moments ---------------
1721        # see image moments in...
1722        # skimage: https://scikit-image.org/docs/dev/api/skimage.measure.html
1723        # wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_moment -> Centroid
1724        # ---
1725        # (a) Calculate 1st central moments of the image
1726        M = moments(arr2,1)
1727        # (b) Calculate the intensity center = centroid according to www-help
1728        (self.x, self.y) = (M[1,0]/M[0,0], M[0,1]/M[0,0])
1729        # (c) We have centroid of the central square
1730        # but we have to recalculate it to the whole image
1731        (self.x, self.y) = (self.x + xborder, self.y + yborder)
1732        # (d) Radius of a diffraction ring 
1733        self.r = self.get_radius(
1734            self.parent.rtype, 
1735            image, 
1736            self.x, 
1737            self.y,
1738            disp=False)
1739        
1740        # (6) User information (if required) ----------------------------------
1741        if (self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print):
1742            self.parent.dText =\
1743                "Center Determination (IntensityCenter): ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1744
1745        # (7) Plot results (if required) --------------------------------------
1746        if plot_results == 1:
1747           self.visualize_center(self.x, self.y, self.r) 
1748                
1749        # (8) Return the results: ---------------------------------------------
1750        #  a) XY-coordinates of the center
1751        #  b) radius of the circle/diff.ring,
1752        #     from which the center was determined
1753
1754        return(self.x, self.y, self.r)
1755    
1756
1757    def detection_Hough(self, 
1758                        plot_results=False, sobel=False, live_plot=False):
1759        '''        
1760        Perform Hough transform to detect the center of diffraction patterns 
1761        with optional real-time visualization and a final image showing all 
1762        detected circles.
1763    
1764        Parameters
1765        ----------
1766        plot_results : int, binary
1767            If 1, shows the final detected circle.
1768        
1769        sobel : bool, optional, default=False
1770            If True, applies Sobel filtering to enhance edges prior to processing. 
1771            
1772        sobel            
1773        live_plot : bool, optional, default=False
1774            If True, animates the circle detection process and shows all 
1775            detected circles.
1776    
1777        Returns
1778        -------
1779        self.x : float64
1780            x-coordinate of the detected center.
1781            
1782        self.y : float64
1783            y-coordinate of the detected center.
1784            
1785        self.r : float64
1786            Radius of the detected circle.
1787        '''
1788        
1789        ## (0) Image preprocessing --------------------------------------------
1790        im = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1791                    
1792        if self.parent.heq == 0:
1793            if np.sum(im) < 150000:
1794                im[im > 50] = 0  
1795            edges = skf.canny(im, 
1796                              sigma=0.2, 
1797                              low_threshold=80, 
1798                              high_threshold=100)
1799        elif self.parent.heq == 1:
1800            if np.sum(im) > 40000:
1801                im[im > 50] = 0  
1802            edges = skf.canny(im, 
1803                              sigma=0.2, 
1804                              low_threshold=0.80, 
1805                              high_threshold=1)
1806        if sobel:
1807            edges = self.sobel_filt(im, disp=False)
1808
1809        ## (1) Define the radii range for concentric circles ------------------
1810        min_radius, max_radius, radius_step = 50, 120, 10
1811        radii = np.arange(min_radius, max_radius + radius_step, radius_step)
1812    
1813        # Store detected circles
1814        detected_circles = []
1815    
1816        if live_plot:
1817            if self.parent.icut is not None:
1818                image = np.where(im > self.parent.icut, self.parent.icut, im)
1819            else:
1820                image = np.copy(im)
1821                
1822            fig, ax = plt.subplots()
1823            plt.axis("off")
1824            ax.imshow(image, cmap=self.parent.cmap)
1825            plt.title("Live Hough Circle Detection")
1826            plt.ion()  # Turn on interactive mode
1827    
1828        ## (2) Process each radius one at a time ------------------------------
1829        for r in radii:
1830            hough_res = hough_circle(edges, np.array([r]))
1831            accums, x_peaks, y_peaks, _ = hough_circle_peaks(hough_res, 
1832                                                             np.array([r]), 
1833                                                             total_num_peaks=1)
1834    
1835            # Store circle if detected
1836            if len(x_peaks) > 0:
