3694        for iteration in range(max_iterations):    
3695            # Refine center while keeping radius constant
3696            curr = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
3697                                      best_center[0], 
3698                                      best_center[1], 
3699                                      best_radius)
3700            
3701            # Store intensity sums of the current center's neighborhood
3702            curr_intensity_sum = []
3703            for dx, dy in neighbors:
3704                nx, ny = best_center[0] + dx, best_center[1] + dy
3705                # Check if the point is within the expanded search radius
3706                curr_intensity_sum.append(self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
3707                                                        nx, ny, 
3708                                                        best_radius))
3709            
3710            # Find the maximum value coordinates within curr_sum
3711            cx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(curr_intensity_sum),
3712                                     [len(curr_intensity_sum),1])
3713                    
3714            # Check for improvement of criterion - in each iteration just once,
3715            # as the algorithm checks the neighbourhood of the best center
3716            # (in each iteration, the center is updated if possible)
3717            if max(curr_intensity_sum) > max_intensity_sum:                           
3718                max_intensity_sum = max(curr_intensity_sum)
3719                
3720                # Calculate the new best coordinates of the center
3721                n = neighbors[cx]
3722                (nx, ny) = tuple(map(lambda x, y: float(x) + float(y), 
3723                                     best_center, n))
3724                best_center = px, py = (np.copy(nx), np.copy(ny))
3725    
3726            # Update maximum intensity sum 
3727            max_intensity_sum = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
3728                                                    best_center[0], 
3729                                                    best_center[1], 
3730                                                    best_radius)
3731    
3732        
3733            # Refine radius if necessary while keeping the center position 
3734            # constant. It iterates through different radius adjustments
3735            # to find a radius that maximizes the intensity sum of pixels.
3736            
3737            radi_intensity_sum = []
3738            radii = np.arange(-1.0, 1.0 + step, step)
3739            for dr in radii:
3740                new_radius = best_radius + dr
3741                radi_intensity_sum.append(self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
3742                                                            best_center[0], 
3743                                                            best_center[1], 
3744                                                            new_radius))
3745                
3746            # Find the maximum value coordinates within curr_sum
3747            rx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(radi_intensity_sum),
3748                                      [len(radi_intensity_sum),1])
3749    
3750            # Check for improvement of criterion
3751            if max(radi_intensity_sum) > max_intensity_sum:
3752                max_intensity_sum = max(radi_intensity_sum)
3753                
3754                n = radii[rx]
3755                nr = best_radius+n
3756                
3757                best_radius = pr = np.copy(nr)
3758                
3759            
3760            # Check for convergence and improvement (termination conditions)
3761            impr = abs(max_intensity_sum - curr)
3762            if impr < convergence_threshold:
3763                no_improvement_count += 1
3764                if no_improvement_count == 25:
3765                    break
3766                
3767            # --- Live plot update ---
3768            if live_plot:
3769                circ_artist.center = best_center
3770                circ_artist.set_radius(best_radius)
3771                ax.set_title(
3772                    f"Iteration {iteration+1} | Sum={max_intensity_sum:.1f}")
3773                fig.canvas.draw()
3774                fig.canvas.flush_events()
3775                plt.pause(0.01)  # small delay for visual update
3776        
3777        # Avoid incorrect/redundant refinement
3778        # ## (1) swapped coordinates
3779        # if ((bckup[0] > bckup[1] and not best_center[0] > best_center[1])
3780        #     or  (bckup[0] < bckup[1]
3781        #     and not best_center[0] < best_center[1])):
3782        #     best_center = best_center[::-1]
3783        
3784        ## (2) worsened final maximum intensity sum than the initial one
3785        if np.round(init_sum,-2) > np.round(max_intensity_sum,-2):
3786            print("Refinement redundant.")
3787            best_center = np.copy(bckup)
3788    
3789        # Print results
3790        if (self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print):
3791            self.parent.rText = \
3792                "Center Refinement (IntensitySum)      : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
3793        
3794        if live_plot:
3795            plt.ioff()
3796            plt.show()
3797
3798        return best_center[0], best_center[1], best_radius
3799    
3800    
3801    def diagnose_landscape(self, px, py, pr, metric='std', search_range=2.0, steps=21):
3802        """
3803        Visualize the optimization landscape of a center refinement metric
3804        around a candidate center location and radius.
3805    
3806        This function evaluates the selected metric over a grid of positions
3807        in a 2D neighborhood around the given (px, py) center, using a fixed
3808        radius `pr`, and visualizes the results as a heatmap with contours.
3809    
3810        It can be useful for diagnosing whether the optimization function
3811        (e.g., standard deviation, median, or sum of pixel intensities) has
3812        a smooth and well-behaved landscape, which is important for gradient
3813        optimization methods.
3814    
3815        Parameters
3816        ----------
3817        px : float
3818            X-coordinate of the candidate center.
3819            
3820        py : float
3821            Y-coordinate of the candidate center.
3822            
3823        pr : float
3824            Radius of the circular region to evaluate the metric on.
3825            
3826        metric : str, optional
3827            The metric to evaluate. Options are:
3828            - 'std': standard deviation of pixel values (default)
3829            - 'median': median of pixel values
3830            - 'sum': sum of pixel values
3831            
3832        search_range : float, optional, default=2.0
3833            The radius of the square region (in pixels) around the center 
3834            to explore. The grid will extend `search_range` in both x and y 
3835            directions.
3836            
3837        steps : int, optional, default=21
3838            The number of points to sample along each axis (grid resolution).
3839            Must be an odd number to ensure the center point is included.
3840    
3841        Returns
3842        -------
3843        None
3844            This method produces a matplotlib plot and does not return any value.
3845        """
3846        # Helper functions ----------------------------------------------------
3847        def intensity_sum(self, image, cx, cy, r):
3848            pixels = self.parent.get_circle_pixels(image, cx, cy, r)
3849            return np.sum(pixels)
3850        
3851        def intensity_std(self, image, cx, cy, r):
3852            pixels = self.parent.get_circle_pixels(image, cx, cy, r)
3853            return np.std(pixels)
3854        
3855        def intensity_median(self, image, cx, cy, r):
3856            pixels = self.parent.get_circle_pixels(image, cx, cy, r)
3857            return np.median(pixels)
3858
3859        print(f"Diagnosing landscape around ({px:.1f}, {py:.1f}) with r={pr:.1f}...")
3860        
3861        # (0) Select the metric function --------------------------------------
3862        metric_map = {'std': intensity_std, 
3863                      'median': intensity_median, 
3864                      'sum': intensity_sum }
3865        metric_func = metric_map.get(metric, intensity_std)
3866    
3867        # (1) Create a grid of x and y coordinates to test --------------------
3868        x_range = np.linspace(px - search_range, px + search_range, steps)
3869        y_range = np.linspace(py - search_range, py + search_range, steps)
3870        score_grid = np.zeros((steps, steps))
3871    
3872        # (2) Calculate the metric score at each point on the grid ------------
3873        for i, y in enumerate(y_range):
3874            for j, x in enumerate(x_range):
3875                score_grid[i, j] = metric_func(self.parent.image, x, y, pr)
3876    
3877        # (3) Plot the results ------------------------------------------------
3878        plt.figure(figsize=(4, 4))
3879        plt.imshow(
3880            score_grid, 
3881            origin='lower', 
3882            extent=[x_range[0], x_range[-1], y_range[0], y_range[-1]]
3883            )
3884        plt.colorbar(label=f"Metric Score ('{metric}')")
3885        plt.contour(x_range, y_range, score_grid, colors='white', alpha=0.5)
3886        
3887        # Mark the starting point
3888        plt.plot(px, py, 'r+', markersize=15, label='Initial Guess')
3889        plt.title("Optimization Landscape")
3890        plt.xlabel("X-coordinate")
3891        plt.ylabel("Y-coordinate")
3892        plt.legend()
3893        plt.show()
3894        
3895
3896class HandlerCircle(HandlerBase):
3897    """
3898    Helper class for creating circular markers in matplotlib legends.
3899
3900    This class customizes the legend to display circular markers instead of the 
3901    default. It is intended for internal use within the module and not 
3902    for general use.
3903
3904    Methods:
3905    --------
3906    create_artists(legend, 
3907                   orig_handle, 
3908                   xdescent,
3909                   ydescent, 
3910                   width, 
3911                   height, 
3912                   fontsize, 
3913                   trans):
3914        Creates a circular marker for the legend based on the original handle's 
3915        properties.
3916
3917    Parameters for `create_artists`:
3918        legend : matplotlib.legend.Legend
3919            The legend instance where the custom marker will be used.
3920        orig_handle : matplotlib.artist.Artist
3921            The original handle containing the marker properties 
3922            (e.g., facecolor, edgecolor).
3923        xdescent : float
3924            Horizontal offset adjustment for the marker.
3925        ydescent : float
3926            Vertical offset adjustment for the marker.
3927        width : float
3928            Width of the legend entry.
3929        height : float
3930            Height of the legend entry.
3931        fontsize : float
3932            Font size of the legend text.
3933        trans : matplotlib.transforms.Transform
3934            Transformation applied to the marker's coordinates.
3935
3936    Returns:
3937    --------
3938    list of matplotlib.patches.Circle
3939        A list containing a single circular marker artist.
3940    """
3941
3942    def create_artists(self, legend, orig_handle, xdescent, ydescent, 
3943                       width, height, fontsize, trans):
3944        # Calculate the center and radius of the circle
3945        x = width / 2
3946        y = height / 2
3947        r = min(width, height) / 2
3948
3949        # Create a circular marker using the properties of the original handle
3950        marker = Circle((x, y), r,
3951                        facecolor=orig_handle.get_facecolor(),
3952                        edgecolor=orig_handle.get_edgecolor(),
3953                        linewidth=orig_handle.get_linewidth(),
3954                        transform=trans)
3955
3956        return [marker]
3957
3958
3959class PocketFFTBackend:
3960    """
3961    High-performance FFT backend leveraging SciPy's PocketFFT with optimized 
3962    defaults. This backend enhances the efficiency of Fast Fourier Transforms 
3963    (FFT), particularly for 2D transforms, which may experience up to a 50% 
3964    speed improvement over standard configurations.
3965
3966    Attributes
3967    ----------
3968    __ua_domain__ : str
3969        Universal array domain identifier for NumPy's SciPy-based FFT interface.
3970
3971    Methods
3972    -------
3973    __ua_function__(method, args, kwargs)
3974        Universal array function handler that dispatches FFT operations to the 
3975        corresponding PocketFFT implementation with optimized threading
3976        settings.
3977    """
3978
3979    __ua_domain__ = "numpy.scipy.fft"
3980
3981    @staticmethod
3982    def __ua_function__(method, args, kwargs):
3983        """
3984        Dispatches FFT operations to SciPy's PocketFFT with optimized worker 
3985        settings. This method dynamically selects the appropriate PocketFFT 
3986        function and applies threading optimizations by adjusting the number 
3987        of workers.
3988
3989        Parameters
3990        ----------
3991        method : callable
3992            The FFT function being dispatched.
3993        args : tuple
3994            Positional arguments passed to the FFT function.
3995        kwargs : dict
3996            Keyword arguments passed to the FFT function, including
3997            the optional "workers" parameter for parallel execution.
3998
3999        Returns
4000        -------
4001        result : object
4002            The output of the FFT function if supported; 
4003            otherwise, returns NotImplemented.
4004        """
4005        fn = getattr(_pocketfft, method.__name__, None)
4006        if fn is None:
4007            return NotImplemented
4008        
4009        workers = kwargs.pop("workers", CPU_COUNT)
4010        return fn(*args, workers=workers, **kwargs)
4011
4012        
4013class IntensityCenter: 
4014    '''
4015    Simple center determination for a symmetric diffractogram.
4016    
4017    * The center is determined as a center of intensity.
4018    * This works well for simple, symmetric diffraction patters, which are:
4019      (i) without beamstopper, (ii) pre-centered, and (iii) powder-like.
4020    * A real-life example of a simple symmetric diffractogram:
4021      a good powder electron diffraction pattern from STEMDIFF software.
4022    * This class is a legacy from previous EDIFF versions;
4023      it is kept mostly for backward compatibility.
4024      The functions in this class can be (and should be)
4025      replaced by a simple call of ediff.center.CenterLocator object.
4026      
4027    >>> # Center determination in a simple symmetric diffraction pattern
4028    >>> # (center = just center_of_intensity, no refinement
4029    >>>
4030    >>> # (1) Old way = this (old, legacy) IntensityCenter class:
4031    >>> xc,yc = ediff.center.IntensityCenter.center_of_intensity(
4032    >>>     arr, csquare=30, cintensity=0.8)
4033    >>>
4034    >>> # (2) New way = newer (and more universal) CenterLocator class:
4035    >>> xc,yc = ediff.center.CenterLocator(
4036    >>>     arr, detection_method='intensity', csquare=30, cintensity=0.8)
4037    '''
4038    
4039    @staticmethod
4040    def center_of_intensity(arr, csquare=20, cintensity=0.8):
4041        '''
4042        Find center of intensity/mass of an array.
4043        
4044        Parameters
4045        ----------
4046        arr : 2D-numpy array
4047            The array, whose intensity center will be determined.
4048        csquare : int, optional, default is 20
4049            The size/edge of the square in the (geometrical) center.
4050            The intensity center is searched only within the central square.
4051            Reasons: To avoid other spots/diffractions and
4052            to minimize the effect of an intensity assymetry around center. 
4053        cintensity : float, optional, default is 0.8
4054            The intensity fraction.
4055            When searching the intensity center, we will consider only
4056            pixels with intensity > max.intensity.
4057            
4058        Returns
4059        -------
4060        xc,yc : float,float
4061            XY-coordinates of the intensity/mass center of the array.
4062            Round XY-coordinates if you use them for image/array calculations.    
4063        '''
4064        # Get image/array size
4065        xsize,ysize = arr.shape
4066        # Calculate borders around the central square
4067        xborder = (xsize - csquare) // 2
4068        yborder = (ysize - csquare) // 2
4069        # Create central square = cut off the borders
4070        arr2 = arr[xborder:-xborder,yborder:-yborder].copy()
4071        # In the central square, set all values below cintenstity to zero
4072        arr2 = np.where(arr2>np.max(arr2)*cintensity, arr2, 0)
4073        # Calculate 1st central moments of the image
4074        M = sk.measure.moments(arr2,1)
4075        # Calculate the intensity center = centroid according to www-help
4076        (xc,yc) = (M[1,0]/M[0,0], M[0,1]/M[0,0])
4077        # We have centroid of the central square => recalculate to whole image
4078        (xc,yc) = (xc+xborder,yc+yborder)
4079        
4080        ## Return the final center
4081        return(xc,yc)
class CenterLocator: 
 64class CenterLocator:
 65    '''
 66    CenterLocator object : determine and refine the center of a 2D electron 
 67    diffraction pattern (diffractogram)
 68    
 69    This class detects the center of diffraction patterns. It offers several 
 70    automatic or manual methods and optionally refines the center position.
 71
 72
 73    Parameters
 74    ----------
 75    input_image : str, path, or numpy.ndarray
 76        The input 2D diffraction image, either a file path or a NumPy array.
 77
 78    determination : str or None, optional, default=None
 79        Method used for the initial center determination.
 80        Options include:
 81        - 'manual': Manual detection = interactive plot where the user
 82          selects 3 points defining a diffraction ring with a mouse.
 83        - 'intensity' : Auto-detection = the intensity center
 84          from the central region.
 85        - 'curvefit': Automatic detection = fit the intensity center
 86          from the central region using pseudo-Voigt profile.                      
 87        - 'hough' : Automatic detection using Hough transform
 88          to find center of ring-like structures.
 89        - 'phase' : Automatic detection using phase correlation
 90          to find the symmetry center.
 91        - 'ccorr' : Automatic detection using cross-correlation
 92          to find the symmetry center.
 93        - None : Skip the center determination;
 94          it is supposed that the center coordinates
 95          will be read from *in_file* argument - see below.
 96          
 97    refinement : str or None, optional, default=None
 98        Method used for refining the initially detected center.
 99        Options include:
100        - 'manual': Manual fine-tuning of the center along
101          the selected diffraction ring.
102        - 'sum' : Automatic refinement by maximizing the intensity sum
103          the selected diffraction ring.
104        - 'var': Automatic refinement by minimizing intensity variance
105          the selected diffraction ring.
106
107    rtype : int, default=1
108        How to determine a radius of a difraction ring for center refinement.
109        In powder diffractograms, the diffraction rings are clearly defined.
110        In spotty diffractograms, the diffraction ring is an fictive ring
111        connecting at least three diffraction spots.
112        Options include:
113        - 0 : Peak matching method
114          (fast and simple, but failing for non-powders, historical).
115        - 1 : Radial distribution method
116          (slower but more universal, new default).
117        
118    in_file : str or None, optional, default=None
119        Path to a file from which the (previously saved)
120        center coordinates will be loaded.
121
122    out_file : str or None, optional, default=None
123        Path to a file where the determined
124        center coordinates will be saved.
125        
126    sobel : bool, optional, default=False
127        If True, apply Sobel filter to the image before processing.
128        
129    heq : bool or None, optional, default=False
130        If True, apply histogram equalization internally (display unchanged).
131
132    icut : float or None, optional, default=None
133        Cut-off intensity level for processing the image.
134        
135    cmap : str, optional, default='gray'
136        Matplotlib colormap name used for displaying the image.
137        
138    csquare : int, optional, default=50
139        Size (in pixels) of the central square used for initial center search.
140        
141    cintensity : float, optional, default=0.8
142        Threshold intensity for finding the intensity center. Pixels with a 
143        (relative) intensity lower than cintensity are ignored.
144        
145    verbose : int, optional, default=0
146        Verbosity level for printing messages during processing:
147        - 0 : Silent mode  no messages are printed.
148        - 1 : Show help messages during manual refinement only.
149        - 2 : Full verbose mode  print all messages and debug information.
150        - 3 : Progress mode  print brief status updates during time-consuming 
151              processing.
152        
153    print_sums : bool, optional, default=False
154        If True, print intensity sums after each adjustment (in manual modes).
155        
156    final_print : bool, optional, default=True
157        If True, print final coordinates to stdout.
158    
159    live_plot : bool, optional, default=True
160        If True, show live visualization of some processes if available.
161 
162    Returns
163    -------
164    None
165        The result is stored in the instance variables:
166        - `(x1, y1)` for the initially determined center
167        - `(x2, y2)` for the refined center (if refinement is applied)
168            
169    Technical notes
170    ---------------
171    * The class automatically initializes and uses two internal components:
172      `CenterDetermination` and `CenterRefinement`.
173    * These internal processes are hidden from the user but can be accessed 
174      directly if needed.
175
176    Examples
177    --------
178    >>> import ediff as ed
179    >>>
180    >>> locator = ed.center.CenterLocator(
181    >>>    input_image   = '.r/path/to/your/data.png',   
182    >>>    determination = 'manual',           
183    >>>    refinement    = 'sum',
184    >>>    final_print   = True)   
185                              
186    '''
187    
188    
189    def __init__(self,
190                 input_image, 
191                 determination = None, 
192                 refinement = None,
193                 rtype = 1,
194                 in_file = None,
195                 out_file = None,
196                 sobel = False,
197                 masking = True,
198                 ellipse = False,
199                 mcorrect = None,
200                 heq = False, 
201                 icut = None,
202                 cmap = 'gray',
203                 csquare=50,
204                 cintensity=0.8,
205                 verbose = 0,
206                 print_sums = False,
207                 final_print = True,
208                 live_plot = False):
209        
210        ######################################################################
211        # PRIVATE FUNCTION: Initialize CenterLocator object.
212        # The parameters are described above in class definition.
213        ######################################################################
214
215        ## Initialize input attributes ---------------------------------------
216        
217        # Input image = diffraction pattern
218        # (it can be either image file or numpy array)
219        self.input_image = input_image
220        
221        # Methods of center determination, refinement, and radius estimation
222        self.determination = determination
223        self.refinement = refinement
224        self.rtype = rtype
225        
226        # For reproducibility, convert the method names to lowercase
227        if determination is not None:
228            self.determination = determination.lower()
229        if refinement is not None:
230            self.refinement = refinement.lower()
231        
232        # Text files for reading/saving center coordinates
233        self.in_file = in_file
234        self.out_file = out_file
235        
236        # Image processing parameters
237        self.ellipse = ellipse
238        self.mcorrect = mcorrect
239        self.sobel = sobel
240        self.masking = masking
241        self.heq = heq
242        self.icut = icut
243        self.cmap = cmap
244        self.csquare = csquare
245        self.cintensity = cintensity
246        
247        # Process-Information parameters
248        self.verbose = verbose
249        self.print_sums = print_sums
250        self.final_print = final_print
251        self.live_plot = live_plot
252        
253        ## Initialize new attributes ------------------------------------------
254        self.to_refine = []
255        self.dText = []
256        self.rText = []
257        
258        # The value of the following attribute can be adjusted
259        self.marker_size = 100          
260
261        ## (1) Read input image -----------------------------------------------
262        if self.verbose==3:
263            print("[INFO] Loading image.")
264        # The input image can be numpy.array (ndarray) or image file (path/str)
265        if isinstance(input_image, np.ndarray):
266            self.image = input_image
267        else:
268            self.image = ediff.io.read_image(self.input_image)
269        
270        ## (2) Correct ellipse ------------------------------------------------
271        if self.ellipse:
272            if self.verbose==3:
273                print("[INFO] Correcting ellipse distortion... ", 
274                      end="", flush=True)
275            self.image = self.ellipse_distortion(self.image, show=True,
276                                                 method=self.mcorrect)
277            if self.verbose == 3:
278                print(" [DONE]")
279                
280        ## (3) Read center coordinates ----------------------------------------
281        # The center coordinates may have been determined in a previous run 
282        # of the program and saved to a text file.
283        # We can Load coordinates from an input file if specified, this is done 
284        # by the following command. As the saved coordinates can be used INSTEAD 
285        # of CenterDetermination we will read them here.
286        if self.in_file is not None: 
287            self.load_results()  
288            if self.verbose==3:
289                print("[INFO] Loading saved center coordinates.")
290        
291        ## (4) Run CenterDetermination ----------------------------------------
292        if self.verbose == 3:
293            print("[INFO] Detecting center...", end="", flush=True)
294            
295        #  (4a) Initialize/run CenterDetermination
296        self.center1 = CenterDetermination(self,
297                self.input_image,
298                self.determination,
299                self.heq,
300                self.icut,
301                self.cmap,
302                self.csquare,
303                self.cintensity,
304                self.verbose,
305                self.print_sums)
306        
307        if self.verbose == 3:
308            print(" [DONE]")
309    
310        #  (4b) Find radius of a circle/diffraction ring, which is needed 
311        #       for the next step = CenterRefimenement.
312        if self.verbose==3:
313            print("[INFO] Estimating radius of the diffraction pattern...",
314                  end="", flush=True)
315    
316        if self.determination != "manual":
317            self.center1.r = self.center1.get_radius(
318                self.rtype,
319                self.image, 
320                self.center1.x, 
321                self.center1.y, 
322                disp=False)
323        
324        if self.verbose == 3:
325            print(" [DONE]")
326            
327        ## (5) Initialize/run CenterRefinement --------------------------------
328        if self.verbose==3:
329            print("[INFO] Refining center coordinates...",
330                  end="", flush=True)
331                
332        self.center2 = CenterRefinement(self,
333            self.input_image, 
334            self.refinement,
335            self.in_file,
336            self.out_file,
337            self.heq, 
338            self.icut,
339            self.cmap,
340            self.verbose,
341            self.print_sums)
342        
343        if self.verbose == 3:
344            print(" [DONE]")
345            
346            
347        ## (6) Collect results ------------------------------------------------
348        if self.verbose==3:
349            print("[INFO] Collecting results.")
350        self.x1 = self.center1.x
351        self.y1 = self.center1.y
352        
353        # Center only detected and not refined
354        if self.refinement is not None:
355            self.x2 = self.center2.xx
356            self.y2 = self.center2.yy
357        else: 
358            # Center detected and refined
359            self.x2 = self.center1.x
360            self.y2 = self.center1.y
361            self.center2.xx = self.center1.x
362            self.center2.yy = self.center1.y
363            self.center2.rr = self.center1.r
364        
365        ## (7) Switch coordinates if necessary --------------------------------
366        #      This step is important, as center detection/refinement methods
367        #      have various coordinate system origins. The conversion is 
368        #      necessary for some combinations of methods
369        
370        if (self.determination == "intensity"):
371            self.x1, self.y1 = self.convert_coords(self.x1, self.y1)
372            self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2)  
373        
374        if (self.determination =="hough" and self.refinement == "manual"):
375            self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2)  
376
377        if (self.determination =="phase" and self.refinement == "manual"):
378            self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2)  
379            
380        if (self.determination =="ccorr" and self.refinement == "manual"):
381            self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2) 
382                        
383        if (self.determination == "curvefit" and self.refinement == "manual"):
384            self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2) 
385                            
386        ## (8) Print the coordinates if required ------------------------------
387        if self.final_print:
388            self.dText=str(self.dText)
389            self.rText=str(self.rText)
390            
391            print("----------------------------------------------------------")
392            print(self.dText.format(float(self.x1),float(self.y1)))
393            
394            if self.refinement is not None:
395                print(self.rText.format(float(self.x2),float(self.y2)))
396                        
397        ## (9) Save results to a .txt file if specified -----------------------
398        
399        if out_file is not None:
400            self.save_results()
401            if self.verbose==3:
402                print("[INFO] Saving results.")
403
404    
405    def output(self):
406        """
407        Return the final results of center determination and refinement. 
408        
409        Returns
410        -------
411        x1 : float
412            x-coordinate of the center determined by the *determination* method.
413            
414        y1 : float
415            y-coordinate of the center determined by the *determination* method.
416        
417        x2 : float
418            x-coordinate of the center after *refinement*, or same as x1 if no 
419            refinement was used.
420        
421        y2 : float
422            y-coordinate of the center after *refinement*, or same as y1 if no 
423            refinement was used.
424
425            
426        Notes
427        -----
428        - The function always returns four values: (x1, y1, x2, y2).
429        - If no refinement method was used (`refinement=None`), then (x2, y2) 
430          will be equal to (x1, y1).
431        - All values are rounded to one decimal place before returning.
432        - Coordinates are internally converted to float to ensure consistency 
433          in output.
434        """
435        
436        # (1) refinement=None -------------------------------------------------
437        if self.center2.ret == 1:
438            # Convert to float
439            if type(self.x1) != float:
440                self.x1, self.y1, self.x2, self.y2 = \
441                    [float(value) for value in (self.x1, self.y1, 
442                                                self.x2, self.y2)]
443                    
444        # (2) refinement!=None ------------------------------------------------
445        else:
446            # Convert to float
447            if type(self.x1) != float:
448                self.x1, self.y1 = \
449                    [float(value) for value in (self.x1,self.y1)]
450            # Define x2,y2 = x1,y1
451            self.x2 = self.x1
452            self.y2 = self.y1
453            
454        # (3) Return (rounded) values of center coordinates -------------------
455        return (np.round(self.x1,1), np.round(self.y1,1), 
456                np.round(self.x2,1), np.round(self.y2,1))  
457
458    
459    def save_results(self):
460        '''
461        Save the determined and refined center coordinates to a file.
462    
463        This method writes the coordinates (x1, y1) from the *determination*
464        step and (x2, y2) from the *refinement* step to a file specified by the 
465        `out_file` attribute.
466    
467        - If the file already exists, the results are appended to the end.
468        - If the file does not exist, it is created and the results are written.
469        - Coordinates are formatted to four decimal places for clarity.
470        
471        
472        Parameters
473        ----------
474        None
475        
476        Returns
477        -------
478        None
479        
480        Notes
481        -----
482        - If `self.out_file` is None, the method does nothing.
483        - The results are written in the format:
484            x1: <value>, y1: <value>
485            x2: <value>, y2: <value>
486        - This method does not raise an error if the path is invalid;
487          ensure `out_file` is a valid writable path.
488        '''
489        
490        if self.out_file is not None:
491            # Check if the specified file exists
492            if os.path.isfile(self.out_file):
493                # Append results to in_file
494                with open(self.out_file, 'a') as f:  # Open in append mode
495                    f.write(f"x1: {self.x1:.4f}, y1: {self.y1:.4f}\n")
496                    f.write(f"x2: {self.x2:.4f}, y2: {self.y2:.4f}\n")
497            else:
498                # If the file does not exist, create it and write results
499                with open(self.out_file, 'w') as f:  # Open in write mode
500                    f.write(f"x1: {self.x1:.4f}, y1: {self.y1:.4f}\n")
501                    f.write(f"x2: {self.x2:.4f}, y2: {self.y2:.4f}\n")
502
503
504    def load_results(self, path=None):
505        """
506        Load center coordinates from a results file.
507    
508        This method reads a text file (defaulting to `self.in_file` or
509        a provided `path`) containing previously saved center coordinates.
510        It extracts coordinate pairs (x1, y1) from the determination step and
511        (x2, y2) from the refinement step. All sets of values are stored
512        internally, with the most recent values assigned to instance variables 
513        `self.x1`, `self.y1`, `self.x2`, and `self.y2`.
514    
515        Parameters
516        ----------
517        path : str, optional
518            Path to the results file. 
519            If not provided, the method uses `self.in_file`.
520    
521        Returns
522        -------
523        tuple or None
524            If `path` is provided and successfully loaded:
525                (x1_values, y1_values) : Lists of all loaded x1 and y1 values.
526            If loading fails:
527                None
528    
529        Notes
530        -----
531        - The file is expected to contain lines in the following format:
532            x1: <value>, y1: <value>
533            x2: <value>, y2: <value>
534        - Multiple coordinate entries can be loaded; the last set is stored in
535          the instance variables for easy access.
536        - If the file doesn't exist or is unreadable, a warning is printed and
537          the function returns None.
538        """      
539        
540        if path is not None:
541            self.in_file = path
542            
543        if self.in_file is not None and os.path.isfile(self.in_file):
544            with open(self.in_file, 'r') as f:
545                lines = f.readlines()
546                
547                # Initialize lists to hold multiple values
548                x1_values = []
549                y1_values = []
550                x2_values = []
551                y2_values = []
552    
553                for line in lines:
554                    # Strip and split each line to get the coordinates
555                    parts = line.strip().split(',')
556                    if len(parts) == 2:
557                        # Extract x1 and y1 or x2 and y2 based on line content
558                        if 'x1' in parts[0]:
559                            x1 = float(parts[0].split(':')[1].strip())
560                            y1 = float(parts[1].split(':')[1].strip())
561                            x1_values.append(x1)
562                            y1_values.append(y1)
563                        elif 'x2' in parts[0]:
564                            x2 = float(parts[0].split(':')[1].strip())
565                            y2 = float(parts[1].split(':')[1].strip())
566                            x2_values.append(x2)
567                            y2_values.append(y2)
568    
569                # Store the last set of values as instance variables 
570                self.x1 = x1_values
571                self.y1 = y1_values
572                self.x2 = x2_values
573                self.y2 = y2_values
574    
575                # Store the last loaded values:
576                if x1_values and y1_values and x2_values and y2_values:
577                    self.x1 = x1_values[-1]
578                    self.y1 = y1_values[-1]
579                    self.x2 = x2_values[-1]
580                    self.y2 = y2_values[-1]
581                    
582                if path is not None:
583                    return x1_values, y1_values
584        else:
585            print("Error reading text file with center coordinates!")
586            return
587
588
589    def get_circle_pixels(self, image, cx, cy, r, num_points=360):
590        """
591        Extract pixel values along a circular path in the image.
592    
593        Parameters
594        ----------
595        image : np.ndarray
596            2D grayscale image from which pixel values are extracted.
597            
598        cx : float
599            X-coordinate (row) of the circle center.
600        
601        cy : float
602            Y-coordinate (column) of the circle center.
603        
604        r : float
605            Radius of the circle.
606        
607        num_points : int, optional
608            Number of points to sample along the circular path. Default is 360.
609    
610        Returns
611        -------
612        pixels : np.ndarray
613            1D array of pixel intensity values sampled along the circular path.
614        """
615        points = np.linspace(0, 2 * np.pi, num_points)
616        
617        # Generate coordinates for the circle
618        x = cx + r * np.cos(points)
619        y = cy + r * np.sin(points)
620        
621        # Use map_coordinates for accurate sub-pixel interpolation
622        coords = np.vstack((y, x))
623        
624        # 'order=1' is linear interpolation
625        pixels = map_coordinates(image, 
626                                 coords, 
627                                 order=1, 
628                                 mode='constant', 
629                                 cval=0.0)
630        
631        # Return pixels
632        return pixels
633     
634     
635    def intensity_sum(self, im, cx, cy, r):
636        """
637        Compute the sum of pixel intensities along a circular path.
638    
639        This function extracts pixel values along a circle defined by the 
640        given center coordinates (cx, cy) and radius r, then returns 
641        the sum of these intensities.
642    
643        Parameters
644        ----------
645        im : np.ndarray
646            2D grayscale image from which the intensities are extracted.
647        
648        cx : float
649            X-coordinate (row) of the circle center.
650        
651        cy : float
652            Y-coordinate (column) of the circle center.
653        
654        r : float
655            Radius of the circle.
656    
657        Returns
658        -------
659        float
660            Sum of pixel intensities along the circular path.
661        """
662        # Get pixel intensities
663        pixels = self.get_circle_pixels(im, cx, cy, r)
664        
665        # Sum pixel intensities
666        return np.sum(pixels)
667    
668    
669    def intensity_variance(self, image, px, py, pr):
670        ''' 
671        Variance of intensity values of pixels of a diffraction pattern.
672
673        Parameters
674        ----------
675        image : array of uint8
676            image from which the diffraction pattern has been detected.
677        
678        px : float64
679            x-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
680        
681        py : float64
682            y-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
683        
684        pr : float64
685            radius of the diffraction pattern.
686
687        Returns
688        -------
689        s : float64
690            intensity variance
691
692        '''
693        # Extract pixels on the circle border
694        pxc, pyc = self.get_circle_pixels(px, py, pr)
695        pxc = np.array(pxc, dtype=int)
696        pyc = np.array(pyc, dtype=int)
697        
698        # Calculate sum using the filtered values
699        s = np.var(image[pxc, pyc])
700        return s
701    
702    
703    def convert_coords(self, x, y):
704        """
705        Convert coordinates between numpy and matplotlib systems.
706
707        Parameters
708        ----------
709        x : int or float
710            The x-coordinate in the numpy (column index) format.
711        
712        y : int or float
713            The y-coordinate in the numpy (row index) format.
714
715        Returns
716        -------
717        tuple of (int or float, int or float)
718            The converted coordinates in matplotlib format, where:
719            - First element corresponds to y (new x in matplotlib).
720            - Second element corresponds to x (new y in matplotlib).
721        """
722        return y, x
723
724
725    def visualize_results(self, csquare=None, out_file=None, out_dpi=200):
726        '''
727        Visualize diffractogram and its center after
728        center determination + refinement.
729    
730        Parameters
731        ----------
732        csquare : int, optional, default is None
733            If csquare argument is given,
734            only the central square of the diffractogram will be plotted;
735            the size of the central square will be equal to csquare argument.
736        
737        out_file : str, optional, default is None
738            If out_file is given,
739            save the final plot to image named *out_file*.
740        
741        out_dpi : int, optional, default is 200
742            DPI of the output image file;
743            this parameter is relevant only if out_file is given.
744    
745        Returns
746        -------
747        None
748            The output is the image of the diffractogram
749            showing also the central coordinates and refinement ring.
750        '''
751        
752        # (0) Collect center coordinates and radii ----------------------------
753        x1, y1 = (self.x1, self.y1)
754        r1 = self.center1.r
755
756        x2, y2 = (self.x2, self.y2)
757        r2 = self.center2.rr
758
759        # (1) Prepare the image of the diffractogram --------------------------
760        image = np.copy(self.to_refine)
761        if self.icut is not None:
762            im = np.where(image > self.icut, self.icut, image)
763        else:
764            im = np.copy(image)
765            
766        # (2) Calculate intensity sum or intensity variance -------------------
767        if self.refinement == "var":
768            dvar = self.intensity_variance(image, x1, y1, r1)
769            rvar = self.intensity_variance(image, x2, y2, r2)
770            labeld = f'd-center: [{x1:.1f}, {y1:.1f}]\nint-var: {dvar:.1f}'
771            labelr = f'r-center: [{x2:.1f}, {y2:.1f}]\nint-var: {rvar:.1f}'
772        else:
773            dsum = self.intensity_sum(image, x1, y1, r1)
774            rsum = self.intensity_sum(image, x2, y2, r2)
775            labeld = f'd-center: [{x1:.1f}, {y1:.1f}]\nint-sum: {dsum:.1f}'
776            labelr = f'r-center: [{x2:.1f}, {y2:.1f}]\nint-sum: {rsum:.1f}'
777            
778        # (3) Calculate xy-limits if we want to see only the central square ---
779        if csquare is not None:
780            xmin, xmax = (0, image.shape[0])
781            ymin, ymax = (0, image.shape[1])
782            edge = (xmax - csquare) // 2
783            xmin += edge
784            xmax -= edge
785            ymin += edge
786            ymax -= edge
787    
788        # (4) Final plot: show the diffractogram + refinement results ---------
789        fig, ax = plt.subplots(layout='constrained')
790        ax.imshow(im, cmap=self.cmap)
791    
792        ax.set_title(f'Center :: {self.determination}/{self.refinement}')
793    
794        ax.scatter(x1, y1, 
795                   label=labeld, 
796                   color='gold', 
797                   marker='x', 
798                   s=60, lw=1)
799        c0 = plt.Circle((x1, y1), r1, 
800                        color='gold', 
801                        fill=False, 
802                        label='detected center', 
803                        lw=1)
804        ax.add_patch(c0)
805    
806        ax.scatter(x2, y2,
807                   label=labelr, 
808                   color='red', 
809                   marker='x', lw=1, s=60)
810        c1 = plt.Circle((x2, y2), r2, 
811                        color='red', 
812                        fill=False, 
813                        label='refined center', 
814                        lw=1)
815        ax.add_patch(c1)
816    
817        ax.legend(loc='upper left', frameon=False, 
818                  handler_map={Circle: HandlerCircle()}, 
819                  bbox_to_anchor=(.98, 1.01), 
820                  bbox_transform=ax.transAxes)
821    
822        # Remove axes (= tick and ticklabels) around the diffractogram
823        ax.axis('off')
824        
825        # Plot only the central square region if requested
826        if csquare is not None:
827            ax.set_xlim(xmin, xmax)
828            ax.set_ylim(ymin, ymax)
829        
830        # Save the result to output file if requested
831        if out_file is not None:
832            fig.savefig(out_file, dpi=out_dpi)
833        
834        # Show the plot on screen
835        plt.show(block=False)
836
837
838    def ellipse_distortion(self, img, show=True, method=None):
839        """
840        Corrects elliptical distortion in an image by transforming 4 distorted 
841        points (which should ideally lie on a circle) to lie on a true circle.
842    
843        Parameters
844        ----------
845        img : np.ndarray
846            Input image (2D numpy array) containing an elliptical diffraction 
847            pattern.
848        
849        show : bool, optional
850            If True, displays the original and corrected images. 
851            Default is True.
852        
853        method : str, optional
854            Point selection method: 'manual' or 'auto'.
855            - 'manual': User clicks four points on the image.
856            - 'auto': Automatically detects the four brightest Bragg spots 
857              (not yet implemented).
858    
859        Returns
860        -------
861        corrected : np.ndarray
862            The distortion-corrected image.
863        """
864            
865        # Helper function
866        def refine_to_local_max(img, pt, window=9):
867            """
868            Refine a point to the local maximum intensity within a neighborhood.
869        
870            This function searches for the brightest (maximum intensity) pixel
871            within a square window centered around a given point. It is typi-
872            cally used to improve the accuracy of an estimated center by snap-
873            ping it to the nearest local maximum.
874        
875            Parameters
876            ----------
877            img : ndarray
878                2D array (grayscale) in which the local maximum is to be found.
879                
880            pt : array-like of float
881                Initial (x, y) point coordinates around which the local maximum 
882                is searched.
883                
884            window : int, optional
885                Size of the square window for the local search (default is 9).
886                The actual window will be `window x window` pixels, 
887                centered at `pt`.
888        
889            Returns
890            -------
891            refined_pt : ndarray of float
892                Refined point coordinates [x, y] corresponding to the brightest 
893                pixel in the local window.
894        
895            Notes
896            -----
897            - If the window overlaps the image boundaries, it is clipped 
898              appropriately.
899            - If the window is completely outside the image, the original point 
900              is returned.
901            - Assumption : `img` uses (row, column) = (y, x) indexing.
902            """
903            x, y = int(round(pt[0])), int(round(pt[1]))
904            r = window // 2
905            x_min, x_max = max(0, x - r), min(img.shape[1], x + r + 1)
906            y_min, y_max = max(0, y - r), min(img.shape[0], y + r + 1)
907    
908            local = img[y_min:y_max, x_min:x_max]
909            if local.size == 0:
910                return np.array([x, y], dtype=np.float32)
911    
912            dy, dx = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(local), local.shape)
913            refined_x = x_min + dx
914            refined_y = y_min + dy
915            return np.array([refined_x, refined_y], dtype=np.float32)
916        
917        # Elliptical correction workflow --------------------------------------
918        h, w = img.shape
919    
920        if method != "manual":
921            print("Only user-assisted ('manual') correction available.")
922            method = "manual"
923    
924        if method == 'manual':
925            # Manual point selection
926            plt.imshow(img, cmap=self.cmap)
927            plt.title("Click 4 distorted points (in circular order)")
928            raw_pts = np.array(plt.ginput(4, timeout=-1), dtype=np.float32)
929            plt.close()
930    
931            # Refine each point to local max
932            distorted_pts = np.array([
933                refine_to_local_max(img, pt, window=9) for pt in raw_pts
934            ], dtype=np.float32)
935    
936        # Compute center and average radius
937        center = np.mean(distorted_pts, axis=0)
938        radii = np.linalg.norm(distorted_pts - center, axis=1)
939        avg_radius = np.mean(radii)
940    
941        # Target points evenly on circle
942        angles = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, 5)[:-1]
943        circle_pts = np.stack([
944            center[0] + avg_radius * np.cos(angles),
945            center[1] + avg_radius * np.sin(angles)
946        ], axis=1).astype(np.float32)
947    
948        # Perspective transform
949        H = cv2.getPerspectiveTransform(distorted_pts, circle_pts)
950        
951        # Make output square by padding the image to max_dim x max_dim
952        max_dim = max(h, w)
953        
954        # Compute offset to center the original image content in the square 
955        x_offset = (max_dim - w) // 2
956        y_offset = (max_dim - h) // 2
957        
958        # Create a translation matrix to shift image content to center
959        T = np.array([
960            [1, 0, x_offset],
961            [0, 1, y_offset],
962            [0, 0, 1]
963        ], dtype=np.float32)
964        
965        # Combine the original homography with the translation
966        H_total = T @ H  # Matrix multiplication
967        
968        # Apply the combined transformation
969        corrected = cv2.warpPerspective(
970            img, H_total, (max_dim, max_dim),
971            borderMode=cv2.BORDER_CONSTANT,
972            borderValue=0
973        )
974
975        # Show results
976        if show:
977            plt.figure(figsize=(12, 5))
978            plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
979            plt.title("Original with refined points")
980            plt.imshow(img, cmap=self.cmap)
981            plt.scatter(*distorted_pts.T, color='cyan', s=40)
982    
983            plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)
984            plt.title("Corrected image")
985            plt.imshow(corrected, cmap=self.cmap)
986            plt.show()
987    
988        return corrected

CenterLocator object : determine and refine the center of a 2D electron diffraction pattern (diffractogram)

This class detects the center of diffraction patterns. It offers several automatic or manual methods and optionally refines the center position.

Parameters
  • input_image (str, path, or numpy.ndarray): The input 2D diffraction image, either a file path or a NumPy array.
  • determination (str or None, optional, default=None): Method used for the initial center determination. Options include:
    • 'manual': Manual detection = interactive plot where the user selects 3 points defining a diffraction ring with a mouse.
    • 'intensity' : Auto-detection = the intensity center from the central region.
    • 'curvefit': Automatic detection = fit the intensity center from the central region using pseudo-Voigt profile.
    • 'hough' : Automatic detection using Hough transform to find center of ring-like structures.
    • 'phase' : Automatic detection using phase correlation to find the symmetry center.
    • 'ccorr' : Automatic detection using cross-correlation to find the symmetry center.
    • None : Skip the center determination; it is supposed that the center coordinates will be read from in_file argument - see below.
  • refinement (str or None, optional, default=None): Method used for refining the initially detected center. Options include:
    • 'manual': Manual fine-tuning of the center along the selected diffraction ring.
    • 'sum' : Automatic refinement by maximizing the intensity sum the selected diffraction ring.
    • 'var': Automatic refinement by minimizing intensity variance the selected diffraction ring.
  • rtype (int, default=1): How to determine a radius of a difraction ring for center refinement. In powder diffractograms, the diffraction rings are clearly defined. In spotty diffractograms, the diffraction ring is an fictive ring connecting at least three diffraction spots. Options include:
    • 0 : Peak matching method (fast and simple, but failing for non-powders, historical).
    • 1 : Radial distribution method (slower but more universal, new default).
  • in_file (str or None, optional, default=None): Path to a file from which the (previously saved) center coordinates will be loaded.
  • out_file (str or None, optional, default=None): Path to a file where the determined center coordinates will be saved.
  • sobel (bool, optional, default=False): If True, apply Sobel filter to the image before processing.
  • heq (bool or None, optional, default=False): If True, apply histogram equalization internally (display unchanged).
  • icut (float or None, optional, default=None): Cut-off intensity level for processing the image.
  • cmap (str, optional, default='gray'): Matplotlib colormap name used for displaying the image.
  • csquare (int, optional, default=50): Size (in pixels) of the central square used for initial center search.
  • cintensity (float, optional, default=0.8): Threshold intensity for finding the intensity center. Pixels with a (relative) intensity lower than cintensity are ignored.
  • verbose (int, optional, default=0): Verbosity level for printing messages during processing:
    • 0 : Silent mode no messages are printed.
    • 1 : Show help messages during manual refinement only.
    • 2 : Full verbose mode print all messages and debug information.
    • 3 : Progress mode print brief status updates during time-consuming processing.
  • print_sums (bool, optional, default=False): If True, print intensity sums after each adjustment (in manual modes).
  • final_print (bool, optional, default=True): If True, print final coordinates to stdout.
  • live_plot (bool, optional, default=True): If True, show live visualization of some processes if available.
Returns
  • None: The result is stored in the instance variables:
    • (x1, y1) for the initially determined center
    • (x2, y2) for the refined center (if refinement is applied)
Technical notes
  • The class automatically initializes and uses two internal components: CenterDetermination and CenterRefinement.
  • These internal processes are hidden from the user but can be accessed directly if needed.
Examples
>>> import ediff as ed
>>>
>>> locator = ed.center.CenterLocator(
>>>    input_image   = '.r/path/to/your/data.png',   
>>>    determination = 'manual',           
>>>    refinement    = 'sum',
>>>    final_print   = True)
def output(self): 
405    def output(self):
406        """
407        Return the final results of center determination and refinement. 
408        
409        Returns
410        -------
411        x1 : float
412            x-coordinate of the center determined by the *determination* method.
413            
414        y1 : float
415            y-coordinate of the center determined by the *determination* method.
416        
417        x2 : float
418            x-coordinate of the center after *refinement*, or same as x1 if no 
419            refinement was used.
420        
421        y2 : float
422            y-coordinate of the center after *refinement*, or same as y1 if no 
423            refinement was used.
424
425            
426        Notes
427        -----
428        - The function always returns four values: (x1, y1, x2, y2).
429        - If no refinement method was used (`refinement=None`), then (x2, y2) 
430          will be equal to (x1, y1).
431        - All values are rounded to one decimal place before returning.
432        - Coordinates are internally converted to float to ensure consistency 
433          in output.
434        """
435        
436        # (1) refinement=None -------------------------------------------------
437        if self.center2.ret == 1:
438            # Convert to float
439            if type(self.x1) != float:
440                self.x1, self.y1, self.x2, self.y2 = \
441                    [float(value) for value in (self.x1, self.y1, 
442                                                self.x2, self.y2)]
443                    
444        # (2) refinement!=None ------------------------------------------------
445        else:
446            # Convert to float
447            if type(self.x1) != float:
448                self.x1, self.y1 = \
449                    [float(value) for value in (self.x1,self.y1)]
450            # Define x2,y2 = x1,y1
451            self.x2 = self.x1
452            self.y2 = self.y1
453            
454        # (3) Return (rounded) values of center coordinates -------------------
455        return (np.round(self.x1,1), np.round(self.y1,1), 
456                np.round(self.x2,1), np.round(self.y2,1))

Return the final results of center determination and refinement.

Returns
  • x1 (float): x-coordinate of the center determined by the determination method.
  • y1 (float): y-coordinate of the center determined by the determination method.
  • x2 (float): x-coordinate of the center after refinement, or same as x1 if no refinement was used.
  • y2 (float): y-coordinate of the center after refinement, or same as y1 if no refinement was used.
Notes
  • The function always returns four values: (x1, y1, x2, y2).
  • If no refinement method was used (refinement=None), then (x2, y2) will be equal to (x1, y1).
  • All values are rounded to one decimal place before returning.
  • Coordinates are internally converted to float to ensure consistency in output.
def save_results(self): 
459    def save_results(self):
460        '''
461        Save the determined and refined center coordinates to a file.
462    
463        This method writes the coordinates (x1, y1) from the *determination*
464        step and (x2, y2) from the *refinement* step to a file specified by the 
465        `out_file` attribute.
466    
467        - If the file already exists, the results are appended to the end.
468        - If the file does not exist, it is created and the results are written.
469        - Coordinates are formatted to four decimal places for clarity.
470        
471        
472        Parameters
473        ----------
474        None
475        
476        Returns
477        -------
478        None
479        
480        Notes
481        -----
482        - If `self.out_file` is None, the method does nothing.
483        - The results are written in the format:
484            x1: <value>, y1: <value>
485            x2: <value>, y2: <value>
486        - This method does not raise an error if the path is invalid;
487          ensure `out_file` is a valid writable path.
488        '''
489        
490        if self.out_file is not None:
491            # Check if the specified file exists
492            if os.path.isfile(self.out_file):
493                # Append results to in_file
494                with open(self.out_file, 'a') as f:  # Open in append mode
495                    f.write(f"x1: {self.x1:.4f}, y1: {self.y1:.4f}\n")
496                    f.write(f"x2: {self.x2:.4f}, y2: {self.y2:.4f}\n")
497            else:
498                # If the file does not exist, create it and write results
499                with open(self.out_file, 'w') as f:  # Open in write mode
500                    f.write(f"x1: {self.x1:.4f}, y1: {self.y1:.4f}\n")
501                    f.write(f"x2: {self.x2:.4f}, y2: {self.y2:.4f}\n")

Save the determined and refined center coordinates to a file.

This method writes the coordinates (x1, y1) from the determination step and (x2, y2) from the refinement step to a file specified by the out_file attribute.

  • If the file already exists, the results are appended to the end.
  • If the file does not exist, it is created and the results are written.
  • Coordinates are formatted to four decimal places for clarity.
Parameters
  • None
Returns
  • None
Notes
  • If self.out_file is None, the method does nothing.
  • The results are written in the format: x1: , y1: x2: , y2:
  • This method does not raise an error if the path is invalid; ensure out_file is a valid writable path.
def load_results(self, path=None): 
504    def load_results(self, path=None):
505        """
506        Load center coordinates from a results file.
507    
508        This method reads a text file (defaulting to `self.in_file` or
509        a provided `path`) containing previously saved center coordinates.
510        It extracts coordinate pairs (x1, y1) from the determination step and
511        (x2, y2) from the refinement step. All sets of values are stored
512        internally, with the most recent values assigned to instance variables 
513        `self.x1`, `self.y1`, `self.x2`, and `self.y2`.
514    
515        Parameters
516        ----------
517        path : str, optional
518            Path to the results file. 
519            If not provided, the method uses `self.in_file`.
520    
521        Returns
522        -------
523        tuple or None
524            If `path` is provided and successfully loaded:
525                (x1_values, y1_values) : Lists of all loaded x1 and y1 values.
526            If loading fails:
527                None
528    
529        Notes
530        -----
531        - The file is expected to contain lines in the following format:
532            x1: <value>, y1: <value>
533            x2: <value>, y2: <value>
534        - Multiple coordinate entries can be loaded; the last set is stored in
535          the instance variables for easy access.
536        - If the file doesn't exist or is unreadable, a warning is printed and
537          the function returns None.
538        """      
539        
540        if path is not None:
541            self.in_file = path
542            
543        if self.in_file is not None and os.path.isfile(self.in_file):
544            with open(self.in_file, 'r') as f:
545                lines = f.readlines()
546                
547                # Initialize lists to hold multiple values
548                x1_values = []
549                y1_values = []
550                x2_values = []
551                y2_values = []
552    
553                for line in lines:
554                    # Strip and split each line to get the coordinates
555                    parts = line.strip().split(',')
556                    if len(parts) == 2:
557                        # Extract x1 and y1 or x2 and y2 based on line content
558                        if 'x1' in parts[0]:
559                            x1 = float(parts[0].split(':')[1].strip())
560                            y1 = float(parts[1].split(':')[1].strip())
561                            x1_values.append(x1)
562                            y1_values.append(y1)
563                        elif 'x2' in parts[0]:
564                            x2 = float(parts[0].split(':')[1].strip())
565                            y2 = float(parts[1].split(':')[1].strip())
566                            x2_values.append(x2)
567                            y2_values.append(y2)
568    
569                # Store the last set of values as instance variables 
570                self.x1 = x1_values
571                self.y1 = y1_values
572                self.x2 = x2_values
573                self.y2 = y2_values
574    
575                # Store the last loaded values:
576                if x1_values and y1_values and x2_values and y2_values:
577                    self.x1 = x1_values[-1]
578                    self.y1 = y1_values[-1]
579                    self.x2 = x2_values[-1]
580                    self.y2 = y2_values[-1]
581                    
582                if path is not None:
583                    return x1_values, y1_values
584        else:
585            print("Error reading text file with center coordinates!")
586            return

Load center coordinates from a results file.

This method reads a text file (defaulting to self.in_file or a provided path) containing previously saved center coordinates. It extracts coordinate pairs (x1, y1) from the determination step and (x2, y2) from the refinement step. All sets of values are stored internally, with the most recent values assigned to instance variables self.x1, self.y1, self.x2, and self.y2.

Parameters
  • path (str, optional): Path to the results file. If not provided, the method uses self.in_file.
Returns
  • tuple or None: If path is provided and successfully loaded: (x1_values, y1_values) : Lists of all loaded x1 and y1 values. If loading fails: None
Notes
  • The file is expected to contain lines in the following format: x1: , y1: x2: , y2:
  • Multiple coordinate entries can be loaded; the last set is stored in the instance variables for easy access.
  • If the file doesn't exist or is unreadable, a warning is printed and the function returns None.
def get_circle_pixels(self, image, cx, cy, r, num_points=360): 
589    def get_circle_pixels(self, image, cx, cy, r, num_points=360):
590        """
591        Extract pixel values along a circular path in the image.
592    
593        Parameters
594        ----------
595        image : np.ndarray
596            2D grayscale image from which pixel values are extracted.
597            
598        cx : float
599            X-coordinate (row) of the circle center.
600        
601        cy : float
602            Y-coordinate (column) of the circle center.
603        
604        r : float
605            Radius of the circle.
606        
607        num_points : int, optional
608            Number of points to sample along the circular path. Default is 360.
609    
610        Returns
611        -------
612        pixels : np.ndarray
613            1D array of pixel intensity values sampled along the circular path.
614        """
615        points = np.linspace(0, 2 * np.pi, num_points)
616        
617        # Generate coordinates for the circle
618        x = cx + r * np.cos(points)
619        y = cy + r * np.sin(points)
620        
621        # Use map_coordinates for accurate sub-pixel interpolation
622        coords = np.vstack((y, x))
623        
624        # 'order=1' is linear interpolation
625        pixels = map_coordinates(image, 
626                                 coords, 
627                                 order=1, 
628                                 mode='constant', 
629                                 cval=0.0)
630        
631        # Return pixels
632        return pixels

Extract pixel values along a circular path in the image.

Parameters
  • image (np.ndarray): 2D grayscale image from which pixel values are extracted.
  • cx (float): X-coordinate (row) of the circle center.
  • cy (float): Y-coordinate (column) of the circle center.
  • r (float): Radius of the circle.
  • num_points (int, optional): Number of points to sample along the circular path. Default is 360.
Returns
  • pixels (np.ndarray): 1D array of pixel intensity values sampled along the circular path.
def intensity_sum(self, im, cx, cy, r): 
635    def intensity_sum(self, im, cx, cy, r):
636        """
637        Compute the sum of pixel intensities along a circular path.
638    
639        This function extracts pixel values along a circle defined by the 
640        given center coordinates (cx, cy) and radius r, then returns 
641        the sum of these intensities.
642    
643        Parameters
644        ----------
645        im : np.ndarray
646            2D grayscale image from which the intensities are extracted.
647        
648        cx : float
649            X-coordinate (row) of the circle center.
650        
651        cy : float
652            Y-coordinate (column) of the circle center.
653        
654        r : float
655            Radius of the circle.
656    
657        Returns
658        -------
659        float
660            Sum of pixel intensities along the circular path.
661        """
662        # Get pixel intensities
663        pixels = self.get_circle_pixels(im, cx, cy, r)
664        
665        # Sum pixel intensities
666        return np.sum(pixels)

Compute the sum of pixel intensities along a circular path.

This function extracts pixel values along a circle defined by the given center coordinates (cx, cy) and radius r, then returns the sum of these intensities.

Parameters
  • im (np.ndarray): 2D grayscale image from which the intensities are extracted.
  • cx (float): X-coordinate (row) of the circle center.
  • cy (float): Y-coordinate (column) of the circle center.
  • r (float): Radius of the circle.
Returns
  • float: Sum of pixel intensities along the circular path.
def intensity_variance(self, image, px, py, pr): 
669    def intensity_variance(self, image, px, py, pr):
670        ''' 
671        Variance of intensity values of pixels of a diffraction pattern.
672
673        Parameters
674        ----------
675        image : array of uint8
676            image from which the diffraction pattern has been detected.
677        
678        px : float64
679            x-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
680        
681        py : float64
682            y-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
683        
684        pr : float64
685            radius of the diffraction pattern.
686
687        Returns
688        -------
689        s : float64
690            intensity variance
691
692        '''
693        # Extract pixels on the circle border
694        pxc, pyc = self.get_circle_pixels(px, py, pr)
695        pxc = np.array(pxc, dtype=int)
696        pyc = np.array(pyc, dtype=int)
697        
698        # Calculate sum using the filtered values
699        s = np.var(image[pxc, pyc])
700        return s

Variance of intensity values of pixels of a diffraction pattern.

Parameters
  • image (array of uint8): image from which the diffraction pattern has been detected.
  • px (float64): x-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
  • py (float64): y-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
  • pr (float64): radius of the diffraction pattern.
Returns
  • s (float64): intensity variance
def convert_coords(self, x, y): 
703    def convert_coords(self, x, y):
704        """
705        Convert coordinates between numpy and matplotlib systems.
706
707        Parameters
708        ----------
709        x : int or float
710            The x-coordinate in the numpy (column index) format.
711        
712        y : int or float
713            The y-coordinate in the numpy (row index) format.
714
715        Returns
716        -------
717        tuple of (int or float, int or float)
718            The converted coordinates in matplotlib format, where:
719            - First element corresponds to y (new x in matplotlib).
720            - Second element corresponds to x (new y in matplotlib).
721        """
722        return y, x

Convert coordinates between numpy and matplotlib systems.

Parameters
  • x (int or float): The x-coordinate in the numpy (column index) format.
  • y (int or float): The y-coordinate in the numpy (row index) format.
Returns
  • tuple of (int or float, int or float): The converted coordinates in matplotlib format, where:
    • First element corresponds to y (new x in matplotlib).
    • Second element corresponds to x (new y in matplotlib).
def visualize_results(self, csquare=None, out_file=None, out_dpi=200): 
725    def visualize_results(self, csquare=None, out_file=None, out_dpi=200):
726        '''
727        Visualize diffractogram and its center after
728        center determination + refinement.
729    
730        Parameters
731        ----------
732        csquare : int, optional, default is None
733            If csquare argument is given,
734            only the central square of the diffractogram will be plotted;
735            the size of the central square will be equal to csquare argument.
736        
737        out_file : str, optional, default is None
738            If out_file is given,
739            save the final plot to image named *out_file*.
740        
741        out_dpi : int, optional, default is 200
742            DPI of the output image file;
743            this parameter is relevant only if out_file is given.
744    
745        Returns
746        -------
747        None
748            The output is the image of the diffractogram
749            showing also the central coordinates and refinement ring.
750        '''
751        
752        # (0) Collect center coordinates and radii ----------------------------
753        x1, y1 = (self.x1, self.y1)
754        r1 = self.center1.r
755
756        x2, y2 = (self.x2, self.y2)
757        r2 = self.center2.rr
758
759        # (1) Prepare the image of the diffractogram --------------------------
760        image = np.copy(self.to_refine)
761        if self.icut is not None:
762            im = np.where(image > self.icut, self.icut, image)
763        else:
764            im = np.copy(image)
765            
766        # (2) Calculate intensity sum or intensity variance -------------------
767        if self.refinement == "var":
768            dvar = self.intensity_variance(image, x1, y1, r1)
769            rvar = self.intensity_variance(image, x2, y2, r2)
770            labeld = f'd-center: [{x1:.1f}, {y1:.1f}]\nint-var: {dvar:.1f}'
771            labelr = f'r-center: [{x2:.1f}, {y2:.1f}]\nint-var: {rvar:.1f}'
772        else:
773            dsum = self.intensity_sum(image, x1, y1, r1)
774            rsum = self.intensity_sum(image, x2, y2, r2)
775            labeld = f'd-center: [{x1:.1f}, {y1:.1f}]\nint-sum: {dsum:.1f}'
776            labelr = f'r-center: [{x2:.1f}, {y2:.1f}]\nint-sum: {rsum:.1f}'
777            
778        # (3) Calculate xy-limits if we want to see only the central square ---
779        if csquare is not None:
780            xmin, xmax = (0, image.shape[0])
781            ymin, ymax = (0, image.shape[1])
782            edge = (xmax - csquare) // 2
783            xmin += edge
784            xmax -= edge
785            ymin += edge
786            ymax -= edge
787    
788        # (4) Final plot: show the diffractogram + refinement results ---------
789        fig, ax = plt.subplots(layout='constrained')
790        ax.imshow(im, cmap=self.cmap)
791    
792        ax.set_title(f'Center :: {self.determination}/{self.refinement}')
793    
794        ax.scatter(x1, y1, 
795                   label=labeld, 
796                   color='gold', 
797                   marker='x', 
798                   s=60, lw=1)
799        c0 = plt.Circle((x1, y1), r1, 
800                        color='gold', 
801                        fill=False, 
802                        label='detected center', 
803                        lw=1)
804        ax.add_patch(c0)
805    
806        ax.scatter(x2, y2,
807                   label=labelr, 
808                   color='red', 
809                   marker='x', lw=1, s=60)
810        c1 = plt.Circle((x2, y2), r2, 
811                        color='red',
