2605            #    and second points (x[0], y[0]) and (x[1], y[1]).
2606            # s: the twice the signed area of the triangle formed by 3 points
2607            
2608        c = (x[0]-x[1])**2 + (y[0]-y[1])**2
2609        a = (x[1]-x[2])**2 + (y[1]-y[2])**2
2610        b = (x[2]-x[0])**2 + (y[2]-y[0])**2
2611        s = 2*(a*b + b*c + c*a) - (a*a + b*b + c*c) 
2612        
2613        # coordinates of the center
2614        self.x = (a*(b+c-a)*x[0] + b*(c+a-b)*x[1] + c*(a+b-c)*x[2]) / s
2615        self.y = (a*(b+c-a)*y[0] + b*(c+a-b)*y[1] + c*(a+b-c)*y[2]) / s 
2616        
2617        # radius
2618        ar = a**0.5
2619        br = b**0.5
2620        cr = c**0.5 
2621        self.r = ar*br*cr/((ar+br+cr)*(-ar+br+cr)*(ar-br+cr)*(ar+br-cr))**0.5
2622        
2623        # # Print results
2624        # if self.parent.verbose:
2625        #     print("CenterEstimator :: manual center detection")
2626        #     print(f"Center coordinates: {self.x:.2f} {self.y:.2f}")
2627                    
2628        if plot_results==1:
2629            # Create and manage the figure
2630            fig, ax = plt.subplots()
2631            manager = plt.get_current_fig_manager()
2632            manager.window.showMaximized()
2633            ax.imshow(self.parent.image, cmap = self.parent.cmap,
2634                      origin="upper")
2635            
2636            # Plot center and points
2637            center, = plt.plot(self.x, self.y, 
2638                     'rx', 
2639                     label='Center', 
2640                     markersize=12)
2641            plt.scatter(x,y, 
2642                        marker='x', 
2643                        color='palevioletred', 
2644                        label = 'Circle points')
2645            plt.title('Circle found using 3 manually detected points')
2646            
2647            # Circle visualization
2648            circle = plt.Circle((self.x,self.y), 
2649                                self.r, 
2650                                color='palevioletred', 
2651                                fill=False,
2652                                label = 'pattern')
2653            ax.add_artist(circle)
2654            
2655            # Set the aspect ratio to equal to have a circular shape
2656            plt.axis('equal')
2657            
2658            plt.legend(loc='lower center', 
2659                       ncol=2, 
2660                       bbox_to_anchor=(0.5,-0.1), 
2661                       mode='expand', 
2662                       frameon=False)
2663            plt.axis('off')
2664            plt.tight_layout()
2665            plt.show(block=False)
2666
2667        
2668        self.center = (self.x, self.y)
2669        self.circle = plt.Circle((self.x,self.y),self.r)
2670        
2671
2672        return self.x, self.y, self.r, self.center, self.circle
2673
2674
2675    def get_radius(
2676            self, rtype:int, im:np.ndarray, x:float, y:float, disp:bool=False) -> float:
2677        """
2678        Calculate the radius of a circle based on intensity profiles along 
2679        horizontal and vertical axes.
2680    
2681        Parameters
2682        ----------
2683        rtype : integer
2684            Method for radius calculation. Default is 0.
2685            - rtype=0 : peaks matching method
2686            - rtype=1 : radial distribution method
2687            
2688        im : np.ndarray
2689            The 2D image array containing the circle. 
2690            
2691        x : float
2692            The x-coordinate of the circle's center.
2693            
2694        y : float
2695            The y-coordinate of the circle's center.
2696            
2697        disp : bool, optional
2698            If True, visualizes the detected intensity profiles and peaks 
2699            (default is False).
2700    
2701        Returns
2702        -------
2703        float
2704            The estimated radius of the circle. Defaults to 100 if no valid 
2705            radius is detected.
2706        """
2707        # Helper function -----------------------------------------------------
2708        def match_peaks(arr):
2709            """
2710            Find the most similar values across the left and right halves of 
2711            an array, excluding the global maximum.
2712        
2713            This function is typically used for analyzing symmetric patterns 
2714            such as diffraction profiles or intensity histograms. It identifies 
2715            the most similar pair of peaks on either side of the central maximum, 
2716            which is excluded from the comparison.
2717        
2718            Special case:
2719            - If the array contains exactly two elements, it assumes they form 
2720              the best pair and returns their indices directly.
2721            - If one half is empty after removing the central peak,
2722              it returns (None, None).
2723        
2724            Parameters
2725            ----------
2726            arr : np.ndarray or list of float
2727                1D array of values (intensity profile) where symmetric peak
2728                positions are to be matched.
2729        
2730            Returns
2731            -------
2732            best_pair : tuple[int or None, int or None]
2733                Indices of the two most similar values, one from each half of 
2734                the array. Returns (None, None) if no valid pair is found.
2735        
2736            Notes
2737            -----
2738            - The function assumes the most prominent peak (maximum value) lies 
2739              at or near the center and represents the central feature.
2740            - The left and right halves are compared pairwise, and the closest 
2741              match in absolute value difference is returned.
2742            - This is useful for refining radial symmetry or finding symmetric 
2743              ring peaks.
2744            """
2745            if len(arr) < 2:  # Not enough values to compare
2746                if self.parent.verbose==2:
2747                    print("Not enough values to find similar pairs.")
2748                return None, None
2749    
2750            # Special case: if there are exactly 2 peaks, return them
2751            if len(arr) == 2:
2752                if self.parent.verbose==2:
2753                    print("Exactly two peaks detected. Returning them as the best pair.")
2754                return 0, 1
2755    
2756            # Find the index of the highest value
2757            center_idx = np.argmax(arr)
2758    
2759            # Split into left and right halves, excluding the highest value
2760            left = arr[:center_idx]
2761            right = arr[center_idx + 1:]
2762            left_indices = np.arange(center_idx)
2763            right_indices = np.arange(center_idx + 1, len(arr))
2764    
2765            if len(left) == 0 or len(right) == 0:  # Check for empty halves
2766                if self.parent.verbose==2:
2767                    print("One of the halves is empty.")
2768                return None, None
2769    
2770            # Initialize variables for tracking the smallest difference
2771            smallest_diff = np.inf
2772            best_pair = (None, None)
2773    
2774            # Compare each value in the left with every value in the right
2775            for i, l_val in enumerate(left):
2776                for j, r_val in enumerate(right):
2777                    diff = abs(l_val - r_val)
2778                    if diff < smallest_diff:
2779                        smallest_diff = diff
2780                        best_pair = (left_indices[i], right_indices[j])
2781    
2782            return best_pair
2783        
2784        # Peak matching method ------------------------------------------------
2785        if rtype == 0:
2786            self.xpeaks, self.ypeaks = None, None
2787            self.xyvals, self.yyvals = None, None
2788        
2789            x_line = im[int(x), :]
2790            y_line = im[:, int(y)]
2791        
2792            # Define threshold for peak detection
2793            x_thr = 0.5 * max(x_line)
2794            y_thr = 0.5 * max(y_line)
2795        
2796            # Find peaks with dynamic height thresholds
2797            self.xpeaks, _ = find_peaks(x_line, 
2798                                        height=x_thr, 
2799                                        prominence=1, 
2800                                        distance=30)
2801            self.xyvals = x_line[self.xpeaks]
2802            self.ypeaks, _ = find_peaks(y_line, 
2803                                        height=y_thr, 
2804                                        prominence=1, 
2805                                        distance=30)
2806            self.yyvals = y_line[self.ypeaks]
2807        
2808            # Define half the length of the image
2809            half_length_x = x_line.shape[0] / 2
2810            half_length_y = y_line.shape[0] / 2
2811        
2812            # Check the additional condition for xpeaks
2813            if len(self.xpeaks) == 2 and (
2814                (self.xpeaks[0]<half_length_x and self.xpeaks[1]<half_length_x) or
2815                (self.xpeaks[0]>half_length_x and self.xpeaks[1]>half_length_x)):
2816                if self.parent.verbose==2:
2817                    print("xpeaks condition met: Both peaks are on the same side of the center.")
2818                self.pairX = None
2819            else:
2820                self.pairX = match_peaks(self.xyvals)
2821        
2822            # Check the additional condition for ypeaks
2823            if len(self.ypeaks) == 2 and (
2824                (self.ypeaks[0]<half_length_y and self.ypeaks[1]<half_length_y) or
2825                (self.ypeaks[0]>half_length_y and self.ypeaks[1]>half_length_y)):
2826                if self.parent.verbose==2:
2827                    print("ypeaks condition met: Both peaks are on the same side of the center.")
2828                self.pairY = None
2829            else:
2830                self.pairY = match_peaks(self.yyvals)
2831        
2832            # Determine radius based on available pairs
2833            if self.pairX is None or None in self.pairX:
2834                rx_x = None
2835            else:
2836                x1 = self.xpeaks[self.pairX[0]]
2837                x2 = self.xpeaks[self.pairX[1]]
2838                rx_x = abs(x1 - x2) / 2
2839        
2840            if self.pairY is None or None in self.pairY:
2841                rx_y = None
2842            else:
2843                y1 = self.ypeaks[self.pairY[0]]
2844                y2 = self.ypeaks[self.pairY[1]]
2845                rx_y = abs(y1 - y2) / 2
2846        
2847            if rx_x is not None and rx_y is not None:
2848                rx = np.mean([rx_x, rx_y])
2849            elif rx_x is not None:
2850                rx = rx_x
2851            elif rx_y is not None:
2852                rx = rx_y
2853            else:
2854                if self.parent.verbose==2:
2855                    print("No valid pairs detected for radius calculation.")
2856                return 100  # Default radius or error handling
2857        
2858            if disp:
2859                # Plot xline with peaks
2860                plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
2861        
2862                # Plot for xline
2863                plt.subplot(2, 1, 1)
2864                plt.plot(x_line, label='xline')
2865                plt.plot(self.xpeaks, self.xyvals, "ro", label='Peaks')
2866                plt.title('Peaks in xline')
2867                plt.xlabel('Index')
2868                plt.ylabel('Value')
2869                plt.legend()
2870        
2871                # Plot for yline
2872                plt.subplot(2, 1, 2)
2873                plt.plot(y_line, label='yline')
2874                plt.plot(self.ypeaks, self.yyvals, "ro", label='Peaks')  
2875                plt.title('Peaks in yline')
2876                plt.xlabel('Index')
2877                plt.ylabel('Value')
2878                plt.legend()
2879        
2880                plt.tight_layout()
2881                plt.show()
2882        
2883        # Radial distribution method ------------------------------------------
2884        elif rtype == 1:
2885            profile = ediff.radial.calc_radial_distribution(
2886                im, 
2887                center=(x, y)
2888                )
2889            p0, p1 = profile
2890            idx_max = np.argmax(p1[50:]) + 50
2891            rx = p0[idx_max]
2892            max_val = p1[idx_max]
2893    
2894            if disp:
2895                fig, axs = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(8, 3))
2896                axs[0].imshow(im, cmap=self.parent.cmap)
2897                axs[0].add_patch(
2898                    Circle(
2899                        (y, x), rx, 
2900                        edgecolor='red', 
2901                        fill=False, 
2902                        linewidth=2))
2903                axs[0].scatter(y, x, color="red", marker="x")
2904                axs[0].set_title("Initial Estimate")
2905                axs[0].axis('off')
2906                axs[1].plot(p0, p1)
2907                axs[1].set_ylim(0,max_val+20)
2908                axs[1].axvline(rx, 
2909                               color='red', 
2910                               linestyle='--', 
2911                               label='Initial Radius')
2912                axs[1].set_title("Radial Profile")
2913                axs[1].legend()
2914                plt.tight_layout()
2915                plt.show()
2916        
2917        # Return found radius
2918        return rx
2919
2920
2921    def backend_fft(f):
2922        """
2923        Decorator to enforce the use of PocketFFTBackend when utilizing the 
2924        `scipy.fft` module. This ensures that all FFT computations leverage 
2925        the optimized PocketFFT implementation, improving performance, 
2926        particularly for multi-threaded execution.
2927    
2928        Parameters
2929        ----------
2930        f : callable
2931            The function to be wrapped, ensuring it executes within the 
2932            PocketFFTBackend context.
2933    
2934        Returns
2935        -------
2936        callable
2937            A wrapped function that forces the use of PocketFFTBackend.
2938        """
2939        @wraps(f)
2940        def newf(*args, **kwargs):
2941            with set_backend(PocketFFTBackend):
2942                return f(*args, **kwargs)
2943        return newf
2944    
2945    @backend_fft
2946    def calc_fft(self, fft_function):
2947        """
2948        Computes the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) using the specified function.
2949
2950        This method ensures that the FFT operation is executed using 
2951        the PocketFFTBackend, applying optimized settings for improved efficiency.
2952
2953        Parameters
2954        ----------
2955        fft_function : callable
2956            The FFT function to be applied to the data.
2957
2958        Returns
2959        -------
2960        object
2961            The result of the FFT computation.
2962        """
2963        return fft_function
2964
2965   
2966    def auto_masking(self, im, threshold=0.2, show_mask=False):
2967        """
2968        Automatically generates a binary mask for an image based on intensity 
2969        thresholding.
2970        
2971        This function determines a lower intensity limit by taking a fraction 
2972        (threshold) of the median of the highest intensity values in the image. 
2973        This helps filter out noise while preserving meaningful features, 
2974        avoiding the influence of hot spots.
2975    
2976        Parameters
2977        ----------
2978        im : ndarray
2979            Input grayscale image as a 2D NumPy array.
2980        
2981        threshold : float, optional
2982            A fraction (default is 0.1) of the median of the highest intensity 
2983            values. Pixels with intensity above this computed limit will be 
2984            included in the mask.
2985    
2986        Returns
2987        -------
2988        mask : ndarray
2989            A boolean mask (same shape as `im`), where `True` indicates pixels 
2990            above the threshold and `False` represents background or noise.
2991    
2992        """
2993        # Find the median of the highest intensity value of the image to avoid 
2994        # hot spots (More stable than median scaling)
2995        lower_limit = np.percentile(im, threshold * 100) 
2996        
2997        # Generate a mask
2998        mask = im > lower_limit
2999        
3000        if show_mask:
3001            plt.figure()
3002            plt.imshow(mask)
3003            plt.title("Beam Stopper Masking")
3004            plt.tight_layout()
3005            plt.axis("off")
3006            plt.show()
3007        
3008        return mask
3009
3010        
3011    def visualize_center(self, x: float, y: float, r: float, rd: str) -> None:
3012        '''         
3013        Visualize detected diffraction patterns and mark the center.
3014        
3015        Parameters
3016        ----------
3017        tit : string
3018            name of the method used for circle detection
3019            
3020        x : float64
3021            x-coordinate of the detected center
3022            
3023        y : float64
3024            y-coordinate of the detected center
3025            
3026        r : float64
3027            radius of the detected center
3028        
3029        Returns
3030        -------
3031        None.
3032                            
3033        '''
3034        # Load image
3035        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
3036    
3037        if rd=="d":
3038            tit = "Detected center position"
3039        elif rd=="r":
3040            tit = "Refined center position"
3041        else: 
3042            tit = "Center position"
3043            
3044            
3045        if self.parent.icut is not None:
3046            im = np.where(image > self.parent.icut, self.parent.icut, image)
3047        else:
3048            im = np.copy(image)
3049            
3050        # Create a figure and display the image
3051        fig, ax = plt.subplots()
3052        
3053        # Allow using arrows to move back and forth between view ports
3054        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].append('left')
3055        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].append('right')
3056 
3057        plt.title(tit)
3058        ax.axis('off')
3059
3060        # Plot center point
3061        ax.scatter(x,y,
3062                label= f'center:  [{x:.1f}, {y:.1f}]',
3063                marker='x', color="red", s=60)
3064
3065        plt.legend(loc='upper right')
3066        
3067        # Display the image
3068        ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap, origin="upper")
3069        plt.axis('off')
3070        plt.tight_layout()
3071        plt.show(block=False)

CenterDetermination object - initial detection of a diffractogram center.

This class is responsible for identifying the center coordinates of a 2D diffraction pattern image using various detection methods specified by the user. It initializes with the input image and other parameters that influence the center detection process.

Parameters
  • parent (CenterLocator): Reference to the parent CenterLocator object, allowing access to shared attributes and methods.
  • input_image (str, path, or numpy.array): The input image representing a 2D diffraction pattern, provided as a file path or a NumPy array.
  • determination (str or None, optional, default=None): Method used for the initial center determination. Options include:
    • 'manual' : Manual selection of 3 points on a diffraction ring.
    • 'hough' : Automatic detection using Hough transform.
    • 'intensity': Automatic detection based on the intensity center of the central region.
    • 'phase' : Automatic detection using phase correlation to find the symmetry center.
    • 'ccorr' : Automatic detection using cross-correlation to find the symmetry center.
    • 'curvefit' : Automatic detecting using pseudo-Voigt profile fitting
  • in_file (str or None, optional, default=None): Path to the file from which previously saved coordinates will be loaded.
  • out_file (str or None, optional, default=None): Path to the file where the determined coordinates will be saved.
  • sobel (bool, optional, default=False): If True, apply Sobel filter to the image before processing.
  • heq (bool or None, optional, default=False): If True, apply histogram equalization internally (display unchanged).
  • icut (float or None, optional, default=None): Cut-off intensity level for processing the image.
  • cmap (str, optional, default='gray'): Matplotlib colormap name used for displaying the image.
  • csquare (int, optional, defaul=50): Size (in pixels) of the central square used for initial center search.
  • cintensity (float, optional, default=0.8): Threshold intensity for finding the intensity center. Pixels with a (relative) intensity lower than cintensity are ignored.
  • verbose (bool, optional, default=False): If True, print informational verbose during the detection process.
  • print_sums (bool, optional, default=False): If True, print intensity sums after each adjustment (in manual modes).
Returns
  • None
Notes
  • The class preprocesses the input image and then applies the specified center detection method.
  • The detected center coordinates are stored in instance variables x, y, and r, representing the center's x-coordinate, y-coordinate, and radius, respectively.
def preprocess( self, preInit=0, preHough=0, preManual=0, preVar=0, preSum=0, preInt=0): 
1132    def preprocess(self, preInit=0, preHough=0, preManual=0,
1133                   preVar=0, preSum=0, preInt=0):  
1134        """
1135        Preprocess the input image based on the selected automatic detection 
1136        and refinement methods.
1137    
1138        Parameters
1139        ----------
1140        preInit : bool, optional, default=0
1141            Preprocess the original image using initialization methods such as
1142            histogram equalization (heq) or contrast clipping (icut). This
1143            is used to enhance the input image prior to any detection or
1144            correction.
1145        
1146        preHough : bool, optional, default=0
1147            Perform preprocessing required for Hough transform-based automatic 
1148            detection. This includes edge detection and handling beamstoppers. 
1149    
1150        preManual, preVar, preSum, preInt : bool, optional, default=0
1151            Placeholder flags for future preprocessing needs for manual 
1152            detection and different refinement methods (variance, sum, 
1153            intensity-based). Currently unused.
1154    
1155        Returns
1156        -------
1157        edges : np.ndarray of bool, optional
1158            Edge map obtained using the Canny edge detector, required for Hough
1159            transform. Only returned if `preHough` is True.
1160    
1161        Notes
1162        -----
1163        This function performs different preprocessing steps depending on the
1164        detection/refinement strategy selected. It is modular and supports
1165        optional display of intermediate results if `self.parent.verbose` is True.
1166        """
1167    
1168        # Flags
1169        control_print = 1
1170        
1171        # Load original image
1172        if len(self.parent.image.shape)!=2:
1173            self.parent.image = np.mean(self.parent.image,axis=2)
1174            
1175        image = np.copy(self.parent.image)
1176        
1177        ### After initialization: perform an image enhancement if specified
1178        if preInit == 1:
1179            # Enhance diffraction pattern to make it more visible
1180            if self.parent.heq == 1:
1181                if self.parent.verbose==2:
1182                    print("Histogram equalized.")
1183                image = sk.exposure.equalize_adapthist(image)
1184
1185            self.parent.to_refine = image
1186            return
1187        
1188        ### Hough transform: perform pre-processing necessary for the detection
1189        if preHough == 1:           
1190            if self.parent.heq == 0:
1191                csq = self.central_square(self.parent.to_refine, csquare=80)   
1192                
1193                # Beam stopper present in image
1194                if np.median(csq)<100 and np.median(csq) > 0:
1195                    if self.parent.verbose==2:
1196                        print('Beamstopper removed.')
1197                    max_indices=np.where(self.parent.to_refine>np.median(csq))
1198        
1199                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
1200                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
1201        
1202                    self.parent.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0    
1203                    
1204                    max_indices = \
1205                        np.where(self.parent.to_refine < 0.8*np.median(csq))
1206                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
1207                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
1208        
1209                    self.parent.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0   
1210                    
1211                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1212                    edges = sk.feature.canny(self.parent.to_refine, 
1213                            sigma=0.2, 
1214                            low_threshold=2.5*np.median(self.parent.to_refine), 
1215                            high_threshold=3*np.median(self.parent.to_refine))
1216                    
1217                    # Dilate the edges to connect them
1218                    selem = sk.morphology.disk(5)
1219                    dilated_edges = sk.morphology.dilation(edges, selem)
1220                    
1221                    # Erode the dilated edges
1222                    # to reduce thickness and smooth the contour
1223                    connected_edges=sk.morphology.erosion(dilated_edges,selem)
1224
1225                    if control_print == 1:
1226                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
1227                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.parent.image, origin="upper")
1228                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
1229                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.parent.to_refine, origin="upper")
1230                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
1231                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
1232                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
1233                        ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges, origin="upper")
1234                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
1235                        plt.tight_layout()
1236                        plt.show(block=False)
1237                        
1238                # No beam stopper in image
1239                else:
1240                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1241                    print('No beamstopper.')
1242                    edges = sk.feature.canny(self.to_refine, 
1243                                             sigma=0.2, 
1244                                             low_threshold=80, 
1245                                             high_threshold=100)
1246                    
1247                    # Dilate the edges to connect them
1248                    selem = sk.morphology.disk(10)
1249                    dilated_edges = sk.morphology.dilation(edges, selem)
1250                    
1251                    # Erode the dilated edges
1252                    # to reduce thickness and smooth the contour
1253                    connected_edges=sk.morphology.erosion(dilated_edges,selem)
1254                    connected_edges = sk.morphology.remove_small_objects(
1255                        connected_edges, 
1256                        min_size=100)
1257                    
1258                    if control_print == 1:
1259                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
1260                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
1261                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
1262                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
1263                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
1264                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper",)
1265                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
1266                        ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges,origin="upper")
1267                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
1268                        plt.tight_layout()
1269                        plt.show(block=False)
1270                
1271            elif self.heq == 1: 
1272                # Central square extraction
1273                csq = self.central_square(self.to_refine, csquare=80)   
1274
1275                # Beam stopper present in image
1276                if 0.4 <= np.median(csq) <= 0.6:
1277                    
1278                    max_indices = \
1279                        np.where(self.to_refine > 2*np.median(self.to_refine))
1280    
1281                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
1282                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
1283    
1284                    self.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0 
1285                                                     
1286                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1287                    edges = sk.feature.canny(
1288                        self.to_refine, 
1289                        sigma=0.2, 
1290                        low_threshold=1.5*np.median(self.to_refine), 
1291                        high_threshold=3*np.median(self.to_refine))
1292
1293                    
1294                    if control_print == 1:
1295                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
1296                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
1297                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
1298                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
1299                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
1300                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
1301                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
1302                      #  ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges)
1303                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
1304                        plt.tight_layout()
1305                        plt.show(block=False)
1306                    
1307                # No beam stopper in image
1308                else:
1309                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1310                    edges = sk.feature.canny(
1311                        self.to_refine, 
1312                        sigma=0.2, 
1313                        low_threshold=2.5*np.median(self.to_refine), 
1314                        high_threshold=3*np.median(self.to_refine))
1315
1316                    
1317                    if control_print == 1:
1318                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
1319                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
1320                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
1321                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
1322                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
1323                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
1324                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
1325                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
1326                        plt.tight_layout()
1327                        plt.show(block=False)
1328            
1329            return edges

Preprocess the input image based on the selected automatic detection and refinement methods.

Parameters
  • preInit (bool, optional, default=0): Preprocess the original image using initialization methods such as histogram equalization (heq) or contrast clipping (icut). This is used to enhance the input image prior to any detection or correction.
  • preHough (bool, optional, default=0): Perform preprocessing required for Hough transform-based automatic detection. This includes edge detection and handling beamstoppers.
  • preManual, preVar, preSum, preInt (bool, optional, default=0): Placeholder flags for future preprocessing needs for manual detection and different refinement methods (variance, sum, intensity-based). Currently unused.
Returns
  • edges (np.ndarray of bool, optional): Edge map obtained using the Canny edge detector, required for Hough transform. Only returned if preHough is True.
Notes

This function performs different preprocessing steps depending on the detection/refinement strategy selected. It is modular and supports optional display of intermediate results if self.parent.verbose is True.

def sobel_filt(self, image, disp=True): 
1332    def sobel_filt(self, image, disp=True):   
1333        """
1334        The Sobel filter, which is a simple 33 kernel convolved with the image 
1335        which approximates the gradient of intensity in a certain direction. 
1336        Since the Sobel filter is a simple matrix, it can be applied across 
1337        datasets without concern for effects caused by changing user defined 
1338        thresholds, and is much faster and impartial than an iterative method
1339
1340        Parameters
1341        ----------
1342        image : TYPE
1343            DESCRIPTION.
1344        disp : TYPE, optional
1345            DESCRIPTION. The default is False.
1346
1347        Returns
1348        -------
1349        sobel_magnitude : TYPE
1350            DESCRIPTION.
1351
1352        """
1353        # Apply Sobel filter
1354        sobel_x = cv2.Sobel(image, 
1355                            cv2.CV_64F, 
1356                            1, 0, 
1357                            ksize=3)  # Horizontal edges
1358        sobel_y = cv2.Sobel(image, 
1359                            cv2.CV_64F, 
1360                            0, 1,
1361                            ksize=3)  # Vertical edges
1362        
1363        # # Take absolute values to remove negatives
1364        # sobel_x = np.abs(sobel_x)
1365        # sobel_y = np.abs(sobel_y)
1366
1367        
1368        # Compute gradient magnitude
1369        sobel_magnitude = np.sqrt(sobel_x**2 + sobel_y**2)
1370        
1371        # Normalize
1372        sobel_magnitude = \
1373            np.uint8(255 * sobel_magnitude / np.max(sobel_magnitude))  
1374        
1375        if disp:
1376            # Display results
1377            plt.figure(figsize=(12, 4))
1378            plt.subplot(1, 3, 1), 
1379            plt.imshow(sobel_x, cmap='gray'), 
1380            plt.title('Sobel X')
1381            plt.subplot(1, 3, 2),
1382            plt.imshow(sobel_y, cmap='gray'),
1383            plt.title('Sobel Y')
1384            plt.subplot(1, 3, 3), 
1385            plt.imshow(sobel_magnitude, cmap='gray'), 
1386            plt.title('Gradient Magnitude')
1387            plt.show()
1388        
1389        return sobel_magnitude

The Sobel filter, which is a simple 33 kernel convolved with the image which approximates the gradient of intensity in a certain direction. Since the Sobel filter is a simple matrix, it can be applied across datasets without concern for effects caused by changing user defined thresholds, and is much faster and impartial than an iterative method

Parameters
  • image (TYPE): DESCRIPTION.
  • disp (TYPE, optional): DESCRIPTION. The default is False.
Returns
  • sobel_magnitude (TYPE): DESCRIPTION.
def detection_phase(self, normalize_bg=True, sobel=False, disp=False, masking=True): 
1392    def detection_phase(self, normalize_bg=True, sobel=False, 
1393                        disp=False, masking=True):
1394        """
1395        Detects the center of symmetry in a diffraction image using a 
1396        combination of weighted intensity averaging and phase cross-correlation.
1397    
1398        This method performs the following steps:
1399            1. Estimates an initial center using a weighted average of pixel 
1400               intensities.
1401            2. Crops the image to focus on its central region.
1402            3. Optionally normalizes the background to mitigate experimental 
1403               artifacts.
1404            4. Computes a refined center via inversion symmetry and phase 
1405               cross-correlation.
1406            5. Returns the final refined center coordinates.
1407    
1408        Parameters
1409        ----------
1410        normalize_bg : bool, optional, default=True
1411            If True, normalize background intensity to reduce artifacts.
1412            
1413        sobel : bool, optional, default=False
1414            If True, applies Sobel filtering (currently unused if not implemented)
1415            
1416        disp : bool, optional, default=False
1417            If True, displays intermediate processing results. 
1418            
1419        masking : bool, optional, default=True
1420            If True, applies masking to exclude unwanted regions from analysis
1421    
1422        Returns
1423        -------
1424        r_final : float
1425            Estimated row-coordinate of the image center after refinement.
1426            
1427        c_final : float
1428            Estimated column-coordinate of the image center after refinement.
1429            
1430        None : NoneType
1431            Placeholder for future functionality (e.g., radius estimation).
1432        """
1433        # (1) Get image  ------------------------------------------------------
1434        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1435        
1436        # if Sobel==True, perform Sobel filtration
1437        # https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ultramic.2016.12.021
1438        if sobel:
1439            image = self.sobel_filt(image,disp)
1440        
1441        
1442        # shift the pixel values (smallest value is zero -> non-negative image)
1443        image -= image.min()
1444
1445        # (2) Prepare mask and compute weighted center ------------------------
1446        if masking:
1447            mask = self.auto_masking(image) 
1448            # print("masked")
1449        else: mask = np.ones_like(image, dtype=bool) # binary mask
1450        
1451        weights = image                        # 
1452        
1453        rr, cc = np.indices(image.shape)       # matrices of row/col indices
1454
1455        # Weighted center of mass (brighter pixels contribute more)
1456        # This gives an initial estimate of the center (r_, c_).
1457        r_ = int(np.average(rr.flatten(), weights=weights.flatten()))
1458        c_ = int(np.average(cc.flatten(), weights=weights.flatten()))
1459
1460        # (3) Crop the image around the estimated center ----------------------
1461        # Some diffraction patterns are not centered, and so there's a lot of 
1462        # image area that cannot be used for registration.
1463        # Radial inversion becomes simple inversion of dimensions
1464        side_length = \
1465            floor(min([r_,abs(r_-image.shape[0]),c_,abs(c_-image.shape[1])]))
1466        rs = slice(r_ - side_length, r_ + side_length)
1467        cs = slice(c_ - side_length, c_ + side_length)
1468        image = image[rs, cs]
1469        mask = mask[rs, cs]
1470    
1471        # (4) Normalize background intensity (optional) -----------------------
1472        # This step removes intensity variations due to experimental artifacts, 
1473        # such as uneven illumination.
1474        if normalize_bg:
1475            with warnings.catch_warnings():
1476                warnings.simplefilter("ignore", category=RuntimeWarning)
1477                image = image.astype(np.float64)  # float64 before division
1478                image /= gaussian_filter(
1479                    input=image, sigma=min(image.shape) / 25, truncate=2)
1480        
1481        # Replace NaN values with 0s
1482        image = np.nan_to_num(image, copy=False)
1483
1484
1485        # (5) Compute inversion symmetry using Fourier methods ----------------
1486        # an inverted copy of the image (im_i) and mask (mask_i), 
1487        # flipping both horizontally and vertically ::-1
1488        im_i = image[::-1, ::-1]
1489        mask_i = mask[::-1, ::-1]
1490
1491        # downsampling to speed up processing (for too large images)
1492        downsampling = 1
1493        if min(image.shape) > 1024:
1494            downsampling = 2
1495    
1496        # phase cross-correlation finds the best alignment between the image
1497        # and its inverted copy
1498        # the shift tells us how much the center is offset from perfect 
1499        # inversion symmetry.
1500        shift, *_ = self.calc_fft(phase_cross_correlation)(
1501            reference_image=image[::downsampling, ::downsampling],
1502            moving_image=im_i[::downsampling, ::downsampling],
1503            reference_mask=mask[::downsampling, ::downsampling],
1504            moving_mask=mask_i[::downsampling, ::downsampling],
1505        )
1506        
1507        # The computed shift is rescaled to match the original image resolution.
1508        correction = shift * downsampling
1509
1510
1511        # (6) User information (if required) ----------------------------------
1512        if (self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print):
1513            self.parent.dText = \
1514                "Center Determination (PhaseCorrCenter): ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1515        
1516        # Ensure correction is a tuple or list before extracting elements
1517        correction_r, correction_c = correction \
1518            if isinstance(correction, (list, tuple, np.ndarray)) \
1519                else (correction, correction)
1520        
1521        r_final = r_ + correction_r / 2
1522        c_final = c_ + correction_c / 2
1523                
1524        return float(r_final), float(c_final), None

Detects the center of symmetry in a diffraction image using a combination of weighted intensity averaging and phase cross-correlation.

This method performs the following steps: 1. Estimates an initial center using a weighted average of pixel intensities. 2. Crops the image to focus on its central region. 3. Optionally normalizes the background to mitigate experimental artifacts. 4. Computes a refined center via inversion symmetry and phase cross-correlation. 5. Returns the final refined center coordinates.

Parameters
  • normalize_bg (bool, optional, default=True): If True, normalize background intensity to reduce artifacts.
  • sobel (bool, optional, default=False): If True, applies Sobel filtering (currently unused if not implemented)
  • disp (bool, optional, default=False): If True, displays intermediate processing results.
  • masking (bool, optional, default=True): If True, applies masking to exclude unwanted regions from analysis
Returns
  • r_final (float): Estimated row-coordinate of the image center after refinement.
  • c_final (float): Estimated column-coordinate of the image center after refinement.
  • None (NoneType): Placeholder for future functionality (e.g., radius estimation).
def detection_crosscorr(self, normalize_bg=True, sobel=False, disp=False): 
1527    def detection_crosscorr(self, normalize_bg=True, sobel=False, disp=False):
1528        """
1529        Detects the center of symmetry in a diffraction image using a 
1530        combination of weighted intensity averaging and cross-correlation.
1531    
1532        This method performs the following steps:
1533            1. Estimates an initial center using the weighted average of pixel
1534               intensities.
1535            2. Crops the image to focus on its central region.
1536            3. Optionally normalizes the background to reduce experimental
1537               artifacts.
1538            4. Computes a refined center by analyzing inversion symmetry 
1539               using cross-correlation.
1540            5. Returns the final corrected center coordinates.
1541    
1542        Parameters
1543        ----------
1544        normalize_bg : bool, optional, default=True
1545            If True, normalizes the background intensity to reduce illumination 
1546            artifacts. 
1547            
1548        sobel : bool, optional, default=False
1549            If True, applies Sobel filtering to enhance edges prior to processing. 
1550            
1551        disp : bool, optional, default=False
1552            If True, displays intermediate processing results.
1553    
1554        Returns
1555        -------
1556        r_final : float
1557            Estimated row-coordinate of the image center after refinement.
1558            
1559        c_final : float
1560            Estimated column-coordinate of the image center after refinement.
1561        """
1562       
1563        # (1) Get image -------------------------------------------------------
1564        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1565        
1566        # Apply Sobel filter if requested
1567        if sobel:
1568            image = self.sobel_filt(image, disp=False)
1569        
1570        # Shift pixel values to ensure non-negative image
1571        image -= image.min()
1572     
1573    
1574        # (2) Normalize background intensity (optional) -----------------------
1575        if normalize_bg:
1576            with warnings.catch_warnings():
1577                warnings.simplefilter("ignore", category=RuntimeWarning)
1578                image = image.astype(np.float64) 
1579                image /= gaussian_filter(image, 
1580                                         sigma=min(image.shape) / 25, 
1581                                         truncate=2)
1582        
1583        # Replace NaN values with 0s
1584        image = np.nan_to_num(image, copy=False)
1585    
1586        # (3) Compute inversion symmetry using cross-correlation --------------
1587        # Dynamically set the margin to a reasonable fraction of the image size
1588        margin = int(np.floor(image.shape[0] // 4))
1589        im_i = image[margin:-margin, margin:-margin]  # Crop slightly
1590        
1591        template = im_i[::-1, ::-1]  # Inverted image for symmetry comparison
1592    
1593        # Compute cross-correlation using OpenCV template matching
1594        # it finds areas in an image that best match a given template. 
1595        # it compares the original image with its inverted version to measure 
1596        # inversion symmetry
1597        # im_i (template) slides over image in a pixel-by-pixel manner.
1598        # at each position, it computes the cross-correlation between 
1599        # overlapping pixels.
1600        # result is a 2D matrix, where each value represents the correlation 
1601        # score at a particular location. Higher values indicate
1602        # better symmetry at that position.
1603        
1604        # Ensure template is smaller than image
1605        assert template.shape[0] <= image.shape[0] \
1606            and template.shape[1] <= image.shape[1], \
1607            "Template is larger than the image"
1608        
1609        result = cv2.matchTemplate(image.astype(np.float32), 
1610                                   template.astype(np.float32), 
1611                                   method=cv2.TM_CCORR_NORMED)
1612        
1613        # Get the location of the best match in `result`
1614        max_location = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(result), result.shape) 
1615        correction_r, correction_c = max_location  
1616        
1617        if disp: 
1618            plt.figure()
1619            plt.imshow(result, cmap="inferno")
1620            plt.title("Correlation matrix")
1621            plt.show()
1622            plt.axis("off")
1623            plt.tight_layout()
1624            plt.show()
1625        
1626        # Adjust to original image coordinates (account for template cropping)
1627        corrected_r = correction_r + template.shape[0] // 2
1628        corrected_c = correction_c + template.shape[1] // 2
1629        
1630        # (4) Visualization ---------------------------------------------------
1631        # Plot with correct alignment
1632        if disp:
1633            
1634            plt.figure()
1635            if self.parent.icut:
1636                orig=np.where(self.parent.to_refine>self.parent.icut,
1637                              self.parent.icut, self.parent.to_refine)
1638            else: orig = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1639            
1640            # Assuming fft_im_i is your Fourier transform image
1641            center_size = 513
1642            center_x = orig.shape[1] // 2
1643            center_y = orig.shape[0] // 2
1644
1645            # Crop the central part of the spectrum
1646            orig = orig[
1647                center_y - center_size // 2:center_y + center_size // 2,
1648                center_x - center_size // 2:center_x + center_size // 2]
1649            
1650            plt.imshow(orig, cmap="gray", origin="lower")
1651            plt.scatter(corrected_c-center_x//2, corrected_r-center_y//2, 
1652                        color="white", marker="x", s=100,
1653                        label = "center")
1654            my_title =  "Location of the highest correlation coefficient"
1655            my_title += "in the original image."
1656            plt.title(my_title)
1657            plt.axis("off")
1658            plt.tight_layout()
1659            
1660            plt.show()
1661        
1662        # (5) User information (if required) ----------------------------------
1663        if self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print:
1664            self.parent.dText = \
1665                "Center Determination (CrossCorrCenter): ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1666
1667        return float(corrected_r), float(corrected_c), None

Detects the center of symmetry in a diffraction image using a combination of weighted intensity averaging and cross-correlation.

This method performs the following steps: 1. Estimates an initial center using the weighted average of pixel intensities. 2. Crops the image to focus on its central region. 3. Optionally normalizes the background to reduce experimental artifacts. 4. Computes a refined center by analyzing inversion symmetry using cross-correlation. 5. Returns the final corrected center coordinates.

Parameters
  • normalize_bg (bool, optional, default=True): If True, normalizes the background intensity to reduce illumination artifacts.
  • sobel (bool, optional, default=False): If True, applies Sobel filtering to enhance edges prior to processing.
  • disp (bool, optional, default=False): If True, displays intermediate processing results.
Returns
  • r_final (float): Estimated row-coordinate of the image center after refinement.
  • c_final (float): Estimated column-coordinate of the image center after refinement.
def detection_intensity(self, csquare, cintensity, plot_results=0, sobel=0): 
1670    def detection_intensity(self, 
1671                            csquare, cintensity, plot_results=0, sobel=0):
1672        '''
1673        Find center of intensity/mass of an array.
1674        
1675        Parameters
1676        ----------
1677        arr : 2D-numpy array
1678            The array, whose intensity center will be determined.
1679            
1680        csquare : int, optional, default is 20
1681            The size/edge of the square in the (geometrical) center.
1682            The intensity center will be searched only within the central
1683            square.
1684            Reasons: To avoid other spots/diffractions and
1685            to minimize the effect of possible intensity assymetry
1686            around the center. 
1687            
1688        cintensity : float, optional, default is 0.8
1689            The intensity fraction.
1690            When searching the intensity center, we will consider only
1691            pixels with intensity > max.intensity.
1692            
1693        Returns
1694        -------
1695        xc, yc : float,float
1696            XY-coordinates of the intensity/mass center of the array.
1697            Round XY-coordinates if you use them for image/array calculations.
1698        '''  
1699        
1700        # (1) Get image/array size --------------------------------------------
1701        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1702        
1703        if sobel:
1704            image = self.sobel_filt(image, disp=False)
1705             
1706        arr = np.copy(image)
1707        xsize,ysize = arr.shape
1708        
1709        # (2) Calculate borders around the central square ---------------------
1710        xborder = (xsize - csquare) // 2
1711        yborder = (ysize - csquare) // 2
1712        
1713        # (3) Create the central square, --------------------------------------
1714        # from which the intensity center will be detected
1715        arr2 = arr[xborder:-xborder,yborder:-yborder].copy()
1716        
1717        # (4) In the central square, ------------------------------------------
1718        # set all values below cintenstity to zero
1719        arr2 = np.where(arr2>np.max(arr2)*cintensity, arr2, 0)
1720        
1721        # (5) Determine the intensity center from image moments ---------------
1722        # see image moments in...
1723        # skimage: https://scikit-image.org/docs/dev/api/skimage.measure.html
1724        # wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_moment -> Centroid
1725        # ---
1726        # (a) Calculate 1st central moments of the image
1727        M = moments(arr2,1)
1728        # (b) Calculate the intensity center = centroid according to www-help
1729        (self.x, self.y) = (M[1,0]/M[0,0], M[0,1]/M[0,0])
1730        # (c) We have centroid of the central square
1731        # but we have to recalculate it to the whole image
1732        (self.x, self.y) = (self.x + xborder, self.y + yborder)
1733        # (d) Radius of a diffraction ring 
1734        self.r = self.get_radius(
1735            self.parent.rtype, 
1736            image, 
1737            self.x, 
1738            self.y,
1739            disp=False)
1740        
1741        # (6) User information (if required) ----------------------------------
1742        if (self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print):
1743            self.parent.dText =\
1744                "Center Determination (IntensityCenter): ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1745
1746        # (7) Plot results (if required) --------------------------------------
1747        if plot_results == 1:
1748           self.visualize_center(self.x, self.y, self.r) 
1749                
1750        # (8) Return the results: ---------------------------------------------
1751        #  a) XY-coordinates of the center
1752        #  b) radius of the circle/diff.ring,
1753        #     from which the center was determined
1754
1755        return(self.x, self.y, self.r)

Find center of intensity/mass of an array.

Parameters
  • arr (2D-numpy array): The array, whose intensity center will be determined.
  • csquare (int, optional, default is 20): The size/edge of the square in the (geometrical) center. The intensity center will be searched only within the central square. Reasons: To avoid other spots/diffractions and to minimize the effect of possible intensity assymetry around the center.
  • cintensity (float, optional, default is 0.8): The intensity fraction. When searching the intensity center, we will consider only pixels with intensity > max.intensity.
Returns
  • xc, yc (float,float): XY-coordinates of the intensity/mass center of the array. Round XY-coordinates if you use them for image/array calculations.
def detection_Hough(self, plot_results=False, sobel=False, live_plot=False): 
1758    def detection_Hough(self, 
1759                        plot_results=False, sobel=False, live_plot=False):
1760        '''        
1761        Perform Hough transform to detect the center of diffraction patterns 
1762        with optional real-time visualization and a final image showing all 
1763        detected circles.
1764    
1765        Parameters
1766        ----------
1767        plot_results : int, binary
1768            If 1, shows the final detected circle.
1769        
1770        sobel : bool, optional, default=False
1771            If True, applies Sobel filtering to enhance edges prior to processing. 
1772            
1773        sobel            
1774        live_plot : bool, optional, default=False
1775            If True, animates the circle detection process and shows all 
1776            detected circles.
1777    
1778        Returns
1779        -------
1780        self.x : float64
1781            x-coordinate of the detected center.
1782            
1783        self.y : float64
1784            y-coordinate of the detected center.
1785            
1786        self.r : float64
1787            Radius of the detected circle.
1788        '''
1789        
1790        ## (0) Image preprocessing --------------------------------------------
1791        im = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1792                    
1793        if self.parent.heq == 0:
1794            if np.sum(im) < 150000:
1795                im[im > 50] = 0  
1796            edges = skf.canny(im, 
1797                              sigma=0.2, 
1798                              low_threshold=80, 
1799                              high_threshold=100)
1800        elif self.parent.heq == 1:
1801            if np.sum(im) > 40000:
1802                im[im > 50] = 0  
1803            edges = skf.canny(im, 
1804                              sigma=0.2, 
1805                              low_threshold=0.80, 
1806                              high_threshold=1)
1807        if sobel:
1808            edges = self.sobel_filt(im, disp=False)
1809
1810        ## (1) Define the radii range for concentric circles ------------------
1811        min_radius, max_radius, radius_step = 50, 120, 10
1812        radii = np.arange(min_radius, max_radius + radius_step, radius_step)
1813    
1814        # Store detected circles
1815        detected_circles = []
1816    
1817        if live_plot:
1818            if self.parent.icut is not None:
1819                image = np.where(im > self.parent.icut, self.parent.icut, im)
1820            else:
1821                image = np.copy(im)
1822                
1823            fig, ax = plt.subplots()
1824            plt.axis("off")
1825            ax.imshow(image, cmap=self.parent.cmap)
1826            plt.title("Live Hough Circle Detection")
1827            plt.ion()  # Turn on interactive mode
1828    
1829        ## (2) Process each radius one at a time ------------------------------
1830        for r in radii:
1831            hough_res = hough_circle(edges, np.array([r]))
1832            accums, x_peaks, y_peaks, _ = hough_circle_peaks(hough_res, 
1833                                                             np.array([r]), 
1834                                                             total_num_peaks=1)
1835    
1836            # Store circle if detected
1837            if len(x_peaks) > 0:
1838                detected_circles.append((x_peaks[0], y_peaks[0], r))
1839    
1840            # Live animation (if enabled)
1841            if live_plot:
1842                ax.clear()
1843                ax.imshow(image, cmap=self.parent.cmap)
1844                plt.title(f"Detecting Circles: Radius {r}px")
1845                for x, y, rad in detected_circles:
1846                    plt.axis("off")
1847                    circ = plt.Circle((x, y), rad, color='red', 
1848                                      fill=False, linewidth=1)
1849                    ax.add_patch(circ)
1850                plt.pause(0.3)
1851    
1852        ## (3) Final detected circle ------------------------------------------
1853        accums ,self.x,self.y,self.r = hough_circle_peaks(
1854            hough_circle(edges, radii),
1855            radii,
1856            total_num_peaks=5
1857        )
1858        
1859        
1860        self.x, self.y, self.r = \
1861            float(self.x[0]), float(self.y[0]), float(self.r[0])
1862    
1863        ## (4) User information -----------------------------------------------
1864        if (self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print):
1865            self.parent.dText = \
1866                "Center Determination (HoughTransform) : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})".\
1867                    format(self.x, self.y)
1868    
1869        ## (5) Final plot with all detected circles (if enabled) --------------
1870        if live_plot:
1871            plt.ioff()  # Turn off interactive mode
1872            plt.close("all")
1873        
1874        
1875            fig_final, ax_final = plt.subplots()
1876            ax_final.imshow(image, cmap=self.parent.cmap)
1877            plt.title("Hough Transform Preliminary Detection")
1878        
1879            for x, y, rad in detected_circles:
1880                circ = plt.Circle((x, y), rad, color='blue', 
1881                                  fill=False, linewidth=1)
1882                ax_final.add_patch(circ)
1883        
1884            # Highlight the final detected circle (red)
1885            circ_final = plt.Circle((self.x, self.y), self.r, 
1886                                    color='red', fill=False, 
1887                                    linewidth=2, label="Selected Circle")
1888            plt.scatter(self.x, self.y, color="red", marker='x', s=60, lw=1)
1889            ax_final.add_patch(circ_final)
1890        
1891            # Create a single blue circle just for the legend
1892            legend_blue = plt.Line2D([0], [0], 
1893                                     color='blue', 
1894                                     linewidth=1, 
1895                                     linestyle='-', 
1896                                     label="Searching Space")
1897        
1898            # Add the legend
1899            ax_final.legend(handles=[legend_blue, circ_final])
1900            plt.axis("off")
1901            plt.tight_layout()
1902
1903            plt.show()
1904    
1905        # Close live plot (to avoid non-closed windows in Jupyter)
1906        plt.close("all")
1907        
1908        ## (6) Final detected circle visualization (if requested) --------------
1909        if plot_results:
1910            self.visualize_center(self.x, self.y, self.r)
1911    
1912        return self.x, self.y, self.r

Perform Hough transform to detect the center of diffraction patterns with optional real-time visualization and a final image showing all detected circles.

Parameters
  • plot_results (int, binary): If 1, shows the final detected circle.
  • sobel (bool, optional, default=False): If True, applies Sobel filtering to enhance edges prior to processing.
  • sobel
  • live_plot (bool, optional, default=False): If True, animates the circle detection process and shows all detected circles.
Returns
  • self.x (float64): x-coordinate of the detected center.
  • self.y (float64): y-coordinate of the detected center.
  • self.r (float64): Radius of the detected circle.
def detection_curvefit(self, plot_results=False): 
1915    def detection_curvefit(self, plot_results=False):
1916        """
1917        Detects the center of a diffraction pattern by fitting a 2D pseudo-Voigt 
1918        function to the central region of the image.
1919     
1920        This method:
1921            - Crops a square region around the image center.
1922            - Fits a 2D pseudo-Voigt peak to the cropped region.
1923            - Returns the refined center coordinates in the original image space.
1924            - Optionally visualizes the result.
1925            - Falls back to the crop center if fitting fails.
1926     
1927        Parameters
1928        ----------
1929        plot_results : bool, optional, default=False
1930            If True, displays the fitted center location on the image. 
1931     
1932        Returns
1933        -------
1934        x : float
1935            Refined x-coordinate of the center (column index).
1936            
1937        y : float
1938            Refined y-coordinate of the center (row index).
1939
1940        """
1941    
1942        def pseudo_voigt_2d(xy, amp, x0, y0, sigma_x, sigma_y, eta):
1943            """
1944            Computes a 2D pseudo-Voigt function, which is a linear combination 
1945            of a Gaussian and a Lorentzian function.
1946        
1947            Parameters
1948            ----------
1949            xy : tuple of numpy.ndarray
1950                A tuple (x, y) containing coordinate meshgrids.
1951                
1952            amp : float
1953                Amplitude of the peak.
1954                
1955            x0, y0 : float
1956                Coordinates of the center of the peak.
1957                
1958            sigma_x, sigma_y : float
1959                Width (standard deviation) of the peak along the x and y axes.
1960                
1961            eta : float
1962                Mixing parameter (0 = pure Gaussian, 1 = pure Lorentzian).
1963        
1964            Returns
1965            -------
1966            numpy.ndarray
1967                Flattened 1D array of function values evaluated at the input 
1968                coordinates.
1969            """
1970            x, y = xy
1971            r_x = (x - x0) / sigma_x
1972            r_y = (y - y0) / sigma_y
1973    
1974            gaussian = np.exp(-(r_x**2 + r_y**2) / 2)
1975            lorentzian = 1 / (1 + r_x**2 + r_y**2)
1976    
1977            return amp * ((1 - eta) * gaussian + eta * lorentzian)
1978        
1979        # Define crop size around the center of the image
1980        crop_size = 100
1981        
1982        # Make a copy of the image to avoid modifying the original
1983        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1984        
1985        # Get the image dimensions
1986        h, w = image.shape
1987        
1988        # Estimate the center of the image
1989        x_center, y_center = w // 2, h // 2
1990    
1991        # Calculate the bounds of the cropped square region
1992        half_crop = crop_size // 2
1993        x_min, x_max = max(0, x_center - half_crop), min(w, x_center + half_crop)
1994        y_min, y_max = max(0, y_center - half_crop), min(h, y_center + half_crop)
1995    
1996        # Crop the image around the center for curve fitting
1997        cropped_image = image[y_min:y_max, x_min:x_max]
1998    
1999        # Create a meshgrid of x and y coordinates for the cropped region
2000        x, y = np.meshgrid(np.arange(cropped_image.shape[1]),
2001                           np.arange(cropped_image.shape[0]))
2002        
2003        # Flatten the meshgrid coordinates and image for use with curve fitting
2004        x_flat, y_flat = x.ravel(), y.ravel()
2005        image_flat = cropped_image.ravel()
2006
2007        # Set initial parameter guesses for curve fitting:
2008        # [amplitude, x0, y0, sigma_x, sigma_y, eta]    
2009        initial_guess = [
2010            np.max(cropped_image),
2011            crop_size // 2,
2012            crop_size // 2,
2013            max(1, crop_size / 5),
2014            max(1, crop_size / 5),
2015            0.5
2016        ]
2017        
2018        # Define bounds for each parameter during optimization
2019        bounds = (
2020            [0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 0],
2021            [np.inf, crop_size, crop_size, crop_size, crop_size, 1]
2022        )
2023    
2024        try:
2025            # Fit the pseudo-Voigt function to the cropped image
2026            popt, _ = curve_fit(
2027                pseudo_voigt_2d,
2028                (x_flat, y_flat),
2029                image_flat,
2030                p0=initial_guess,
2031                bounds=bounds,
2032                max_nfev=2000  # increase if needed
2033            )
2034            
2035            # Extract refined x and y center coordinates from fit
2036            x_refined, y_refined = popt[1], popt[2]
2037            used_fallback = False
2038    
2039        except RuntimeError:
2040            # If fitting fails, fall back to geometric center 
2041            x_refined, y_refined = crop_size // 2, crop_size // 2
2042            used_fallback = True
2043            
2044        # Add the offset of the cropped region to get coordinates in full image
2045        self.x, self.y = x_refined + x_min, y_refined + y_min
2046        
2047        # Print the result if verbose are enabled
2048        if self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print:
2049            self.parent.dText = (
2050                f"Center Determination (CurveFitting) :   ({self.x:.3f}, {self.y:.3f})"
2051                + (" [fallback]" if used_fallback else "")
2052            )
2053            
2054        # Optionally show the result visually
2055        if plot_results:
2056            self.visualize_center(self.x, self.y, 100)
2057    
2058        return self.x, self.y, None

Detects the center of a diffraction pattern by fitting a 2D pseudo-Voigt function to the central region of the image.

This method: - Crops a square region around the image center. - Fits a 2D pseudo-Voigt peak to the cropped region. - Returns the refined center coordinates in the original image space. - Optionally visualizes the result. - Falls back to the crop center if fitting fails.

Parameters
  • plot_results (bool, optional, default=False): If True, displays the fitted center location on the image.
Returns
  • x (float): Refined x-coordinate of the center (column index).
  • y (float): Refined y-coordinate of the center (row index).
def detection_3points(self, plot_results=0): 
2061    def detection_3points(self, plot_results=0):
2062        '''         
2063        Semi-automated detection of the diffraction pattern center using manual 
2064        selection of 3 points.
2065
2066        This method allows the user to manually select 3 points along a visible 
2067        diffraction ring in the image to define a circle. Once selected, 
2068        the center and radius of the circle are automatically computed. After 
2069        that, the user can manually adjust the center position using
2070        an interactive interface.
2071
2072        User Controls (during point selection)
2073        --------------------------------------
2074        - **'1'**: Add a point at the current mouse cursor position 
2075                         (max 3 points).
2076        - **'2'**: Delete the most recently added point.
2077        - **'3'**: Delete the point closest to the mouse cursor.
2078        - **'d'**: When 3 points are selected (DONE), proceed 
2079        - **Close**    : Terminate the process without detecting a center.
2080        
2081        Parameters
2082        ----------
2083        plot_results : int, binary, default=0
2084            Plot the pattern determined by pixels selected by the user.
2085        
2086        Returns
2087        -------
2088        self.x : float64
2089            x-coordinate of the detected center
2090            
2091        self.y : float64
2092            y-coordinate of the detected center
2093            
2094        self.r : float64
2095            radius of the detected center
2096            (if available, othervise returns None)
2097                                    
2098        '''
2099        # (0) Load and prepare image ------------------------------------------
2100        im = self.parent.to_refine
2101        
2102        # Edit contrast with a user-predefined parameter
2103        if self.parent.icut is not None:
2104            if self.parent.verbose==2:
2105                print("Contrast enhanced.")
2106            im = np.where(im > self.parent.icut, 
2107                              self.parent.icut, 
2108                              im)
2109            
2110        # (2) Create a figure and display the image ---------------------------
2111        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 12)) 
2112        
2113        # Allow using arrows to move back and forth between view ports
2114        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].append('left')
2115        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].append('right')
2116 
2117        plt.title("Select 3 points defining one of diffraction circles", 
2118                  fontsize = 20)
2119        ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap, origin="upper")
2120        ax.axis('off')
2121
2122        # (3) User information ------------------------------------------------
2123        instructions = dedent(
2124            """
2125            CenterDetermination :: ThreePoints (semi-automated method)
2126            Select 3 points to define a diffraction circle using keys:
2127              - '1' : define a point at current cursor position
2128              - '2' : delete the last point
2129              - '3' : delete the point closest to the cursor
2130              - 'd' : done = finished = go to the next step
2131            Close the figure to terminate. No center will be detected.
2132            """)
2133
2134        if (self.parent.verbose==1 or self.parent.verbose==2):
2135            print(instructions)
2136       
2137        # (4) Enable interactive mode -----------------------------------------
2138        # (figure is updated after every plotting command
2139        # (so that calling figure.show() is not necessary
2140        plt.ion()
2141 
2142        # (5) Initialization
2143        # Initialize the list of coordinates
2144        self.coords = [] 
2145        
2146        # Initialize all flags and counters
2147        calculate_circle_flag = False          # press 'd' event
2148        termination_flag = False               # close window event
2149        point_counter = 0                      # number of selected points
2150        
2151        # (6) Define the event handler for figure close event -----------------
2152        def onclose(event):
2153            nonlocal termination_flag
2154            termination_flag = True
2155            if self.parent.verbose==2:
2156                print('Execution terminated.')
2157                print("------------------------------------------------------------")
2158
2159 
2160        # Connect the event handler to the figure close event
2161        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('close_event', onclose)
2162        
2163        
2164        # (7) Define the callback function for key press events ---------------
2165        def onkeypress(event):
2166            # nonlocal to modify the flag variable in the outer scope
2167            nonlocal calculate_circle_flag, point_counter, termination_flag
2168            
2169            # Store the zoom level
2170            current_xlim = ax.get_xlim()
2171            current_ylim = ax.get_ylim()
2172 
2173            ## Delete points -- the closest to the cursor
2174            if event.key == '3':
2175                point_counter -= 1
2176                if len(self.coords) > 0:
2177                    pointer_x, pointer_y = event.xdata, event.ydata
2178                    distances = [
2179                        np.sqrt((x - pointer_x)**2 + (y - pointer_y)**2)
2180                        for x, y in self.coords]
2181                    closest_index = np.argmin(distances)
2182                    del self.coords[closest_index]
2183    
2184                    ## Redraw the image without the deleted point
2185                    ax.clear()
2186                    ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap,
2187                              origin="upper")
2188                    for x, y in self.coords:
2189                        ax.scatter(x, y, 
2190                                   c='r', marker='x', 
2191                                   s=self.parent.marker_size)
2192
2193                    my_plot_title = (
2194                        "Select 3 points to define "
2195                        "one of diffraction circles.")
2196                    plt.title(my_plot_title, fontsize=20)
2197                    
2198                    # Retore the previous zoom level
2199                    ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
2200                    ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
2201                    ax.axis('off')
2202                    
2203                    fig.canvas.draw()
2204                else:
2205                    print("No points to delete.")
2206    
2207            # Delete recent point (last added) -- independent on the cursor
2208            if event.key == '2':
2209                # Check if there are points to delete
2210                if point_counter > 0:  
2211                    point_counter -= 1
2212                    if len(self.coords) > 0:
2213                        # Delete the last point in the list
2214                        del self.coords[-1]
2215    
2216                        # Redraw the image without the deleted point
2217                        ax.clear()
2218                        ax.imshow(im, cmap=self.parent.cmap,
2219                                  origin="upper")
2220                        for x, y in self.coords:
2221                            ax.scatter(x, y,
2222                                       c='r', marker='x', 
2223                                       s=self.parent.marker_size)
2224
2225                        my_plot_title = (
2226                            "Select 3 points to define "
2227                            "one of diffraction circles.")
2228                        plt.title(my_plot_title)
2229                        
2230                        # Retore the previous zoom level
2231                        ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
2232                        ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
2233                        ax.axis('off')
2234
2235                        fig.canvas.draw()
2236                else:
2237                    print("No points to delete.")
2238                    
2239            ## Select points 
2240            elif event.key == '1':
2241                # Only allow selecting up to three points
2242                if point_counter < 3:  
2243                    # Save the coordinates of the clicked point
2244                    new_point = (event.xdata, event.ydata)
2245                    
2246                    if new_point in self.coords:
2247                        # Do not allow multiple selection of one point
2248                        print("The selected point already exists.")
2249                    else:
2250                        # Add selected point
2251                        self.coords.append(new_point)
2252    
2253                        # Visualize the selected point on the image
2254                        ax.scatter(event.xdata, event.ydata, 
2255                                   c='r', marker='x', 
2256                                   s=self.parent.marker_size)
2257
2258                        # Restore the previous zoom level
2259                        ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
2260                        ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
2261                        ax.axis('off')
2262
2263                        fig.canvas.draw()
2264    
2265                        point_counter += 1
2266
2267    
2268                if len(self.coords) == 3:
2269                    # Turn off interactive mode
2270                    plt.ioff()
2271    
2272
2273    
2274            # (8) Calculate circle or terminate -------------------------------
2275            elif event.key == 'd':
2276                if len(self.coords) == 3:
2277                    calculate_circle_flag = True
2278 
2279                else:
2280                    print("Select exactly 3 points to calculate the circle.")
2281                    fig.canvas.draw()
2282    
2283        # Connect the callback function to the key press event
