2284        cid0 = fig.canvas.mpl_connect('key_press_event', onkeypress)
2285
2286        # Show the plot 
2287        plt.tight_layout()
2288        ax.axis('off')
2289
2290        plt.show(block=False)
2291      
2292        # Wait for 'd' key event or close the figure if no points are selected
2293        while not calculate_circle_flag and not termination_flag:
2294 
2295            try:
2296                plt.waitforbuttonpress(timeout=0.1)
2297                # Store the zoom level
2298                current_xlim = ax.get_xlim()
2299                current_ylim = ax.get_ylim()
2300 
2301                # Plot detected diffraction pattern
2302                if calculate_circle_flag:
2303 
2304                    self.calculate_circle(plot_results=0)
2305                    
2306                    ax.clear()
2307                    ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap,
2308                              origin="upper")
2309                    # Retore the previous zoom level
2310                    ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
2311                    ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
2312                 
2313                    circle = plt.Circle(
2314                        (self.x, self.y), self.r, color='r', fill=False)
2315                    ax.add_artist(circle)
2316        
2317                    # Plot center point
2318                    center, = ax.plot(self.x, self.y, 'rx', markersize=12)
2319                    plt.title('Manually adjust the position of the center using keys.')
2320        
2321                    # Display the image
2322                    plt.draw()
2323                    ax.axis('off')
2324
2325                    plt.show(block = False)
2326
2327            except KeyboardInterrupt:
2328                print("Execution manually interrupted by user.")
2329                break
2330            except ValueError as e:
2331                print("ValueError:", e)
2332                break
2333           
2334        # If the termination_flag is True, stop the code
2335        if termination_flag: 
2336             print("No points selected. Returned None values.")
2337             sys.exit()
2338             return None, None, None
2339        
2340        # Disconnect key press events
2341        fig.canvas.mpl_disconnect(cid0) 
2342        
2343        # local variables save
2344        self.center = center
2345        
2346        self.backip = [self.x, self.y, self.r]
2347        # Manually adjust the calculated center coordinates
2348        self.x, self.y, self.r = self.adjustment_3points(fig, circle, center)
2349
2350        # Return the results:
2351        # a) XY-coordinates of the center
2352        # b) radius of the circle/diff.ring,
2353        #    from which the center was determined
2354        return(self.x, self.y, self.r)

Semi-automated detection of the diffraction pattern center using manual selection of 3 points.

This method allows the user to manually select 3 points along a visible diffraction ring in the image to define a circle. Once selected, the center and radius of the circle are automatically computed. After that, the user can manually adjust the center position using an interactive interface.

User Controls (during point selection)

  • '1': Add a point at the current mouse cursor position (max 3 points).
  • '2': Delete the most recently added point.
  • '3': Delete the point closest to the mouse cursor.
  • 'd': When 3 points are selected (DONE), proceed
  • Close : Terminate the process without detecting a center.
Parameters
  • plot_results (int, binary, default=0): Plot the pattern determined by pixels selected by the user.
Returns
  • self.x (float64): x-coordinate of the detected center
  • self.y (float64): y-coordinate of the detected center
  • self.r (float64): radius of the detected center (if available, othervise returns None)
def adjustment_3points(self, fig, circle, center, plot_results=0) -> tuple: 
2357    def adjustment_3points(self, fig, circle, center, plot_results=0) -> tuple:
2358        """
2359        Manual/interactive refinement of the diffraction pattern center
2360        after initial detection via 3 points.
2361
2362        User Controls (during point selection)
2363        --------------------------------------
2364        This method allows the user to fine-tune the estimated
2365        center and radius of a diffraction ring,
2366        (which was determined manually by selecting 3 points)
2367        by means of the following interactive keyboard controls:
2368
2369        - Arrow keys (, , , ): Move the center left, right, up, or down
2370        - **'+'** : Increase the radius
2371        - **'-'** : Decrease the radius
2372        - **'b'** : Increase step size (5)
2373        - **'l'** : Decrease step size (/5, with minimum step size 0.5)
2374        - **'d'**: Done  finalize the center and radius
2375        - Closing the figure: Cancels refinement and returns the original input 
2376          center and radius
2377
2378        Parameters
2379        ----------
2380        fig : matplotlib.figure.Figure
2381            The figure window used for interactive refinement.
2382            
2383        circle : matplotlib.patches.Circle
2384            The circle object initially defined from 3 selected points.
2385            
2386        center : tuple
2387            The initial (x, y) center coordinates estimated from the selected 
2388            points.
2389            
2390        plot_results : bool, optional, default=False
2391            If True, the results of the adjustment are visualized.
2392
2393        Returns
2394        -------
2395        xy[0] : float
2396            x-coordinate of the adjusted center of the diffraction pattern.
2397            
2398        xy[1] : float
2399            y-coordinate of the adjusted center of the diffraction pattern.
2400            
2401        r : float
2402            Adjusted radius of the diffraction ring.
2403
2404        Notes
2405        -----
2406        - Interactive adjustments are visualized in real time.
2407        - Intensity sum at the current center/radius is printed if print_sums
2408          is True.
2409        - Arrow key defaults in Matplotlib (e.g., navigation) are temporarily 
2410          disabled to allow movement control.
2411        """
2412                    
2413        # Remove default left / right arrow key press events
2414        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].remove('left')
2415        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].remove('right')
2416        
2417        if (self.parent.verbose==1 or self.parent.verbose==2):
2418            instructions = dedent(
2419            """
2420            CenterDetermination :: ThreePoints (interactive adjustment)
2421            Use these keys:
2422              - '' : move left
2423              - '' : move right
2424              - '' : move up
2425              - '' : move down
2426              - '+' : increase circle radius
2427              - '-' : decrease circle radius
2428              - 'b' : increase step size
2429              - 'l' : decrease step size
2430              - 'd' : refinement done
2431                  
2432            DISCLAIMER: For the purpose of the center position adjustment, 
2433                        the default shortcuts for arrows were removed.
2434            """)
2435            print(instructions)
2436        
2437        if self.parent.print_sums:
2438            print("Intensity sums during refinement:")
2439            
2440        # Initialize variables and flags
2441        self.backip = np.array((self.x, self.y))
2442        xy = np.array((self.x, self.y))
2443        r = np.copy(self.r)
2444        termination_flag = False
2445        
2446        plt.title("Manually adjust the center position.", fontsize=20)
2447
2448        plt.ion()
2449          
2450        ### Define the event handler for figure close event
2451        def onclose(event):
2452            nonlocal termination_flag
2453            termination_flag = True
2454
2455        # Connect the event handler to the figure close event
2456        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('close_event', onclose)
2457        
2458        # Define the callback function for key press events
2459        def onkeypress2(event):
2460            # Use nonlocal to modify the center position in the outer scope
2461            nonlocal xy, r, termination_flag
2462        
2463            # OTHER KEYS USED IN INTERACTIVE FIGURES
2464            #   event.key == '1': select a point in self.detection_3points()
2465            #   event.key == '2': delete the last point in self.detection...
2466            #   event.key == '3': delete a point in self.detection...
2467            #   event.key == '+': increase circle radius
2468            #   event.key == '-': decrease circle radius           
2469            #   event.key == 'b': increase the step size (big step size)
2470            #   event.key == 'l': decrease the step size (little step size)
2471            #   event.key == 'd': proceed in self.detection_3points()
2472        
2473            if event.key in ['up', 'down', 'left', 'right', '+', '-']:                    
2474                if event.key in ['+', '-']:
2475                    r += 1 if event.key == '+' else -1
2476                else:
2477                    # Perform shifts normally
2478                    if event.key == 'up':
2479                        xy[1] -= self.step
2480                    elif event.key == 'down':
2481                        xy[1] += self.step
2482                    elif event.key == 'left':
2483                        xy[0] -= self.step
2484                    elif event.key == 'right':
2485                        xy[0] += self.step
2486                    
2487                    # Print sum only for arrow keys
2488                    if self.parent.print_sums:
2489                        s = self.parent.intensity_sum(self.parent.to_refine, 
2490                                                      xy[0], xy[1], r)
2491                        print(f'{s:.2f}')
2492            
2493            # Terminate the interactive refinement with 'd' key
2494            if event.key == 'd':
2495                termination_flag = True
2496        
2497            # Change step size 
2498            if event.key == 'b':
2499                self.step = self.step * 5
2500        
2501            if event.key == 'l':
2502                self.step = self.step / 5
2503                if self.step < 0.5:
2504                    self.step = 0.5
2505        
2506            # Update the plot with the new center position
2507            circle.set_center((xy[0], xy[1]))  # circle
2508            circle.set_radius(r)               # radius
2509            center.set_data([xy[0]], [xy[1]])  # center
2510        
2511            plt.title("Manually adjust the center position.", fontsize=20)
2512        
2513            # Update the plot
2514            plt.draw()
2515
2516                
2517        # Disconnect the on_key_press1 event handler from the figure
2518        fig.canvas.mpl_disconnect(fig.canvas.manager.key_press_handler_id)
2519        
2520        # Connect the callback function to the key press event
2521        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('key_press_event', onkeypress2)
2522
2523        # Enable interaction mode
2524        plt.ion() 
2525               
2526        # Wait for 'd' key press or figure closure
2527        while not termination_flag:
2528            try:
2529                plt.waitforbuttonpress(timeout=0.1)
2530            except KeyboardInterrupt:
2531                # If the user manually closes the figure, terminate the loop
2532                termination_flag = True
2533                
2534        # Turn off interactive mode
2535        plt.ioff()
2536        
2537        # Display the final figure with the selected center position and radius
2538        plt.tight_layout()
2539
2540        plt.show(block=False)
2541        
2542        # If the termination_flag is True, stop the code
2543        if termination_flag: 
2544            plt.close()  # Close the figure
2545
2546        # User information:
2547        if (self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print):
2548            self.parent.dText = "Center Determination (ThreePoints)    : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
2549        
2550    
2551        return xy[0], xy[1], r

Manual/interactive refinement of the diffraction pattern center after initial detection via 3 points.

User Controls (during point selection)

This method allows the user to fine-tune the estimated center and radius of a diffraction ring, (which was determined manually by selecting 3 points) by means of the following interactive keyboard controls:

  • Arrow keys (, , , ): Move the center left, right, up, or down
  • '+' : Increase the radius
  • '-' : Decrease the radius
  • 'b' : Increase step size (5)
  • 'l' : Decrease step size (/5, with minimum step size 0.5)
  • 'd': Done finalize the center and radius
  • Closing the figure: Cancels refinement and returns the original input center and radius
Parameters
  • fig (matplotlib.figure.Figure): The figure window used for interactive refinement.
  • circle (matplotlib.patches.Circle): The circle object initially defined from 3 selected points.
  • center (tuple): The initial (x, y) center coordinates estimated from the selected points.
  • plot_results (bool, optional, default=False): If True, the results of the adjustment are visualized.
Returns
  • xy[0] (float): x-coordinate of the adjusted center of the diffraction pattern.
  • xy[1] (float): y-coordinate of the adjusted center of the diffraction pattern.
  • r (float): Adjusted radius of the diffraction ring.
Notes
  • Interactive adjustments are visualized in real time.
  • Intensity sum at the current center/radius is printed if print_sums is True.
  • Arrow key defaults in Matplotlib (e.g., navigation) are temporarily disabled to allow movement control.
def calculate_circle( self, plot_results: int) -> tuple[float, float, float, tuple[float, float], matplotlib.patches.Circle]: 
2554    def calculate_circle(self, plot_results:int)->tuple[
2555            float,float,float,tuple[float,float], plt.Circle]:
2556        """
2557        Calculate the center and radius of a circle defined by 3 manually 
2558        selected points.
2559
2560        Given three user-defined points (typically on a diffraction ring), this 
2561        method computes the center and radius of the circle that passes through 
2562        them. Optionally, it visualizes the result including the circle, center, 
2563        and selected points overlaid on the image.
2564
2565        Parameters
2566        ----------
2567        plot_results : int (binary: 0 or 1)
2568            If 1, displays the image with the fitted circle and center.
2569            If 0, skips visualization.
2570
2571        Returns
2572        -------
2573        self.x : float
2574            x-coordinate of the detected circle center.
2575
2576        self.y : float
2577            y-coordinate of the detected circle center.
2578
2579        self.r : float
2580            Radius of the detected circle.
2581
2582        self.center : tuple[float, float]
2583            The (x, y) coordinates of the circle center.
2584
2585        self.circle : matplotlib.patches.Circle
2586            A matplotlib Circle object that can be reused for future plotting.
2587
2588        Notes
2589        -----
2590        - The method uses a geometric approach to calculate the circumcenter
2591          and circumradius.
2592        - For best visual results, ensure the selected points are well spaced 
2593          and belong to the same circular ring.
2594        """
2595        # Extract the coordinates of the points        
2596        x = [self.coords[0][0], self.coords[1][0], self.coords[2][0]]
2597        y = [self.coords[0][1], self.coords[1][1], self.coords[2][1]]
2598        
2599        # Compute the radius and center coordinates of the circle
2600            # a: the squared length of the side between the second 
2601            #    and third points (x[1], y[1]) and (x[2], y[2]).
2602            # b: the squared length of the side between the first 
2603            #    and third points (x[0], y[0]) and (x[2], y[2]).
2604            # c: the squared length of the side between the first 
2605            #    and second points (x[0], y[0]) and (x[1], y[1]).
2606            # s: the twice the signed area of the triangle formed by 3 points
2607            
2608        c = (x[0]-x[1])**2 + (y[0]-y[1])**2
2609        a = (x[1]-x[2])**2 + (y[1]-y[2])**2
2610        b = (x[2]-x[0])**2 + (y[2]-y[0])**2
2611        s = 2*(a*b + b*c + c*a) - (a*a + b*b + c*c) 
2612        
2613        # coordinates of the center
2614        self.x = (a*(b+c-a)*x[0] + b*(c+a-b)*x[1] + c*(a+b-c)*x[2]) / s
2615        self.y = (a*(b+c-a)*y[0] + b*(c+a-b)*y[1] + c*(a+b-c)*y[2]) / s 
2616        
2617        # radius
2618        ar = a**0.5
2619        br = b**0.5
2620        cr = c**0.5 
2621        self.r = ar*br*cr/((ar+br+cr)*(-ar+br+cr)*(ar-br+cr)*(ar+br-cr))**0.5
2622        
2623        # # Print results
2624        # if self.parent.verbose:
2625        #     print("CenterEstimator :: manual center detection")
2626        #     print(f"Center coordinates: {self.x:.2f} {self.y:.2f}")
2627                    
2628        if plot_results==1:
2629            # Create and manage the figure
2630            fig, ax = plt.subplots()
2631            manager = plt.get_current_fig_manager()
2632            manager.window.showMaximized()
2633            ax.imshow(self.parent.image, cmap = self.parent.cmap,
2634                      origin="upper")
2635            
2636            # Plot center and points
2637            center, = plt.plot(self.x, self.y, 
2638                     'rx', 
2639                     label='Center', 
2640                     markersize=12)
2641            plt.scatter(x,y, 
2642                        marker='x', 
2643                        color='palevioletred', 
2644                        label = 'Circle points')
2645            plt.title('Circle found using 3 manually detected points')
2646            
2647            # Circle visualization
2648            circle = plt.Circle((self.x,self.y), 
2649                                self.r, 
2650                                color='palevioletred', 
2651                                fill=False,
2652                                label = 'pattern')
2653            ax.add_artist(circle)
2654            
2655            # Set the aspect ratio to equal to have a circular shape
2656            plt.axis('equal')
2657            
2658            plt.legend(loc='lower center', 
2659                       ncol=2, 
2660                       bbox_to_anchor=(0.5,-0.1), 
2661                       mode='expand', 
2662                       frameon=False)
2663            plt.axis('off')
2664            plt.tight_layout()
2665            plt.show(block=False)
2666
2667        
2668        self.center = (self.x, self.y)
2669        self.circle = plt.Circle((self.x,self.y),self.r)
2670        
2671
2672        return self.x, self.y, self.r, self.center, self.circle

Calculate the center and radius of a circle defined by 3 manually selected points.

Given three user-defined points (typically on a diffraction ring), this method computes the center and radius of the circle that passes through them. Optionally, it visualizes the result including the circle, center, and selected points overlaid on the image.

Parameters
  • plot_results : int (binary (0 or 1)): If 1, displays the image with the fitted circle and center. If 0, skips visualization.
Returns
  • self.x (float): x-coordinate of the detected circle center.
  • self.y (float): y-coordinate of the detected circle center.
  • self.r (float): Radius of the detected circle.
  • self.center (tuple[float, float]): The (x, y) coordinates of the circle center.
  • self.circle (matplotlib.patches.Circle): A matplotlib Circle object that can be reused for future plotting.
Notes
  • The method uses a geometric approach to calculate the circumcenter and circumradius.
  • For best visual results, ensure the selected points are well spaced and belong to the same circular ring.
def get_radius( self, rtype: int, im: numpy.ndarray, x: float, y: float, disp: bool = False) -> float: 
2675    def get_radius(
2676            self, rtype:int, im:np.ndarray, x:float, y:float, disp:bool=False) -> float:
2677        """
2678        Calculate the radius of a circle based on intensity profiles along 
2679        horizontal and vertical axes.
2680    
2681        Parameters
2682        ----------
2683        rtype : integer
2684            Method for radius calculation. Default is 0.
2685            - rtype=0 : peaks matching method
2686            - rtype=1 : radial distribution method
2687            
2688        im : np.ndarray
2689            The 2D image array containing the circle. 
2690            
2691        x : float
2692            The x-coordinate of the circle's center.
2693            
2694        y : float
2695            The y-coordinate of the circle's center.
2696            
2697        disp : bool, optional
2698            If True, visualizes the detected intensity profiles and peaks 
2699            (default is False).
2700    
2701        Returns
2702        -------
2703        float
2704            The estimated radius of the circle. Defaults to 100 if no valid 
2705            radius is detected.
2706        """
2707        # Helper function -----------------------------------------------------
2708        def match_peaks(arr):
2709            """
2710            Find the most similar values across the left and right halves of 
2711            an array, excluding the global maximum.
2712        
2713            This function is typically used for analyzing symmetric patterns 
2714            such as diffraction profiles or intensity histograms. It identifies 
2715            the most similar pair of peaks on either side of the central maximum, 
2716            which is excluded from the comparison.
2717        
2718            Special case:
2719            - If the array contains exactly two elements, it assumes they form 
2720              the best pair and returns their indices directly.
2721            - If one half is empty after removing the central peak,
2722              it returns (None, None).
2723        
2724            Parameters
2725            ----------
2726            arr : np.ndarray or list of float
2727                1D array of values (intensity profile) where symmetric peak
2728                positions are to be matched.
2729        
2730            Returns
2731            -------
2732            best_pair : tuple[int or None, int or None]
2733                Indices of the two most similar values, one from each half of 
2734                the array. Returns (None, None) if no valid pair is found.
2735        
2736            Notes
2737            -----
2738            - The function assumes the most prominent peak (maximum value) lies 
2739              at or near the center and represents the central feature.
2740            - The left and right halves are compared pairwise, and the closest 
2741              match in absolute value difference is returned.
2742            - This is useful for refining radial symmetry or finding symmetric 
2743              ring peaks.
2744            """
2745            if len(arr) < 2:  # Not enough values to compare
2746                if self.parent.verbose==2:
2747                    print("Not enough values to find similar pairs.")
2748                return None, None
2749    
2750            # Special case: if there are exactly 2 peaks, return them
2751            if len(arr) == 2:
2752                if self.parent.verbose==2:
2753                    print("Exactly two peaks detected. Returning them as the best pair.")
2754                return 0, 1
2755    
2756            # Find the index of the highest value
2757            center_idx = np.argmax(arr)
2758    
2759            # Split into left and right halves, excluding the highest value
2760            left = arr[:center_idx]
2761            right = arr[center_idx + 1:]
2762            left_indices = np.arange(center_idx)
2763            right_indices = np.arange(center_idx + 1, len(arr))
2764    
2765            if len(left) == 0 or len(right) == 0:  # Check for empty halves
2766                if self.parent.verbose==2:
2767                    print("One of the halves is empty.")
2768                return None, None
2769    
2770            # Initialize variables for tracking the smallest difference
2771            smallest_diff = np.inf
2772            best_pair = (None, None)
2773    
2774            # Compare each value in the left with every value in the right
2775            for i, l_val in enumerate(left):
2776                for j, r_val in enumerate(right):
2777                    diff = abs(l_val - r_val)
2778                    if diff < smallest_diff:
2779                        smallest_diff = diff
2780                        best_pair = (left_indices[i], right_indices[j])
2781    
2782            return best_pair
2783        
2784        # Peak matching method ------------------------------------------------
2785        if rtype == 0:
2786            self.xpeaks, self.ypeaks = None, None
2787            self.xyvals, self.yyvals = None, None
2788        
2789            x_line = im[int(x), :]
2790            y_line = im[:, int(y)]
2791        
2792            # Define threshold for peak detection
2793            x_thr = 0.5 * max(x_line)
2794            y_thr = 0.5 * max(y_line)
2795        
2796            # Find peaks with dynamic height thresholds
2797            self.xpeaks, _ = find_peaks(x_line, 
2798                                        height=x_thr, 
2799                                        prominence=1, 
2800                                        distance=30)
2801            self.xyvals = x_line[self.xpeaks]
2802            self.ypeaks, _ = find_peaks(y_line, 
2803                                        height=y_thr, 
2804                                        prominence=1, 
2805                                        distance=30)
2806            self.yyvals = y_line[self.ypeaks]
2807        
2808            # Define half the length of the image
2809            half_length_x = x_line.shape[0] / 2
2810            half_length_y = y_line.shape[0] / 2
2811        
2812            # Check the additional condition for xpeaks
2813            if len(self.xpeaks) == 2 and (
2814                (self.xpeaks[0]<half_length_x and self.xpeaks[1]<half_length_x) or
2815                (self.xpeaks[0]>half_length_x and self.xpeaks[1]>half_length_x)):
2816                if self.parent.verbose==2:
2817                    print("xpeaks condition met: Both peaks are on the same side of the center.")
2818                self.pairX = None
2819            else:
2820                self.pairX = match_peaks(self.xyvals)
2821        
2822            # Check the additional condition for ypeaks
2823            if len(self.ypeaks) == 2 and (
2824                (self.ypeaks[0]<half_length_y and self.ypeaks[1]<half_length_y) or
2825                (self.ypeaks[0]>half_length_y and self.ypeaks[1]>half_length_y)):
2826                if self.parent.verbose==2:
2827                    print("ypeaks condition met: Both peaks are on the same side of the center.")
2828                self.pairY = None
2829            else:
2830                self.pairY = match_peaks(self.yyvals)
2831        
2832            # Determine radius based on available pairs
2833            if self.pairX is None or None in self.pairX:
2834                rx_x = None
2835            else:
2836                x1 = self.xpeaks[self.pairX[0]]
2837                x2 = self.xpeaks[self.pairX[1]]
2838                rx_x = abs(x1 - x2) / 2
2839        
2840            if self.pairY is None or None in self.pairY:
2841                rx_y = None
2842            else:
2843                y1 = self.ypeaks[self.pairY[0]]
2844                y2 = self.ypeaks[self.pairY[1]]
2845                rx_y = abs(y1 - y2) / 2
2846        
2847            if rx_x is not None and rx_y is not None:
2848                rx = np.mean([rx_x, rx_y])
2849            elif rx_x is not None:
2850                rx = rx_x
2851            elif rx_y is not None:
2852                rx = rx_y
2853            else:
2854                if self.parent.verbose==2:
2855                    print("No valid pairs detected for radius calculation.")
2856                return 100  # Default radius or error handling
2857        
2858            if disp:
2859                # Plot xline with peaks
2860                plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
2861        
2862                # Plot for xline
2863                plt.subplot(2, 1, 1)
2864                plt.plot(x_line, label='xline')
2865                plt.plot(self.xpeaks, self.xyvals, "ro", label='Peaks')
2866                plt.title('Peaks in xline')
2867                plt.xlabel('Index')
2868                plt.ylabel('Value')
2869                plt.legend()
2870        
2871                # Plot for yline
2872                plt.subplot(2, 1, 2)
2873                plt.plot(y_line, label='yline')
2874                plt.plot(self.ypeaks, self.yyvals, "ro", label='Peaks')  
2875                plt.title('Peaks in yline')
2876                plt.xlabel('Index')
2877                plt.ylabel('Value')
2878                plt.legend()
2879        
2880                plt.tight_layout()
2881                plt.show()
2882        
2883        # Radial distribution method ------------------------------------------
2884        elif rtype == 1:
2885            profile = ediff.radial.calc_radial_distribution(
2886                im, 
2887                center=(x, y)
2888                )
2889            p0, p1 = profile
2890            idx_max = np.argmax(p1[50:]) + 50
2891            rx = p0[idx_max]
2892            max_val = p1[idx_max]
2893    
2894            if disp:
2895                fig, axs = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(8, 3))
2896                axs[0].imshow(im, cmap=self.parent.cmap)
2897                axs[0].add_patch(
2898                    Circle(
2899                        (y, x), rx, 
2900                        edgecolor='red', 
2901                        fill=False, 
2902                        linewidth=2))
2903                axs[0].scatter(y, x, color="red", marker="x")
2904                axs[0].set_title("Initial Estimate")
2905                axs[0].axis('off')
2906                axs[1].plot(p0, p1)
2907                axs[1].set_ylim(0,max_val+20)
2908                axs[1].axvline(rx, 
2909                               color='red', 
2910                               linestyle='--', 
2911                               label='Initial Radius')
2912                axs[1].set_title("Radial Profile")
2913                axs[1].legend()
2914                plt.tight_layout()
2915                plt.show()
2916        
2917        # Return found radius
2918        return rx

Calculate the radius of a circle based on intensity profiles along horizontal and vertical axes.

Parameters
  • rtype (integer): Method for radius calculation. Default is 0.
    • rtype=0 : peaks matching method
    • rtype=1 : radial distribution method
  • im (np.ndarray): The 2D image array containing the circle.
  • x (float): The x-coordinate of the circle's center.
  • y (float): The y-coordinate of the circle's center.
  • disp (bool, optional): If True, visualizes the detected intensity profiles and peaks (default is False).
Returns
  • float: The estimated radius of the circle. Defaults to 100 if no valid radius is detected.
def backend_fft(f): 
2921    def backend_fft(f):
2922        """
2923        Decorator to enforce the use of PocketFFTBackend when utilizing the 
2924        `scipy.fft` module. This ensures that all FFT computations leverage 
2925        the optimized PocketFFT implementation, improving performance, 
2926        particularly for multi-threaded execution.
2927    
2928        Parameters
2929        ----------
2930        f : callable
2931            The function to be wrapped, ensuring it executes within the 
2932            PocketFFTBackend context.
2933    
2934        Returns
2935        -------
2936        callable
2937            A wrapped function that forces the use of PocketFFTBackend.
2938        """
2939        @wraps(f)
2940        def newf(*args, **kwargs):
2941            with set_backend(PocketFFTBackend):
2942                return f(*args, **kwargs)
2943        return newf

Decorator to enforce the use of PocketFFTBackend when utilizing the scipy.fft module. This ensures that all FFT computations leverage the optimized PocketFFT implementation, improving performance, particularly for multi-threaded execution.

Parameters
  • f (callable): The function to be wrapped, ensuring it executes within the PocketFFTBackend context.
Returns
  • callable: A wrapped function that forces the use of PocketFFTBackend.
@backend_fft
def calc_fft(self, fft_function): 
2945    @backend_fft
2946    def calc_fft(self, fft_function):
2947        """
2948        Computes the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) using the specified function.
2949
2950        This method ensures that the FFT operation is executed using 
2951        the PocketFFTBackend, applying optimized settings for improved efficiency.
2952
2953        Parameters
2954        ----------
2955        fft_function : callable
2956            The FFT function to be applied to the data.
2957
2958        Returns
2959        -------
2960        object
2961            The result of the FFT computation.
2962        """
2963        return fft_function

Computes the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) using the specified function.

This method ensures that the FFT operation is executed using the PocketFFTBackend, applying optimized settings for improved efficiency.

Parameters
  • fft_function (callable): The FFT function to be applied to the data.
Returns
  • object: The result of the FFT computation.
def auto_masking(self, im, threshold=0.2, show_mask=False): 
2966    def auto_masking(self, im, threshold=0.2, show_mask=False):
2967        """
2968        Automatically generates a binary mask for an image based on intensity 
2969        thresholding.
2970        
2971        This function determines a lower intensity limit by taking a fraction 
2972        (threshold) of the median of the highest intensity values in the image. 
2973        This helps filter out noise while preserving meaningful features, 
2974        avoiding the influence of hot spots.
2975    
2976        Parameters
2977        ----------
2978        im : ndarray
2979            Input grayscale image as a 2D NumPy array.
2980        
2981        threshold : float, optional
2982            A fraction (default is 0.1) of the median of the highest intensity 
2983            values. Pixels with intensity above this computed limit will be 
2984            included in the mask.
2985    
2986        Returns
2987        -------
2988        mask : ndarray
2989            A boolean mask (same shape as `im`), where `True` indicates pixels 
2990            above the threshold and `False` represents background or noise.
2991    
2992        """
2993        # Find the median of the highest intensity value of the image to avoid 
2994        # hot spots (More stable than median scaling)
2995        lower_limit = np.percentile(im, threshold * 100) 
2996        
2997        # Generate a mask
2998        mask = im > lower_limit
2999        
3000        if show_mask:
3001            plt.figure()
3002            plt.imshow(mask)
3003            plt.title("Beam Stopper Masking")
3004            plt.tight_layout()
3005            plt.axis("off")
3006            plt.show()
3007        
3008        return mask

Automatically generates a binary mask for an image based on intensity thresholding.

This function determines a lower intensity limit by taking a fraction (threshold) of the median of the highest intensity values in the image. This helps filter out noise while preserving meaningful features, avoiding the influence of hot spots.

Parameters
  • im (ndarray): Input grayscale image as a 2D NumPy array.
  • threshold (float, optional): A fraction (default is 0.1) of the median of the highest intensity values. Pixels with intensity above this computed limit will be included in the mask.
Returns
  • mask (ndarray): A boolean mask (same shape as im), where True indicates pixels above the threshold and False represents background or noise.
def visualize_center(self, x: float, y: float, r: float, rd: str) -> None: 
3011    def visualize_center(self, x: float, y: float, r: float, rd: str) -> None:
3012        '''         
3013        Visualize detected diffraction patterns and mark the center.
3014        
3015        Parameters
3016        ----------
3017        tit : string
3018            name of the method used for circle detection
3019            
3020        x : float64
3021            x-coordinate of the detected center
3022            
3023        y : float64
3024            y-coordinate of the detected center
3025            
3026        r : float64
3027            radius of the detected center
3028        
3029        Returns
3030        -------
3031        None.
3032                            
3033        '''
3034        # Load image
3035        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
3036    
3037        if rd=="d":
3038            tit = "Detected center position"
3039        elif rd=="r":
3040            tit = "Refined center position"
3041        else: 
3042            tit = "Center position"
3043            
3044            
3045        if self.parent.icut is not None:
3046            im = np.where(image > self.parent.icut, self.parent.icut, image)
3047        else:
3048            im = np.copy(image)
3049            
3050        # Create a figure and display the image
3051        fig, ax = plt.subplots()
3052        
3053        # Allow using arrows to move back and forth between view ports
3054        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].append('left')
3055        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].append('right')
3056 
3057        plt.title(tit)
3058        ax.axis('off')
3059
3060        # Plot center point
3061        ax.scatter(x,y,
3062                label= f'center:  [{x:.1f}, {y:.1f}]',
3063                marker='x', color="red", s=60)
3064
3065        plt.legend(loc='upper right')
3066        
3067        # Display the image
3068        ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap, origin="upper")
3069        plt.axis('off')
3070        plt.tight_layout()
3071        plt.show(block=False)

Visualize detected diffraction patterns and mark the center.

Parameters
  • tit (string): name of the method used for circle detection
  • x (float64): x-coordinate of the detected center
  • y (float64): y-coordinate of the detected center
  • r (float64): radius of the detected center
Returns
  • None.
class CenterRefinement: 
3075class CenterRefinement:
3076    '''
3077    CenterRefinement - Final refinement of the center of a diffraction pattern.
3078
3079    This class performs refinement of the detected center coordinates in a 2D
3080    diffraction pattern. It supports multiple refinement methods, both manual
3081    and automatic, and optionally saves the refined center to a file.
3082
3083
3084    Parameters
3085    ----------
3086    parent : CenterLocator
3087        Reference to the parent CenterLocator object. Used to access shared
3088        attributes like initial center estimates and configuration flags.
3089        
3090    input_image : str, Path, or numpy.ndarray
3091        The diffraction pattern image, either as a file path or a 2D NumPy array.
3092    
3093        
3094    refinement : str or None, optional, default=None
3095        The refinement method to apply. Options include:
3096        - 'manual': Manual adjustment via user interaction on the selected ring.
3097        - 'sum'   : Automatic refinement by maximizing the intensity sum 
3098        - 'var'   : Automatic refinement by minimizing the intensity variance
3099        If None, no refinement is applied.
3100          
3101    out_file : str, optional
3102        Path to a text file where the refined center coordinates will be saved.
3103    
3104    heq : bool, optional, default=False
3105        Whether to apply histogram equalization to the input image before
3106        processing.
3107    
3108    icut : float, optional, default=None
3109        Cut-off intensity level for processing the image
3110        
3111    cmap : str, optional, default='gray'
3112        Colormap to be used when displaying the image for manual refinement.
3113    
3114    verbose : bool, optional, default=False
3115        Flag to enable or disable informational verbose during processing. 
3116
3117    print_sums : bool, optional, default=False
3118        If True, prints the sum of intensity values for the refined circle 
3119        after each adjustment, relevant only for manual refinement methods.
3120
3121    Returns
3122    -------
3123    None
3124
3125    Notes
3126    -----
3127    - If an unsupported refinement method is provided, the program exits with
3128      an error.
3129    - The coordinates `xx`, `yy`, and radius `rr` can be accessed after
3130      initialization for further analysis or saving.
3131    - The refinement strategy relies on initial estimates provided by the parent 
3132      object.
3133    - Manual refinement supports click-based center adjustments guided by visual 
3134      feedback.
3135    - Sum/variance refinement automatically searches for the most likely center
3136      by evaluating ring statistics.
3137    '''
3138    
3139    def __init__(self, parent,
3140                 input_image, 
3141                 refinement = None,
3142                 in_file = None,
3143                 out_file = None,
3144                 heq = False, 
3145                 icut = None,
3146                 cmap = 'gray',
3147                 verbose = 0,
3148                 print_sums = False):
3149        
3150        ######################################################################
3151        # PRIVATE FUNCTION: Initialize CenterLocator object.
3152        # The parameters are described above in class definition.
3153        ######################################################################
3154        
3155        ## (0) Initialize input attributes ------------------------------------
3156        self.parent = parent
3157        
3158        ## (1) Initialize new attributes --------------------------------------
3159        self.step=0.5
3160        
3161        ## (2) Run functions --------------------------------------------------
3162        if refinement is not None:
3163            # Flag for later
3164            self.ret = 1
3165            par_short = self.parent.center1
3166        
3167            if refinement == "manual":
3168                # Manual refinement method
3169                if parent.determination == 'manual':
3170                    self.xx, self.yy, self.rr = \
3171                        par_short.x, par_short.y, par_short.r
3172                    par_short.x, par_short.y = \
3173                        par_short.backip[0], par_short.backip[1]
3174                    if (self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print):
3175                        self.parent.rText = \
3176                            "Center Refinement (Interactive)       : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
3177                elif parent.determination == 'intensity':
3178                    self.yy, self.xx, self.rr = self.ref_interactive(
3179                        par_short.y, par_short.x, par_short.r)
3180                else:
3181                    self.yy, self.xx, self.rr = self.ref_interactive(
3182                        par_short.x, par_short.y, par_short.r)
3183        
3184            elif refinement == "var":
3185                # Intensity variance refinement
3186                self.xx, self.yy, self.rr = self.ref_var(
3187                    par_short.x, par_short.y, par_short.r)
3188        
3189            elif refinement == "sum":
3190                # Intensity sum refinement
3191                self.xx, self.yy, self.rr = self.ref_sum(
3192                    par_short.x, par_short.y, par_short.r,
3193                    live_plot=self.parent.live_plot)
3194            
3195
3196            else:
3197                print("Selected refinement method is not supported.")
3198                sys.exit()
3199       
3200            plt.close("all")          
3201        else: 
3202            # Flag for later
3203            self.ret = 2
3204            
3205           
3206    def ref_interactive(self, px, py, pr):
3207        """
3208        Manual/interactive refinement of the diffraction pattern center.
3209      
3210        This method allows the user to fine-tune the estimated center
3211        and radius of a diffraction ring through interactive keyboard controls.
3212      
3213        An new window is opened and the user can adjust the position
3214        of the diffraction ring using the following keys (keyboard controls):
3215        - Arrow keys (, , , ): Move the center left, right, up, or down
3216        - '+' : Increase the radius
3217        - '-' : Decrease the radius
3218        - 'b' : Increase step size (5)
3219        - 'l' : Decrease step size (/5, with minimum step size 0.5)
3220        - 'd' : Done  finalize the center and radius
3221        - Closing the figure: Cancels refinement and returns the original input 
3222          center and radius
3223      
3224        Parameters
3225        ----------
3226        fig : matplotlib.figure.Figure
3227            The figure window used for interactive refinement.
3228            
3229        circle : matplotlib.patches.Circle
3230            The circle object known from
3231            the previous step = from the center determination.
3232            
3233        center : tuple
3234            The initial (x, y) center coordinates from
3235            the previous step = from the center determination.
3236            
3237        plot_results : bool, optional, default=False
3238            If True, the results of the adjustment are visualized.
3239      
3240        Returns
3241        -------
3242        xy[0] : float
3243            x-coordinate of the adjusted center of the diffraction pattern.
3244            
3245        xy[1] : float
3246            y-coordinate of the adjusted center of the diffraction pattern.
3247            
3248        r : float
3249            Adjusted radius of the diffraction ring.
3250      
3251        Notes
3252        -----
3253        - Interactive adjustments are visualized in real time.
3254        - Intensity sum at the current center/radius is printed
3255          if *print_sums* argument is True.
3256        - Arrow key defaults in Matplotlib (e.g., navigation)
3257          are temporarily disabled to allow movement control.
3258        """
3259             
3260        # (0) Load original image ---------------------------------------------
3261        im = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
3262
3263        # Edit contrast with a user-predefined parameter
3264        if self.parent.icut is not None:
3265            if self.parent.verbose==2:
3266                print("Contrast enhanced.")
3267            im = np.where(im > self.parent.icut, 
3268                              self.parent.icut, 
3269                              im)
3270            
3271        # (1) Initialize variables and flags ----------------------------------
3272        xy = np.array((px, py))
3273        r = np.copy(pr)
3274        termination_flag = False
3275
3276        # (2) User information ------------------------------------------------
3277        if (self.parent.verbose==1 or self.parent.verbose==2):
3278            instructions = dedent("""
3279            
3280            Interactive refinement. Use these keys:
3281                  - '' : move left
3282                  - '' : move right
3283                  - '' : move up
3284                  - '' : move down
3285                  - '+' : increase circle radius
3286                  - '-' : decrease circle radius
3287                  - 'b' : increase step size
3288                  - 'l' : decrease step size
3289                  - 'd' : refinement done
3290                  
3291            DISCLAIMER: For the purpose of the center shift, the default
3292            shortcuts for left and right arrows were removed.
3293            """)
3294            print(instructions)
3295        
3296        if self.parent.print_sums:
3297            print("Intensity sums during refinement:")
3298            
3299        # (3) Create a figure and display the image ---------------------------
3300        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 12))
3301        
3302        # Allow using arrows to move back and forth between view ports
3303        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].append('left')
3304        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].append('right')
3305        
3306        circle = plt.Circle(
3307            (px, py), pr, color='r', fill=False)
3308        ax.add_artist(circle)
3309
3310        # Plot center point
3311        center, = ax.plot(px, py, 'rx', markersize=12)
3312                    
3313        plt.title('Manually adjust the center position.', 
3314                  fontsize=20)
3315
3316        ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap, origin="upper")
3317        ax.axis('off')
3318        
3319        # (4) Enable interactive mode -----------------------------------------
3320        plt.ion()
3321        
3322
3323        # (5) Display the image -----------------------------------------------
3324        # fig.set_size_inches(self.fig_width, self.fig_height)
3325        plt.show(block=False)
3326        
3327        # (6) Define the event handler for figure close event -----------------
3328        def onclose(event):
3329            nonlocal termination_flag
3330            termination_flag = True
3331 
3332        # Connect the event handler to the figure close event
3333        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('close_event', onclose)
3334
3335        # (7) Define the callback function for key press events ---------------
3336        def onkeypress2(event):
3337            # Use nonlocal to modify the center position in the outer scope
3338            nonlocal xy, r, termination_flag
3339        
3340            # OTHER KEYS USED IN INTERACTIVE FIGURES
3341            #   event.key == '1': select a point in self.detection_3points()
3342            #   event.key == '2': delete the last point in self.detection...
3343            #   event.key == '3': delete a point in self.detection...
3344            #   event.key == '+': increase circle radius
3345            #   event.key == '-': decrease circle radius           
3346            #   event.key == 'b': increase the step size (big step size)
3347            #   event.key == 'l': decrease the step size (little step size)
3348            #   event.key == 'd': proceed in self.detection_3points()
3349        
3350            if event.key in ['up', 'down', 'left', 'right', '+', '-']:                    
3351                if event.key in ['+', '-']:
3352                    r += 1 if event.key == '+' else -1
3353                else:
3354                    # Perform shifts normally
3355                    if event.key == 'up':
3356                        xy[1] -= self.step
3357                    elif event.key == 'down':
3358                        xy[1] += self.step
3359                    elif event.key == 'left':
3360                        xy[0] -= self.step
3361                    elif event.key == 'right':
3362                        xy[0] += self.step
3363                    
3364                    # Print sum only for arrow keys
3365                    if self.parent.print_sums:
3366                        s = self.parent.intensity_sum(self.parent.to_refine, 
3367                                                      xy[0], xy[1], r)
3368                        print(f'{s:.2f}')
3369            
3370            # Terminate the interactive refinement with 'd' key
3371            if event.key == 'd':
3372                termination_flag = True
3373        
3374            # Change step size 
3375            if event.key == 'b':
3376                self.step = self.step * 5
3377        
3378            if event.key == 'l':
3379                self.step = self.step / 5
3380                if self.step < 0.5:
3381                    self.step = 0.5
3382        
3383            # Update the plot with the new center position
3384            circle.set_center((xy[0], xy[1]))  # circle
3385            circle.set_radius(r)               # radius
3386            center.set_data([xy[0]], [xy[1]])  # center
3387        
3388            plt.title("Manually adjust the center position.", fontsize=20)
3389        
3390            # Update the plot
3391            plt.draw()
3392
3393            
3394        # Disconnect the on_key_press1 event handler from the figure
3395        fig.canvas.mpl_disconnect(fig.canvas.manager.key_press_handler_id)
3396        
3397        # Connect the callback function to the key press event
3398        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('key_press_event', onkeypress2)
3399
3400        # Enable interaction mode
3401        plt.ion() 
3402               
3403        # Wait for 'd' key press or figure closure
3404        while not termination_flag:
3405            try:
3406                plt.waitforbuttonpress(timeout=0.1)
3407            except KeyboardInterrupt:
3408                # If the user manually closes the figure, terminate the loop
3409                termination_flag = True
3410         
3411        # (8) Turn off interactive mode ---------------------------------------
3412        plt.ioff()
3413        
3414        # Display the final figure with the selected center position and radius
3415        plt.tight_layout()
3416
3417        plt.show(block=False)
3418        
3419        # If the termination_flag is True, stop the code
3420        if termination_flag: 
3421            plt.close()  # Close the figure
3422
3423        # User information:
3424        if (self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print):
3425            self.parent.rText = "Center Refinement (Interactive)       : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
3426
3427        return xy[0], xy[1], r    
3428        
3429    
3430    def ref_var(self, px, py, pr, plot_results=0):
3431        """
3432        Refine the center coordinates (px, py) and radius (pr) of a circular 
3433        diffraction pattern by minimizing the variance of pixel intensities 
3434        along the circle's border.
3435
3436        This method performs iterative local search in the 8-neighbourhood 
3437        around the current center to find a position and radius that minimize 
3438        the intensity variance. The refinement stops when convergence criteria 
3439        are met or after a maximum number of iterations.
3440
3441        Neighborhood pattern tested (o = current center, x = candidate center):
3442            x x x   --> (px - dx, py + dy) (px, py + dy) (px + dx, py + dy)
3443            x o x   --> (px - dx, py)      (px, py)      (px + dx, py)
3444            x x x   --> (px - dx, py - dy) (px, py - dy) (px + dx, py - dy)
3445
3446        Parameters
3447        ----------
3448        px : float
3449            Initial x-coordinate of the detected center.
3450            
3451        py : float
3452            Initial y-coordinate of the detected center.
3453            
3454        pr : float
3455            Initial radius of the detected circular pattern.
3456            
3457        plot_results : int, optional (default=0)
3458            Whether to plot the refinement result (1 = yes, 0 = no).
3459
3460        Returns
3461        -------
3462        px : float
3463            Refined x-coordinate of the center.
3464            
3465        py : float
3466            Refined y-coordinate of the center.
3467            
3468        pr : float
3469            Refined radius of the circular pattern.
3470
3471        Notes
3472        -----
3473        - The function avoids overfitting to local minima by enforcing 
3474          convergence thresholds and consistency checks.
3475        - If the refinement worsens the initial variance significantly or 
3476          suggests an invalid coordinate swap, the original input is preserved.
3477        - Uses `self.parent.intensity_variance()` for evaluating the criterion.
3478        """
3479        
3480        # Store input for plot
3481        bckup = [np.copy(px), np.copy(py), np.copy(pr)]
3482        
3483        # Load image
3484        image = np.copy(self.parent.image)
3485
3486        # Starting values to be modified 
3487        init_var = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, px, py, pr)
3488        min_intensity_var = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, px, py, pr)
3489        best_center = (np.copy(px), np.copy(py))
3490        best_radius = np.copy(pr)
3491    
3492        # Convergence criterion for termination of gradient optimization 
3493        # (1) small positive value that serves as a threshold to determine 
3494        #     when the optimization process has converged
3495        convergence_threshold = 0.1*min_intensity_var
3496        
3497        # (2) maximum number of iterations of optimization
3498        max_iterations = 10
3499        
3500        # (3) keep track of the number of consecutive iterations where there 
3501        #     is no improvement in the objective function beyond 
3502        #     the convergence threshold
3503        no_improvement_count = 0
3504    
3505    
3506        # iterative refinement of the center of a circle while keeping
3507        # the radius constant.
3508        step = 0.3
3509        neighbors = [(float(dx), float(dy))
3510            for dx in np.arange(-1, 1 + step, step)
3511            for dy in np.arange(-1, 1 + step, step)]
3512        
3513        for iteration in range(max_iterations):    
3514            # Refine center while keeping radius constant
3515            curr = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, 
3516                                      best_center[0], 
3517                                      best_center[1], 
3518                                      best_radius) 
3519            # Store intensity sums of the current center's neighborhood
3520            curr_intensity_var = []
3521            for dx, dy in neighbors:
3522                nx, ny = best_center[0] + dx, best_center[1] + dy
3523                # Check if the point is within the expanded search radius
3524                curr_intensity_var.append(
3525                    self.parent.intensity_variance(image, nx, ny, best_radius))
3526            
3527            # Find the minimum value coordinates within curr_intensity_var
3528            cx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmin(curr_intensity_var),
3529                                     [len(curr_intensity_var),1])
3530                    
3531            # Check for improvement of criterion -- in each iteration just once,
3532            # as the algorithm checks the neighbourhood of the best center (in
3533            # each iteration, the center is updated if possible)
3534            if min(curr_intensity_var) <= min_intensity_var:                           
3535                min_intensity_var = max(curr_intensity_var)
3536                
3537                # Calculate the new best coordinates of the center
3538                n = neighbors[cx]
3539                (nx, ny) = tuple(map(lambda x, y: float(x) + float(y), 
3540                                     best_center, n))
3541                best_center = px, py = (np.copy(nx), np.copy(ny))
3542                
3543            # Update maximum intensity sum 
3544            min_intensity_var = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, 
3545                                                    best_center[0], 
3546                                                    best_center[1], 
3547                                                    best_radius) 
3548            
3549            # Refine radius if necessary while keeping the center position 
3550            # constant. It iterates through different radius adjustments
3551            # to find a radius that maximizes the intensity sum of pixels.
3552            
3553            radi_intensity_var = []
3554            radii = np.arange(-1, 1 + step, step)
3555            for dr in radii:
3556                new_radius = best_radius + dr
3557                radi_intensity_var.append(self.parent.intensity_variance(image, 
3558                                                             best_center[0], 
3559                                                             best_center[1], 
3560                                                             new_radius))
3561                
3562            # Find the minimum value coordinates within curr_var
3563            rx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmin(radi_intensity_var),
3564                                      [len(radi_intensity_var),1])
3565            
3566            # Check for improvement of criterion
3567            if max(radi_intensity_var) < min_intensity_var:
3568                min_intensity_var = max(radi_intensity_var)
3569                
3570                n = radii[rx]
3571                nr = best_radius+n
3572                
3573                best_radius = pr = np.copy(nr)
3574
3575            
3576            # Check for convergence and improvement (termination conditions)
3577            impr = abs(min_intensity_var - curr)
3578            if impr < convergence_threshold:
3579                no_improvement_count += 1
3580                if no_improvement_count == 5:
3581                    break
3582        
3583        # Avoid incorrect/redundant refinement
3584        ## (1) swapped coordinates
3585        if ((bckup[0] > bckup[1] and not best_center[0] > best_center[1])
3586            or  (bckup[0] < bckup[1] and not best_center[0] < best_center[1])):
3587            best_center = best_center[::-1]
3588        
3589        ## (2) worsened final maximum intensity sum than the initial one
3590        if np.round(init_var,-2) < np.round(min_intensity_var,-2):
3591            print("Refinement redundant.")
3592            best_center = np.copy(bckup)
3593    
3594        # Print results
3595        if (self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print):
3596            self.parent.rText = \
3597                "Center Refinement (IntensityVar)      : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
3598                                  
3599        return best_center[0], best_center[1], best_radius
3600    
3601    
3602    def ref_sum(self, px, py, pr, plot_results=0, live_plot=False):
3603        """
3604        Refine the center coordinates (px, py) and radius (pr) of a circular 
3605        diffraction pattern by maximizing the summed pixel intensity along 
3606        a circular ring.
3607
3608        The method uses an iterative local search strategy based on gradient 
3609        ascent in the 8-neighbourhood around the current center to find 
3610        a position and radius that maximize the intensity sum. The center 
3611        is updated based on the best neighbor until convergence criteria 
3612        or maximum iteration limits are met.
3613
3614        Neighborhood pattern tested (o = current center, x = candidate center):
3615            x x x   --> (px - dx, py + dy) (px, py + dy) (px + dx, py + dy)
3616            x o x   --> (px - dx, py)      (px, py)      (px + dx, py)
3617            x x x   --> (px - dx, py - dy) (px, py - dy) (px + dx, py - dy)
3618
3619        Parameters
3620        ----------
3621        px : float
3622            Initial x-coordinate of the detected center.
3623            
3624        py : float
3625            Initial y-coordinate of the detected center.
3626            
3627        pr : float
3628            Initial radius of the detected circular pattern.
3629            
3630        plot_results : int, optional (default=0)
3631            If set to 1, plots the final result of the refinement.
3632
3633        Returns
3634        -------
3635        px : float
3636            Refined x-coordinate of the center.
3637            
3638        py : float
3639            Refined y-coordinate of the center.
3640            
3641        pr : float
3642            Refined radius of the circular pattern.
3643
3644        Notes
3645        -----
3646        - Uses `self.parent.intensity_sum()` as the optimization criterion.
3647        - Alternates between optimizing the center and the radius.
3648        - Stops after no significant improvement over multiple iterations.
3649        - If refinement worsens the result, the original values are retained.
3650        """
3651        # Store input for plot via self.visualize_refinement()
3652        bckup = [np.copy(px), np.copy(py), np.copy(pr)]
3653    
3654        # Image in which the center is refined
3655        image = np.copy(self.parent.image)
3656    
3657        # Starting values to be modified 
3658        init_sum = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, px, py, pr)
3659        max_intensity_sum = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, px, py, pr)
3660        best_center = (np.copy(px), np.copy(py))
3661        best_radius = np.copy(pr)
3662        
3663        # Convergence criterion for termination of gradient optimization 
3664        # (1) small positive value that serves as a threshold to determine 
3665        #     when the optimization process has converged
3666        convergence_threshold = 0.05*max_intensity_sum
3667        
3668        # (2) maximum number of iterations of optimization
3669        max_iterations = 100
3670        
3671        # (3) keep track of the number of consecutive iterations where there 
3672        #     is no improvement in the objective function beyond 
3673        #     the convergence threshold
3674        no_improvement_count = 0
3675         
3676        # iterative refinement of the center of a circle while keeping
3677        # the radius constant.
3678        step = 0.2
3679        neighbors = [(float(dx), float(dy))
3680            for dx in np.arange(-1.0, 1.0 + step, step)
3681            for dy in np.arange(-1.0, 1.0 + step, step)]
3682        
3683        # Live plot initialization 
3684        if live_plot:
3685            plt.ion()
3686            fig, ax = plt.subplots()
3687            ax.imshow(image, cmap='gray')
3688            circ_artist = Circle(best_center, best_radius, 
3689                                 fill=False, color='red', lw=1.5)
3690            ax.add_patch(circ_artist)
3691            ax.set_title("Refinement Progress")
3692            ax.axis("off")
3693            fig.show()
3694    
3695        for iteration in range(max_iterations):    
3696            # Refine center while keeping radius constant
3697            curr = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
3698                                      best_center[0], 
3699                                      best_center[1], 
3700                                      best_radius)
3701            
3702            # Store intensity sums of the current center's neighborhood
3703            curr_intensity_sum = []
3704            for dx, dy in neighbors:
3705                nx, ny = best_center[0] + dx, best_center[1] + dy
3706                # Check if the point is within the expanded search radius
3707                curr_intensity_sum.append(self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
3708                                                        nx, ny, 
3709                                                        best_radius))
3710            
3711            # Find the maximum value coordinates within curr_sum
3712            cx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(curr_intensity_sum),
3713                                     [len(curr_intensity_sum),1])
3714                    
3715            # Check for improvement of criterion - in each iteration just once,
3716            # as the algorithm checks the neighbourhood of the best center
3717            # (in each iteration, the center is updated if possible)
3718            if max(curr_intensity_sum) > max_intensity_sum:                           
3719                max_intensity_sum = max(curr_intensity_sum)
3720                
3721                # Calculate the new best coordinates of the center
3722                n = neighbors[cx]
3723                (nx, ny) = tuple(map(lambda x, y: float(x) + float(y), 
3724                                     best_center, n))
3725                best_center = px, py = (np.copy(nx), np.copy(ny))
3726    
3727            # Update maximum intensity sum 
3728            max_intensity_sum = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
3729                                                    best_center[0], 
3730                                                    best_center[1], 
3731                                                    best_radius)
3732    
3733        
3734            # Refine radius if necessary while keeping the center position 
3735            # constant. It iterates through different radius adjustments
3736            # to find a radius that maximizes the intensity sum of pixels.
3737            
3738            radi_intensity_sum = []
3739            radii = np.arange(-1.0, 1.0 + step, step)
3740            for dr in radii:
3741                new_radius = best_radius + dr
3742                radi_intensity_sum.append(self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
3743                                                            best_center[0], 
3744                                                            best_center[1], 
3745                                                            new_radius))
3746                
3747            # Find the maximum value coordinates within curr_sum
3748            rx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(radi_intensity_sum),
3749                                      [len(radi_intensity_sum),1])
3750    
3751            # Check for improvement of criterion
3752            if max(radi_intensity_sum) > max_intensity_sum:
3753                max_intensity_sum = max(radi_intensity_sum)
3754                
3755                n = radii[rx]
3756                nr = best_radius+n
3757                
3758                best_radius = pr = np.copy(nr)
3759                
3760            
3761            # Check for convergence and improvement (termination conditions)
3762            impr = abs(max_intensity_sum - curr)
3763            if impr < convergence_threshold:
3764                no_improvement_count += 1
3765                if no_improvement_count == 25:
3766                    break
3767                
3768            # --- Live plot update ---
3769            if live_plot:
3770                circ_artist.center = best_center
3771                circ_artist.set_radius(best_radius)
3772                ax.set_title(
3773                    f"Iteration {iteration+1} | Sum={max_intensity_sum:.1f}")
3774                fig.canvas.draw()
3775                fig.canvas.flush_events()
3776                plt.pause(0.01)  # small delay for visual update
3777        
3778        # Avoid incorrect/redundant refinement
3779        # ## (1) swapped coordinates
3780        # if ((bckup[0] > bckup[1] and not best_center[0] > best_center[1])
3781        #     or  (bckup[0] < bckup[1]
3782        #     and not best_center[0] < best_center[1])):
3783        #     best_center = best_center[::-1]
3784        
3785        ## (2) worsened final maximum intensity sum than the initial one
3786        if np.round(init_sum,-2) > np.round(max_intensity_sum,-2):
3787            print("Refinement redundant.")
3788            best_center = np.copy(bckup)
3789    
3790        # Print results
3791        if (self.parent.verbose or self.parent.final_print):
3792            self.parent.rText = \
3793                "Center Refinement (IntensitySum)      : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
3794        
3795        if live_plot:
3796            plt.ioff()
3797            plt.show()
3798
3799        return best_center[0], best_center[1], best_radius
3800    
3801    
3802    def diagnose_landscape(self, px, py, pr, metric='std', search_range=2.0, steps=21):
3803        """
3804        Visualize the optimization landscape of a center refinement metric
3805        around a candidate center location and radius.
3806    
3807        This function evaluates the selected metric over a grid of positions
3808        in a 2D neighborhood around the given (px, py) center, using a fixed
3809        radius `pr`, and visualizes the results as a heatmap with contours.
3810    
3811        It can be useful for diagnosing whether the optimization function
3812        (e.g., standard deviation, median, or sum of pixel intensities) has
3813        a smooth and well-behaved landscape, which is important for gradient
3814        optimization methods.
3815    
3816        Parameters
3817        ----------
3818        px : float
3819            X-coordinate of the candidate center.
3820            
3821        py : float
3822            Y-coordinate of the candidate center.
3823            
3824        pr : float
3825            Radius of the circular region to evaluate the metric on.
3826            
3827        metric : str, optional
3828            The metric to evaluate. Options are:
3829            - 'std': standard deviation of pixel values (default)
3830            - 'median': median of pixel values
3831            - 'sum': sum of pixel values
3832            
3833        search_range : float, optional, default=2.0
3834            The radius of the square region (in pixels) around the center 
3835            to explore. The grid will extend `search_range` in both x and y 
3836            directions.
3837            
3838        steps : int, optional, default=21
3839            The number of points to sample along each axis (grid resolution).
3840            Must be an odd number to ensure the center point is included.
3841    
3842        Returns
3843        -------
3844        None
3845            This method produces a matplotlib plot and does not return any value.
3846        """
3847        # Helper functions ----------------------------------------------------
3848        def intensity_sum(self, image, cx, cy, r):
3849            pixels = self.parent.get_circle_pixels(image, cx, cy, r)
3850            return np.sum(pixels)
3851        
3852        def intensity_std(self, image, cx, cy, r):
3853            pixels = self.parent.get_circle_pixels(image, cx, cy, r)
3854            return np.std(pixels)
3855        
3856        def intensity_median(self, image, cx, cy, r):
3857            pixels = self.parent.get_circle_pixels(image, cx, cy, r)
3858            return np.median(pixels)
3859
3860        print(f"Diagnosing landscape around ({px:.1f}, {py:.1f}) with r={pr:.1f}...")
3861        
3862        # (0) Select the metric function --------------------------------------
3863        metric_map = {'std': intensity_std, 
3864                      'median': intensity_median, 
3865                      'sum': intensity_sum }
3866        metric_func = metric_map.get(metric, intensity_std)
3867    
3868        # (1) Create a grid of x and y coordinates to test --------------------
3869        x_range = np.linspace(px - search_range, px + search_range, steps)
3870        y_range = np.linspace(py - search_range, py + search_range, steps)
3871        score_grid = np.zeros((steps, steps))
3872    
3873        # (2) Calculate the metric score at each point on the grid ------------
3874        for i, y in enumerate(y_range):
3875            for j, x in enumerate(x_range):
3876                score_grid[i, j] = metric_func(self.parent.image, x, y, pr)
3877    
3878        # (3) Plot the results ------------------------------------------------
3879        plt.figure(figsize=(4, 4))
3880        plt.imshow(
3881            score_grid, 
3882            origin='lower', 
3883            extent=[x_range[0], x_range[-1], y_range[0], y_range[-1]]
3884            )
3885        plt.colorbar(label=f"Metric Score ('{metric}')")
3886        plt.contour(x_range, y_range, score_grid, colors='white', alpha=0.5)
3887        
3888        # Mark the starting point
3889        plt.plot(px, py, 'r+', markersize=15, label='Initial Guess')
3890        plt.title("Optimization Landscape")
3891        plt.xlabel("X-coordinate")
3892        plt.ylabel("Y-coordinate")
3893        plt.legend()
3894        plt.show()

CenterRefinement - Final refinement of the center of a diffraction pattern.

This class performs refinement of the detected center coordinates in a 2D diffraction pattern. It supports multiple refinement methods, both manual and automatic, and optionally saves the refined center to a file.

Parameters
  • parent (CenterLocator): Reference to the parent CenterLocator object. Used to access shared attributes like initial center estimates and configuration flags.
  • input_image (str, Path, or numpy.ndarray): The diffraction pattern image, either as a file path or a 2D NumPy array.
  • refinement (str or None, optional, default=None): The refinement method to apply. Options include:
    • 'manual': Manual adjustment via user interaction on the selected ring.
    • 'sum' : Automatic refinement by maximizing the intensity sum
    • 'var' : Automatic refinement by minimizing the intensity variance If None, no refinement is applied.
  • out_file (str, optional): Path to a text file where the refined center coordinates will be saved.
  • heq (bool, optional, default=False): Whether to apply histogram equalization to the input image before processing.
  • icut (float, optional, default=None): Cut-off intensity level for processing the image
  • cmap (str, optional, default='gray'): Colormap to be used when displaying the image for manual refinement.
  • verbose (bool, optional, default=False): Flag to enable or disable informational verbose during processing.
  • print_sums (bool, optional, default=False): If True, prints the sum of intensity values for the refined circle after each adjustment, relevant only for manual refinement methods.
Returns
  • None
Notes
  • If an unsupported refinement method is provided, the program exits with an error.
  • The coordinates xx, yy, and radius rr can be accessed after initialization for further analysis or saving.
  • The refinement strategy relies on initial estimates provided by the parent object.
  • Manual refinement supports click-based center adjustments guided by visual feedback.
  • Sum/variance refinement automatically searches for the most likely center by evaluating ring statistics.
def ref_interactive(self, px, py, pr): 
3206    def ref_interactive(self, px, py, pr):
3207        """
3208        Manual/interactive refinement of the diffraction pattern center.
3209      
3210        This method allows the user to fine-tune the estimated center
3211        and radius of a diffraction ring through interactive keyboard controls.
3212      
3213        An new window is opened and the user can adjust the position
3214        of the diffraction ring using the following keys (keyboard controls):
3215        - Arrow keys (, , , ): Move the center left, right, up, or down
3216        - '+' : Increase the radius
3217        - '-' : Decrease the radius
3218        - 'b' : Increase step size (5)
3219        - 'l' : Decrease step size (/5, with minimum step size 0.5)
